story:
The Grey Bruce Arts Collective (GBAC) Presents:

"Beautiful Joe" and "The Tank Range Project"

Two exciting new plays to be performed at Stratford's SpringWorks Festival in May, 2012. 

GBAC is founded by Roger Shank, Jamie Robinson and Julie Miles.

Thanks to all who came out for the successful Toronto fundraiser at Motel Bar on April 26th.

Special Note:
If you prefer helping us through cheque instead of online, you can make the cheque out to "The Grey Bruce Arts Collective". Leave a comment at our email address, greybruceartscollective@gmail.com, and we'll give you the mailing address. As always, thank you for your support.

See the gallery link above for video and pictures about our shows.

Having already performed staged readings of both plays in the fall of 2010 in the town of Meaford, Ontario, this next phase of the work has been highly anticipated. Audience reactions from those readings include:

  • "A unique and refreshing experience."

  • "For the municipality it is a wonderful thing to bring our stories to life."

  • "I found these plays very powerful."

Beautiful Joe 

Beautiful Joe is based upon the classic 1894 novel by Canadian author and activist, Margaret Marshall Saunders (1861-1947), at the time, Canada's best selling book. Written by award-winning Canadian Playwright Michael O'Brien, Beautiful Joe is a play with a passionate message about a real-life farm-dog born near Meaford, Ontario, who suffered cruel abuse at the hands of his master. The story is told from the perspective of the rescued dog Joe, as he recounts his adventures in an inhumane world through mask, puppetry and song in this moving, funny, heart-warming tale for the whole family—set in a distinctly Canadian landscape. Beautiful Joe has been assisted by the Ontario Arts Council, Theatre Direct Canada and Young People's Theatre.

The Tank Range Project 

In 1942, The Government of Canada forced 100 families off of 17000 acres of farmland in the St. Vincent Township of Southwestern Ontario, to be used as an Armored Vehicle Fighting area to train for the war effort overseas. The Tank Range Project is a play that explores this history by dramatically contrasting the importance of those farmers’ original sacrifices, to the land’s use for the military conflict in Afghanistan today. This collaborative piece, written by GBAC company founders Jamie Robinson and Roger Shank, is a mix of fictional drama and biography, including interviews of former St. Vincent Township residents and current military personnel, in addition to reviews of dozens of news articles and books written about the expropriation. In 2010, The Tank Range Project received a Stratford Tyrone Guthrie Award for new play development.

Our History and Intent

  • The Grey Bruce Arts Collective was launched in 2009, creating dynamic new works about local rural stories in the Georgian Bay area. Since then, Co-Artistic Directors Jamie Robinson and Roger Shank, along with key administrator Julie Miles, have expanded their reach to popular Ontario Theatre towns such as Blyth, Thornbury and Stratford.
  • With a cast of 7 professional and upcoming actors and a creative team of well established artisans behind the scenes, both plays are sure to make an impact upon the rural theatrical stage.
  • Your contributions will ensure that both plays get a polished, top-notch presentation at the upcoming SpringWorks Festival this May. With your help, we are certain to have both shows noticed by established Theatres in Ontario for consideration in future seasons' playbills.

What We Need & What You Get

Funding for this project will pay for:

  • Transportation and accomodation provided for out of town artists.
  • An aggressive publicity campaign to get audiences into seats.
  • A fair distribution of funds to a team of highly trained artisans for their rehearsal time and performance ensuring the best show possible.

Depending on the amount you contribute, you could get:

  • Exclusive Straford Theatre Festival show tickets and packages
  • Tickets to the SpringWorks shows
  • Signed copies of both scripts by the writers
  • Acknowledgment in future playbill programs
  • Stratford Restaurant Entrees
  • Hand-made masks from the shows
  • Tax receipts available for each perk upon request
If we do not reach our financial goal, any funds raised will still help cover out of town costs, publicity and fair distribution among artists. Nothing will be wasted.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot contribute, that doesn’t mean you can’t help:

  • Get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that’s all there is to it. Thank you, and we will see you at the Theatre!

Two exciting new plays to be performed at Stratford's SpringWorks Festival in May, 2012. 

GBAC is founded by Roger Shank, Jamie Robinson and Julie Miles.

Having already performed staged readings of both plays in the fall of 2010 in the town of Meaford, Ontario, this next phase of the work has been highly anticipated. Audience reactions from those readings include:



"A unique and refreshing experience."


"For the municipality it is a wonderful thing to bring our stories to life."


"I found these plays very powerful."

Beautiful Joe has been assisted by the Ontario Arts Council, Theatre Direct Canada and Young People's Theatre.

In 2010, The Tank Range Project received a Stratford Tyrone Guthrie Award for new play development.
Our History and Intent

The Grey Bruce Arts Collective was launched in 2009, creating dynamic new works about local rural stories in the Georgian Bay area. Since then, Co-Artistic Directors Jamie Robinson and Roger Shank, along with key administrator Julie Miles, have expanded their reach to popular Ontario Theatre towns such as Blyth, Thornbury and Stratford.
With a cast of 7 professional and upcoming actors and a creative team of well established artisans behind the scenes, both plays are sure to make an impact upon the rural theatrical stage.
Your contributions will ensure that both plays get a polished, top-notch presentation at the upcoming SpringWorks Festival this May. With your help, we are certain to have both shows noticed by established Theatres in Ontario for consideration in future seasons' playbills.



What We Need & What You Get
Funding for this project will pay for:

Transportation and accomodation provided for out of town artists.
An aggressive publicity campaign to get audiences into seats.
A fair distribution of funds to a team of highly trained artisans for their rehearsal time and performance ensuring the best show possible.

Depending on the amount you contribute, you could get:

Exclusive Straford Theatre Festival show tickets and packages
Tickets to the SpringWorks shows
Signed copies of both scripts by the writers
Acknowledgment in future playbill programs
Stratford Restaurant Entrees
Hand-made masks from the shows
Tax receipts available for each perk upon request

If we do not reach our financial goal, any funds raised will still help cover out of town costs, publicity and fair distribution among artists. Nothing will be wasted.

Other Ways You Can Help
If you cannot contribute, that doesn’t mean you can’t help:

Get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
Use the Indiegogo share tools!


And that’s all there is to it. Thank you, and we will see you at the Theatre!

story:
Inspired Dance Scholarship

A New York Creative Arts School looking to raise funds to provide 42 dance scholarships for a one year enrollment to Dunamis Creative Arts School & Ministry (Dunamis CASM), to excelling teenagers from under served and under privileged communities who have a desire to learn dance. Inspired Dance Scholarships was created to provide dance classes to students who have the desire to dance but do not have the financial means to take classes. 

Your contribution to the Inspired Dance Scholarship also provides an opportunity for youth to learn and express themselves creatively, build character and be exposed to a positive, encouraging and creative environment. Students receive a sense of empowerment when they go out into the community and demonstrate what they’ve learned to inspire others through their dance. Studies show that exposure to dance benefits the life of teenagers in many ways. To name a few: Dance is an all-around healthy activity; it is a great way to meet people with similar interests, it provides a way to get off the street, creates a positive outlook, and a great way to help teens develop better self-confidence. Activities like dance also help teens perform better at school.

Contributing to the life of another is a wonderful feeling. Join our mission; contribute to a young life today by supporting the Inspire Dance Scholarship. Help us lift spirits by planting a seed of hope and bringing out greatness hidden within. Your financial support enables us to provide free classes, thereby enabling the doors to remain open and maintain facility operations. Also facilitating growth by helping to cover expenses such as; rental space, teacher fees, student give-a-ways, marketing and studio tools & supplies.

Who am I?

My name is Maya, founder of Dunamis Creative Arts School, LLC. I trained in ballet and modern dance as a teenager and young adult. As a young adult I earned a BA in Marketing and Advertising. My hopes were to have a career working for one of the largest Advertising agencies in the world and maybe one day start my own agency. It turns out that God had another plan for my life.  The Lord called me back into dance several years later and planted a seed in my heart to show people His love from a creative platform bringing hope and healing to hearts with a positive message. The vision God has given me is a large one, and I cannot do it alone. I’m trusting in God that He will make a way. He knows the beginning and the end, all I can do is walk in faith in His will putting one foot in front of the other. I love what I’m doing, and your interest and support mean the world to me. Your donation is greatly appreciated!

God is a creative God. The gifts and talent He gives range far & wide and I encourage you to use what God has given you to bring His name glory. God has a great plan for your life and for each of the students that come to Dunamis CASM.  He has a plan to prosper and not harm, to give hope and a future.

The Dunamis CASM Vision

To produce men and women younger and older who express the love of God by developing and encouraging creativity. Training skillful artists in various art forms in excellence to touch hearts inspire and encourage the community in love.

Other ways to Help

You can help us get the word out by using the Indiegogo share tool to send this campaign to your mailing list, post on your Facebook, refer a friend or recommend our program to others.

story:
what is "city lights"?

“city lights” falls into a unique type of experimental theatre.  billed as a play with dance, the main goal of “city lights” is to marry the worlds of dance, theatre and independent music by featuring a cast of fresh faces, dance pieces from up and coming choreographers and music from independent musicians.  "city lights" will introduce a new, modern form of musical theatre, a recipe for something completely new and inspiring – we just need a little help to make it happen.

written as a response to films such as "black swan" and "center stage",  “city lights” captures the world of an unfunded, independent dance company and the people who populate it.  whether you have a connection to the dance world or not, these are people we've known, situations we've experienced, and broken hearts we have all felt.  these characters have big dreams and struggle as they fight to make their dreams come true.

some of the musicians featured in the piece include jeremy kushnier, apollo run, the yes team, cristofani, and erick shakne.

the writer izze gibson grew up loving musical theatre, having a great passion for music and the intensity of allowing movement to be an expression of emotion.  the idea of breaking into song during a musical is what inspired her to create that allusion of emoting through dance during a play.  the stage suddenly becomes an alternate reality when the actors use their bodies instead of their voices.  it has become most important to ms gibson to expose the intensity of the dance world in this piece.

red door theatre company is an independent theatre company founded in 2005 by kate erin gibson.  red door's mission statement is to produce socially relevant theatrical pieces and to offer a safe haven for controversial or delicate subject matter to be explored on stage;  to provide opportunities for performers, designers, directors, playwrights, composers, choreographers, stage managers and other artists, in all stages of their careers, to express themselves in a risk-free environment;  to provide educational opportunities for all ages, including internships in all fields related to theatrical production;  to create a network of artists who will blend into a supportive, creative community. www.thereddoortheatre.com 

what's in it for me?

theatre is expensive and it can be very hard to make a life as an artist.  any and all funds raised will:

  • help the production team secure space and the tools needed to put the show up (including but not limited to costumes, props, and printing costs)
  • allow the producers to pay the creative team (lighting designer, costume designer, stage manager, choreographer), actors, and musicians for their time and talents

the goal of this indiegogo campaign is to act as a supplement to the budget of the show,  and every dollar will be resourcefully spent in creating an incredible theatrical experience.

donors have the opportunity to give whatever they feel comfortable with.  the perks including everything from complimentary tickets to receiving a co-producer credit on the production.

there is no plan of profiting from this production.  the funds raised through indiegogo with off-set the anticipated ticket sales, allowing the theatre company to break even financially. 

our plan

what sets "city lights" apart from other projects is the desire to create a new genre of theatre.  

our plan is to put up an off-off broadway production and use as minimal a budget as possible to gain attention from potential investors from production companies, theatre companies, and independent financial backers interested in the show.  to find a time and place to have an extended run in manhattan is the ultimate goal – and provide a spring board for young dancers who are also brilliant actors to find their place in new york theatre.

we all have to start somewhere, and your contributions will open up more doors for this project to grow and explore the endless possibilities. 

spread the arts!

spread the word.  post this project to your facebook/twitter/tumblr/instagram and spread the word to as many fellow artists as possible.  

 

UPDATE:


thank you to all of those who have contributed so far.  we recently held auditions and are proud and excited to announce our cast.  check out this video to see what the day was like:

www.youtube.com/watch?vVYouN62dRw

and announcing our beautiful, talented, fantastic cast:


maddie - crimson roe
kristine - kristin morris
sarah - caitlin rigney
ryder - adam zivkovic
alison - holly kaye long
seth - j morgan white
daniel - john c nagy iii
tracie - ashley marinelli
ben - ben maters
female u/s - gabi dunkley
male u/s - joseph tudor

story:
Portland based dance company bobbevy and independent choreographer Kelly Anderson are seeking support to facilitate a tour this September of our most recent works, The Little Things and This is how we Disappear. We are the recipients of a DanceLab space grant awarded by the Danceworks Performance Company, which provides a discount on total theater rental costs.  This tour provides the unique opportunity to present our work to new audiences in Milwaukee, WI and build relationships with other Midwest artists. Your support will assist in eight artist fees and travel expenses.

About the Dances

 The Little Things is a work by independent choreographer Kelly Anderson, featuring guest NYC performers Cassandra Motta and Mary Madsen. This original piece is an exploration of the simple gestures of a lost relationship and the details we choose to forget. A dance of two women and two bed sheets. Each sheet representing her personal journey of what had created the absence of love. Simple, a woman and a sheet. Not so simple, the little things.

This is how we Disappear is an original new work created by Portland based dance company bobbevy. This new work juxtaposes the natural simplicity of time passing with our own experience of human relationships, fraught with frailty, tension and tenderness. Dancers Philippe Bronchtein and Jessica Hightower embody choreographer, Suniti Dernovsek’s unique movement vocabulary, marked by intricacy and expressiveness. This is how we Disappear features visual design by David Stein, sound, composed/generated by Jesse Mejia and real time video by Brian Richardson. Together, the collaborators create a live, interactive performance that blends movement, visual art, sound and video.

About the Artists

Kelly Anderson is an independent choreographer currently based in NYC. She has created evening-length works with Danceworks Performance Company, Vaudeville (2011) and The Bra Project (2009), collaborated with Milwaukee Opera Theatre to create an original opera, 26 (2010), choreographed Gal Friday Film’s Missed Connections (2011), Red Knife Lottery’s music video Junkie Jazz, created The Mondo Lucha Dancers for The Mondo Lucha Variety Show (2011), and has performed/co-produced seven Variety Show’s (2002-present). Her work has also been performed in The Minnesota Fringe Festival, on Your Mother Dances, and at The Puffin Room (NYC).

bobbevy is a Portland based dance company directed by choreographer/dancer Suniti Dernovsek and visual artist David Stein. In addition to 18 shorter works, they have produced five evening-length shows: Palace of Crystal (2011); ill-starred (2009); Lawn of the Limp (2008); Avian Fable (2007); and Marionette (2004). They have been presented by Conduit Dance, Reed College Arts Week, Velocity Dance Center, Northwest New Works at On the Boards, Ten Tiny Dances’ South Waterfront Project, and PICA’s Time Based Art Festival (2008 - 2010) and were recently awarded a second residency at Caldera Arts. For more information visit us at bobbevy.com  

We Need to Raise $5,600

In order to pay 8 artist fees and travel expenses from NYC and Portland, OR to Milwaukee, WI we need to raise $5,500.

Here's where your contribution will go:

5 airline tickets from Portland, OR to Milwaukee, WI  - $1750

3 airline tickets from NYC to Milwaukee, WI - $1,050

Artist Fees - $2,400

Documentation - $400

Total - $5,600

The Impact for bobbevy

Your donation will support bobbevy’s first tour of a group work and it comes at a time when the collaborating artists feel ready to expand into other communities.  This tour to Milwaukee, WI is an important step in the company’s evolution; as it has the potential to not only reach broader audiences, but also to enrich our creative process and collaborative artistic vision.

The Impact for Kelly Anderson

Kelly Anderson has played a significant role in the evolution of the Milwaukee contemporary dance community.  A recent choreographic retreat to New York City has allowed her to dive deeper into her aesthetic through the exposure of a thriving dance environment . Your support will allow her to share with Milwaukee an expanded vision of her work through these experiences.  The Little Things will also feature two UW-Milwaukee Peck School of The Arts alumni, Mary Madsen and Cassandra Motta. Their return will offer the opportunity to discover and enjoy the growth of these mature dance artists.  

The Show

Even if you are unable to donate through this campaign, the greatest support we could receive is to have you in the audience.  We hope you can make it.

This is how we Disappear and The Little Things

Friday-Sunday, September, 14th-16th, 2012 at 8pm

Danceworks Studio Theatre

1661 N Water Street  Milwaukee, WI 53202

 $15 general admission, $13 students/seniors

Tickets at - http://danceworksmke.org or (414) 277-8480

story:
Congratulations--we've successfully raised the funds for me to get to Kolkata for Muktadhara, the International Festival of Theatre of the Oppressed! Thank you for the tremendous support of this work!

We are continuing the campaign to raise funds for the Eastside Forum Project, our very local manifestation of this global Theatre of the Oppressed Movement! It is my dream to help build Living Stages into an organization that has deep roots in our local communities AND strong connections to a vibrant international movement of Theatre of the Oppressed artists. Attending Muktadhara in 2012 is a powerful step towards building the connections to make that dream possible.
 
Eastside Forum Project
 
When I return to Portland in January, I'll be using the skills and experience gained from my time in India to develp, train, and support a performance troupe made up of residents living, working, and accessing services along East 82nd. Eastside Forum will perform next summer in Farmers Markets and locations along the East Side, with a goal of generating dialogue and action about the challenges and possibilities of this commuity. The long-term goal is to create an ongoing theatre presence along Eastside neighborhoods as a process for community engagement and dialogue about the many issues our communities face! 
 
All additional funds raised will go towards outreach for the initial training, facilitation, and support of community performers during the play development and rehearsal process!

More about the Muktadhara campaign:

My name is Tamara Lynne, and I'm a theatre artist and activist based in Portland, Oregon. For me, theatre has always been a powerful tool for empowerment. I founded a theatre organization called Living Stages that is committed to the use of Theatre of the Oppressed for community dialogue, reflection, and action. Theatre of the Oppressed is a form of interactive theatre from Brazil that was developed by Augusto Boal, and is now practiced in over 200 countries around the world as a process of social and political transformation.

I have been invited to participate in Muktdhara, the International Festival of Theatre of the Oppressed in Kolkata India in December 2012. This festival is hosted by Jana Sanskriti, the largest Theatre of the Oppressed organization in the world. With 27 years of experience and over 30 theatre troupes across India, they perform interactive theatre for audiences of up to 7,000 people! I received a grant from the Regional Arts and Culture Council to help pay for airfare, an individual donation to cover the bulk of travel expenses, and now have raised the $650 needed to cover the registration fees for the festival. Now, I'm working to raise funds to continue my work with the Eastside Forum Project!

The work I've been able to do with Living Stages has been possible because of a supportive and enthusiastic community who see the value of Theatre of the Oppressed in building movements for social change. I ask your support once again to support this exciting opportunity, and help us make international connections to grow and sustain our work. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are not able to contribute financially, them please help get the word out by sharing this campaign with your friends!

Thank you for your support!

story:
ME AND MY BIG MOUTH – ONE WOMAN COMEDY SHOW

Written and Performed by Philippa Fordham

Me And My Big Mouth is a dynamic one-woman multi character comedy show packed with a variety of hopelessly deluded and outlandish characters.

This hour long show is energetic, sometimes dark and fast paced. Various characters mix with the audience, opening the door to some blatant fun and interaction.

With plenty of physical humour and a wealth of songs, the show goes straight for the comedy jugular and aims for big laughs. 

In October 2012 the show premiered at The Hen And Chickens Theatre, London for two nights and was a sell out. The next performance will be at The Leicester Square Theatre, London on 31st Janauary and 20th March 2013.

https://leicestersquaretheatre.ticketsolve.com/shows/873487236/events

 

ABOUT ME 

I am an actress, writer and comedian and can often be found showing off on a stage somewhere on the London comedy circuit. 

I co-wrote and performed in my own BBC Radio 4 comedy sketch show Fordham & Lipson and subsequently sketches from the show were selected for BBC’s Radio 4’s ‘Pick of the Week’ for two consecutive weeks.

Fordham & Lipson were also nominated for the Dubble Act Award at the Edinburgh Festival 2005. 

Currently I am co-writing a comedy series for television, which is in development with BBC Television. Prior to this I've had two other writing commissions with BBC TV.

Some of my acting work can be seen in the film Jonny English (Rowan Atkinson touched my bottom), BBC TV's Wild West (Dawn French tried on my ring), People Like Us (David Tenant liked my hair) and This is Dom Joly (Dom made me tea).

More detailed information about me seen at my website:

www.philippafordham.com

 

WHAT I NEED

I would like to perform my show at the Edinburgh Festival 2013 - Scotland, UK. The Festival runs for one month and is expensive. I need to raise £10,000 so that I can pay for venue hire, entry into the Fringe Brochure, PR, printing costs for leaflets and posters, insurance, accommodation and travel. All of these costs can easily amount to £10,000.

I have already secured a top venue to perform my show - TheAppearing at the Edinburgh Festival enables me to showcase my work and be seen by radio and television producers and casting directors. This exposure will potentially help me attain further employment in the comedy industry as a writer and actress as well as secure a producer to develop my show further for Radio and/or Television.

It is unlikely that I will make a profit at the Edinburgh Festival, mainly due to the high costs appearing there. With ticket prices at around £7 - £10 each and a venue capacity of approximately 50 seats, it is therefore nonviable to make a profit from ticket sales after all the costs. However breaking even at the Edinburgh Festival is a great achievement and if ticket sales go well, this is possible.

 

ABOUT THE EDINBURGH FESTIVAL

“Edinburgh Festival is to festivals what Wimbledon is to tennis.” - THE STAGE

Edinburgh is recognised as the home of the largest and most comprehensive Arts Festival in the world. The Fringe, which is in its own right the largest festival in the world, is what many, especially young people, think of as the Edinburgh Festival, being cheaper, more informal and a lot more fun! The Fringe began as a spontaneous addition to the first Edinburgh International Festival in 1947, a kind of polite protest by the more adventurous elements of the arts against what they saw as “The Establishment”.

Over sixty years on, the Fringe is now much more professionally organised and tends to revolve around venues who promote mini-festivals of comedy, cabaret, theatre, music, dance and visual arts. 

• The Edinburgh International Festival

• The Edinburgh Festival Fringe

• The Edinburgh Military Tattoo

• The Edinburgh International Book Festival

• The Edinburgh International Jazz Festival

Within this multitude of activities the two main platforms for the performing arts are the Edinburgh International Festival (EIF) and the Festival Fringe.

The official Festival presents a programme of events chosen by its Director. The Fringe, in contrast, is an open house. It thrives on the initiative and enthusiasm of those who continue to bring their shows from all over the world.

 

I have already secured a top venue to perform my show - The Gilded Balloon.

ABOUT THE GILDED BALLOON

“ One of the most creative venues on the Fringe” - THE GUARDIAN

“The in - place for the comedy crowd” - THE TIMES

“A venue with a touch of class” - THE EVENING NEWS

The Gilded Balloon has experienced a dramatic evolution from its modest origins of one theatre and 7 shows per day, 26 years ago, to operating 9 venues in 2011 with over 100 shows from across the globe, all encapsulating the very essence of the Fringe.

In early December 2002 the Cowgate venues of the Gilded Balloon were destroyed by fire. Since then the Gilded Balloon has operated out of Teviot Row House. The Gilded Balloon’s position as a premier venue is based on its intriguing, imaginative, adventurous and international programming covering exciting dance and physical theatre, new writing, challenging drama, children’s shows and the cream of stand up, improvisation and character comedy. The Gilded Balloon’s reputation continues to thrive, attracting worldwide television, radio and press coverage and selling over 130,000 tickets for its performances, continuing its dominance on the cutting edge of the Fringe. 

OFFICE ADDRESS: VENUE ADDRESS

GILDED BALLOON GILDED BALLOON

25 Greenside Place Teviot Row House

Edinburgh EH1 3AA 13 Bristo Square

Tel: 0131 622 6555 Edinburgh EH8 9AJ

Fax: 0131 622 6556 Box Office: 0131 6226552

admin@gildedballoon.co.uk admin@gildedballoon.co.uk

www.gildedballon.co.uk www.gildedballon.co.uk

STAFF:

Artistic Director : Karen Koren

General Manager: Sharon Burgess

Assistant General Manager: Rowan Campbell

Finance: Alex McDonald

A more detailed breakdown of the Gilded Balloon can be downloaded here:

http://www.gildedballoon.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2011/03/perfinfo1.pdf

 

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

I would LOVE a financial contribution! However, helping me get the word out is another great way to help me reach my goal. 

Below is a "ready to go" message and link which you can cut and paste into your own social media circles, or use the super handy Indiegogo share tools to spread the word:

http://www.indiegogo.com/projects/274369?key=d59d607a95f5717966a44f57075f176157f8bf60

story:
This campaign is completed! We have a campaign to film the Thomas Paine play for PBS. Click to learn more:

https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/to-begin-the-world-over-again-thomas-paine-for-pbs/x/2081821


Celebrating Two Radical Legacies...

Thomas Paine and Harry Bridges, two of the most misunderstood men in American history, are coming to Los Angeles.  These two men changed the course of nations with their vision, biting wit, stubbornness, wives, whiskey, and unswerving determination to make the world a better place. 

Ian Ruskin has performed his two one-man plays, "To Begin the World Over Again: the Life of Thomas Paine" & "From Wharf Rats to Lords of the Docks", over 250 times all over the world to much acclaim, but never in a theatrical run in his hometown of Los Angeles. It’s finally time to do that, and we ask you to help us put a roof over our heads. 

Paine sparked the American Revolution when a world was beginning to shed its old skin. No other Founding Father came close to Thomas Paine's vision of democracy. He helped shape our national character, inspires us to be guardians of that legacy, and based his beliefs on one simple idea, “justice for all.” This call for justice resounds in America today in the Occupy movement and in the words of Martin Luther King: “the moral arc of history is long, but it bends toward justice.” Ruskin was awarded a COLA Fellowship to create this play in 2011. 

Bridges was at the heart of the great struggle for worker’s rights and became the San Francisco labor leader who organized the self-proclaimed “wharf rats” of the West Coast piers. His successful effort to organize was fraught with drama; he was harassed, beaten and jailed, had three wives, two bitter divorces and his time of too much Jack Daniels. Today he is a hero for organized labor throughout the world. 

Both plays have been performed to standing ovations and rave reviews across America because they show the quirks, wicked sense of humor, vulnerabilities, and visions of these two men. It's time for a theatrical run in Los Angeles.

 

Praise for "To Begin the World Over Again: The Life of Thomas Paine" and  "From Wharf Rats to Lords of the Docks."

These plays have been acclaimed across America, and through the shear power of their stories, inspire audiences.  It’s time to bring them to the public in Los Angeles.

“It is a spectacular way to introduce people to the struggles and ideas of Thomas Paine.” -Elaine Bernard, Harvard Law School                                                                                                                

“For our college audience in particular (who are all in their own right struggling to realize their own value and contributions to this world), the lessons learned as a result of experiencing this brilliant performance are many.”  -Julie Davis, Cerritos College                                                                                            

“Our audience was simply riveted, and the enthusiastic standing ovation you received speaks volumes for the power and impact of your performance as Harry Bridges.” -Janet Walden, Center for Collaborative Solutions             

“Ian Ruskin paces the room brandishing a bottle of whiskey and reflecting on decades of labor struggle, breathing life back into the irreverent, irrepressible labor leader.”   -Eric Wolfe, IBEW Local 1245                                                                                                                

"He captures Harry Bridges brilliantly." -Howard Zinn, Historian and Playwright

Additional Collaborators:

Shanga Parker, director, both productions

Ed Asner, narration, “From Wharf Rats…”

Elliott Gould, narration, both productions

Sarah Nash Gates, costume design, “To Begin the World…”

Joe Romano, music, both productions

Addition music by Jackson Browne, Arlo Guthrie, and Sarah Lee Guthrie

Paine image: "Thomas Paine, after Cruikshank," 2012
Limited edition Screen print, by Jos Sances

story:
Who am I and what is Wu Tao?

My name is Anna Brooke and I am the first ever certified Wu Tao teacher in the US. My background is in both dance and healing and Wu Tao has been an incredible and truly special extension of both of my passions.

I am asking for your help to get Wu Tao founder Michelle Locke and her partner, Steve Richter (Wu Tao music composer) to New York City this coming July! Michelle is spearheading Wu Tao International after creating a strong presence in her native Australia and we need your help to pay their way to NYC to continue spreading the love and practice of Wu Tao! Airfare from Perth to New York City is around $3000 per person which is a massive expense. Although they are rich in spirit, that's a serious amount of money to spend without any guaranteed return. By donating to this campaign, you will be helping them reduce their overhead and assisting them in having an affordable and profitable trip to the Big Apple!

What We Need & What You Get

Believe it or not, every dollar of this campaign will support Michelle and Steve's transportation to NYC and any remainder will help them pay living expenses and food - that's really it! 

Our goal is $6000 which will cover the expense of their plane tickets (as long as the tickets stay under $3000 apiece!) Any additional funds will be applied to their expenses incurred while in NYC. Every dollar helps and all funds, no matter the final amount received, will go towards paying off their flights. 

What do you get for helping? A LOT! Scroll through our perks below to see how you can help them and support your own wellbeing in the meantime! From ebooks to cds and DVDs, all the way up to admission to the first level of Wu Tao teacher training, your contributions will be rewarded with tools to promote your own sense of wellbeing and practice of Wu Tao. 

The Impact

There has never been a more important time to restore our connection to life and embody our highest Selves. Dance is a potent healing force and a powerful way to bring ourselves back to truth, authenticity and love. It’s easy and very enjoyable to integrate Wu Tao’s simple yet powerful dance process into every part of your life! You can easily bring more flow, joy, energy and aliveness into your personal relationships, business, and community. By donating to this campaign, you will be helping us to help countless people, showing them how to cultivate peace and wellbeing within their lives, something that is sorely needed in NYC's hectic atmosphere.

Other Ways You Can Help

We completely understand if money is tight and a financial contribution isn't possible for you right now. This being said, your effort in helping us spread the word won't cost you a cent and will help us get toward our goal. Please visit Indiegogo's share tools to see how you can disseminate this info over your different social media sites or e-mail your friends about it. Do you know someone who is ready to make a peaceful and loving change in their life? Please let them know about all the ways that they too can help.

We completely understand if money is tight and a financial contribution isn't possible for you right now. This being said, your effort in helping us spread the word won't cost you a cent and will help us get toward our goal. Please visit Indiegogo's share tools to see how you can disseminate this info over your different social media sites or e-mail your friends about it. Do you know someone who is ready to make a peaceful and loving change in their life? Please let them know about all the ways that they too can help.

story:
Fuel Fitness and Dance is a studio located in Columbia, SC. Fuel is the first studio in Columbia to offer aerial silk classes. Along with aerials, Fuel offers a wide variety of classes including ballet, jazz, hip hop, yoga, zumba and much more. Starting at age 3 going up to adults, there is something for everyone. 

A few months ago Fuel opened a second location with high ceilings to expand the aerial program. The original location has 10ft ceilings and the new facility has 18-20ft ceilings. It was an old vacant warehouse that was fixed up and transformed to an aerial playground. Along with the new location Fuel was able to add two new apparatus, lyra and trapeze. 

The only thing left to do is purchase and install dance floors so this location can offer dance and fitness classes as well. Fuel is trying to raise $5000 for the dance floors. 

Fuels' way of saying THANK YOU for all donations is offering classes to those who live in or close to Columbia. For those who don't, they will receive awesome thank you videos from Fuels' students and sponsor recognition within our newsletters. Also, sponsors names will be written on stars that will be placed on our wall of fame for everyone to know who the awesome people were that helped us.

Fuel has been open for about a year and a half now and has already touched the lives of so many people. With two recitals already, many wonderful memories have been created and Fuel plans to create many more. There is no other studio in Columbia offering unique and cutting edge classes. It's a positive and creative outlet for children, teens and adults!

Every dollar counts and please help spread the word so Fuel can continue to make an impact in the dance art scene in Columbia.

story:
Thanks to everyone's generous donations we have succeeded in meeting our goal!

If you are at the festival please come join us as it is completely free!! We will be performing up in Edinburgh every night at 6:30pm from August 3rd - 14th at the Fiddler's Elbow. https://www.edfringe.com/whats-on/spoken-word/stand-up-tragedy

If you cannot be there in person, why not listen to our podcast which will showcase diffferent acts every day of the Fringe! http://www.standuptragedy.co.uk/

Thanks again! 

-----------------------------------------

A Cabaret with a Difference

Stand up Tragedy believe that Tragedy is worth celebrating.  Why just laugh, when you can laugh untill you cry and cry untill you laugh.  Music, comedy, fiction, spoken word, true stories encourage tears and mirth.  It's catharsis like no other. 

The Tearjerkers:

DAVE PICKERING, the tragic genius behind the show, is a writer, musician, presenter and podcaster. His drama series for Rethink Daily was nominated for Best Internet Programme Award at the Sony Radio Awards 2009. He was also nominated for Best Online Creator at the Radio Production Award 2012, and his popular podcast, Getting Better Acquainted, was featured on Radio 5 Live's Required Listening in August 2012.

Joining Dave in the cabaret are a team of dedicated tragedians who make then show possible. And of course amazing Acts of tragedy! Performers who have shared their tragedies have included: Ben Target, Liars' League, Helen Arney, Grace Petrie, MJ Hibbett, Richard Tyrone Jones, Jay Foreman, Bec Hill, Tania Hershman, Matthew Highton and many many more. 

Spreading the Sorrow

We participate in a tragedy; in comedy we only look

-Adolus Huxley

If you’ve ever been to Edinburgh, you’ll have seen people searching each street  corner for their next comic hit, only to come crashing down as soon as the laughter leaves their mouths. Out they prowl again, this time need more substance for the same high, caught up in a vicious circle of mirth. Stand up Tragedy offers an escape from the this tyranny of laughter. Refreshing and cleansing tears offer respite from this sad addiction, and a more permanant, soulful solution.

We’re honored to be a part of this year’s Fringe Fest and it’s a big deal for our troupe. The Free Fringe means just that: Free for performers to perform, free for audience members to enjoy.

That’s where the utopia ends. We’re paying for accommodations, we’re paying for transportation to and from the festival, we’re paying for promotional material.  For this we need your donation. 

Even if you cannot make it to the festival, by donating you become a part of the experience in Edinburgh. We’re offering as many perks as we can because we want you to feel you’ve been a part of this journey. We’re sending postcards, we’re making one-of-a-kind artwork in situ, we’re toasting to your health and sending you back a bottle.

Be part of the tragedy.

Stand Up Tragedy has a long history of endeavoring to pay its performers and artists and of giving back to the artistic community. As the Free Fringe is supporting us, we’re committed to giving back what we can. Any money we receive over our goal amount will go toward the festival and other fringe performers.  

Don’t Take Our Word For It:

"Laugh? I Nearly Died: The Rise of Stand-Up Tragedy" (Independent, July 2012) 

"Stand Up Tragedy" (thelondonword.com, January 2013)

But That’s Not All:

We’re going to be real with you: we’re thrilled you’re still reading. Not everyone can give and we understand that as well as anyone in our line of business. In this case please share with people through facebook, twitter, email, or through your mouthbox at bus stops on rainy day.   

 

Stand Up Tragedy. We do Catharsis.

story:
Bring Exene to NYC
as The Conspiracy Therapist

Hey All of You X Fans!  Conspiracy Theorists!  Men in Black and the Women Who Abduct Them!  Help us bring Exene to New York! 

November 22, 2013 marks the 50th anniversary of the assassination of President Kennedy.  Yes, we could mourn the man's passing, but instead, we choose to celebrate what was born that fateful day...the mother of all conspiracy theories!  Three Rooms Press proudly presents "JFK/NYC/OMG", Friday, November 22, at Cornelia Street Cafe. This event celebrates conspiracy theories of all shapes, sizes, and paranoia levels!  So far our lineup for this show is a knockout, but we would love to add one more reader to our event - The Conspiracy Therapist herself, Exene Cervenka. 

About Exene

Exene Cervenka, legendary poet, singer (X, Knitters, Original Sinners), songwriter, and artist, currently hosts a new web series on YouTube called The Conspiracy Therapist. For an artist who isn't afraid to lift the veil of the American Dream and poke around in its dark corners, whose work frequently delves into the mystical and the unseen, conspiracy theories are yet another fascinating facet of Americana, waiting to be explored, proven, or debunked.  

We're thrilled that she's 100% into joining our lineup and supporting this campaign, but the thousands of miles between her California abode and our NYC poetry grotto are really raining on our parade.  (Or it may not be rain.  It may be a chemical compound engineered by the government to act as growth hormones and turn us into a race of disease-resistant supersoldiers.)

What we need and what you get

To add Exene to our already-stunning roster, we need to cover her travel costs - because, hey, we at Three Rooms Press are firm believers in supporting our artists, be they East Coast or West!  The combined cost for Exene's stay comes to $1000. 

  • $5 -  A warm feeling of personal satisfaction and acknowledgement as a patron of the arts. 
  • $10 - A doubly warm feeling of personal satisfaction and acknowledgement as a patron of the arts. 
  • $25 - Your name will be printed in the program and you'll get a copy of the program sent to you signed by Exene!!! Plus that special feeling of giving to a project you totally believe in.
  • $50 - Your name will appear in the program, and you'll get a program signed by Exene.  PLUS a special reserved seat for the night of Friday, November 22 show JFK/NYC/OMG at Cornelia Street Cafe (does not include cost of ticket). PLUS that truly special feeling from giving to a project you totally believe in.
  • $100 or more - Your name will appear in the program,  you'll get a program signed by Exene,  PLUS a Free reserved ticket to Friday, November 22 show JFK/NYC/OMG at Cornelia Street Cafe. PLUS that truly special feeling from giving to a project you totally believe in.

Here's hoping you can help. Look forward to seeing you at the event!

Whoa, dude, I'm totally broke!

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about this effort to bring Exene to NYC.
  • Tell people about the "JFK / NYC / OMG" show on Friday, November 22 at Cornelia Street Cafe

story:
Hand Dance to Wasihngton, DC is like The Shag to the Carolinas, Stepping to Chicago and Lindy Hop to New York City.

Hand Dance is a contemporary swing style partner dance which is part of the social fabric of the Nation's Capitol.  This 50 year old dance tradition is the Official Dance of the District of Columbia by Resolution of the DC Council. Hand Dance is a direct descendant of the Lindy Hop, one of the most prolific social dance forms in the history of American dance. 

In an effort to educate hand dancers on the evolution of Swing Dance from Lindy to Hand Dance, The National Hand Dance Association is embarking on a program to bring original Lindy Hop legends of Harlem, New York's historic Savoy Ballroom - Norma Miller (94 year old Queen of Swing), George Sullivan, Sugar Sullivan, and Sonny Allen to the Nation's Capitol  All were staples original architechts of Lindy Hop and Swing during Lindy Hop's golden years from 1930-1970. They will be brought to Washington, DC and paired with legends of Hand Dance in discussions on the history of Lindy Hop and Hand Dance, the connections between the two traditional dances, and new directions of both dance forms.

The program entitled Hand Dance and Lindy Hop: The Evolution of a DC Tradition will take place September 27-28, 2013. Accompanying these oral history discussions are master class workshops in Lindy (taught by and Hand Dance, an afternoon of film screenings, a dance jam session with the Lindy Hop legends and hand dancers. 

The National Hand Dance Association is a 501(c)3 non profit organization whose mission is to Preserve, Educate and Promote the art form of Hand Dance.  This program will be free and open to the public for the two days of his important presentation.  It is important to bring together the elders of these two dance forms in order for the legacy of these cultures to be passed down to the next generation of Lindy Hop dancers and Hand Dancers. Interest in Lindy Hop is growing amongst a new generation of social dancers, and youth in the DC area are begining to make Hand Dance their dance of choice.

The funds raised in this fundraising effort will be used for travel, hotel accommodations, and honorarium for the legends of Lindy Hop.  Three will travel from Florida and the remaining will come from Harlem in New York City. Honorarium is critical for their time and effort in traveling to Washington, DC. The honorarium is a small token of appreciation for their impact on American popular culture and American vernacular dance.  Washington, DC's Arena Stage will provide the venue for the September 28th historic panel discussion, dance workshops, and dance presentations.  Other partners include in-kind services and promotion by "Gotta Swing" (a Lindy Hop organization located in the Washington, DC area) and the African American Music Association.

The most important reason for this fundraising effort is to bring Harlem's Lindy Hop legends Norma Miller, George Sullivan, Sugar Sullivan and Sonny Allen to Washington, DC for this historic public discussion on dance and music culture and "connect the dot" in tracing the roots of DC Hand Dance.

story:
Our Story

Sofia Truzzi and Sara Albertson are high school students in Seattle, Washington. They both participate in theater inside and outside of school, at Seattle Public Theater. They are producing Crooked, by Catherine Trieschmann in March, 2012.

This production will feature Sofia Truzzi, Sara Albertson and Mary Machala, is being directed by Julie Beckman and is being produced in Seattle Public Theater at the Bathhouse in Seattle, Washington. Performance Dates are:

Friday, March 9th; 7:00

Saturday, March 10th; 9:00

Sunday; March 11th; 2:00


The Play

â€œCrookedâ€ by Catherine Trieschmann is a play that centers around a teenage girl with dystonia, a disease that causes the muscles in her shoulders to draw up, creating a lump that looks like a hunch on her back. She is forced to work through this insecurity when she encounters problems with her single mother and questions about her sexuality towards a new friend. It is a dramatic comedy that explores the idea of finding out who one truly is, especially at a young age.


What We Need & What You Get

Funding this project helps pay for space and facilities rental, a set, costumes, advertisement and paying professional actors and directors.


Other Ways You Can Help

"Like" our project on Facebook, and help get the word out. Most of all, come to the show!

story:
49th Parallel Dance Company

About Us

49th Parallel Dance Company was founded in 2010 by Carolyn Schmidt and Ariana Champlin in New York City. These two young women, hailing from opposite sides of North America, joined forces with the mission to create a company that brings together talented artists from across North America. 

 We currently have three homes; Vancouver, BC, Calgary, AB and New York, NY, and are creating and performing new work in each of these cities whenever it is possible. We believe that contemporary dance in the 21st Century should not be limited to boarders or boundaries, and we are constantly working to extend those boarders. By working out of three cities, we have access to a plethora of new ideas and different inspirations depending on what location we are in, which keeps our artistic practice new, fresh and ever evolving. Through our work and activities, we strive to entertain and educate the public about dance and performance, making it accessible and enjoyable to all walks of life. As a company of emerging artists we feel responsible for the future of contemporary dance and we are committed to working tirelessly to ensure that this incredible art form lives on and reaches new heights.

Artistic Directors: 

Ariana Champlin
Cayley Hanrahan
Carolyn Schmidt

 

 

About The Project

 THE WATERING HOLE PROJECT

 June 18 - July 25th, 2012 - Calgary, AB, Canada

The goal of The Watering Hole Project is to raise the profile of contemporary dance amongst people who may be new to, or have never experienced the art form before. 

This is a multi-faceted dance project consisting of many events including:

- Creation of "Watering Hole" with 9 dancers, 3 choreographers and 2 bands

-  Flash Mob performances with live music at some of Calgarys hottest music venues and during The Calgary Stampede 

- Busking and dancing on the streets of Downtown Calgary during lunch hour

- An "Open House" at the historical John Snow House featuring dancing, live music, film, a silent auction and moderated discussions about contemporary dance and art. Friday July 20, 2012  3 - 10pm

- Full length performance of "Watering Hole" at Dancers Studio West in Calgary on July 25th at 8pm.  

** To find out all the details of our events, visit our website www.49thparalleldanceco.com **

 

ABOUT THE PIECE:

This day in age in North America, many young people and artists spend countless hours working in restaurants and bars in order to make ends meet. Using personal experiences, the choreographers are working together to create a full length dance piece that looks into the world of the local watering hole with a magnifying glass. The full dance work will be approximately 50 minutes in length and tells the story of a typical night at a popular local bar. Characters include the Bartender, Waitress, and various patrons. As the piece develops, the viewer receives close up views of all nine characters and discovers why they are at the bar on this given night. Using a language of pure contemporary dance, and set to live music by local bands The Bownesians  and Magik Spells, Watering Hole rises and falls and has moments of humor, frustration and passion.


WHY ARE WE DOING THIS?

Watering Hole is not your typical contemporary dance piece. The purpose of creating this show is not only to showcase the extraordinary talents of the dancers and musicians involved, but to build a deeper connection between dance and the community. Concert dance is often considered as "high art" and can be hard to relate to for many people. Our main goal through this project is to break the traditional boundaries of concert dance and to show our community that contemporary dance is a fun, entertaining and inspiring vehicle for expression and storytelling. By performing in public areas we aim to connect wtih as many people as we can, showing them that dance is an accessible art form that can be part of their lives. 

What We Need and How You Can Help...

Putting together a full length dance show takes an incredible amount of time, work, committment, and of course, money. We need to raise a few extra bucks to make sure this amazing project can blossom to its fullest potential. 

Here is a breakdown of the costs involved in this project: 

 

120 hours of rehearsal space = $2400

Compensation for 9 professional dancers = $4500

Pay for 3 choreographers/directors = $1500

Pay for bands to create new music = $1000

Costumes and props for the show = $1000

Theatre Rental = $500

Lighting and sound technician = $500

 

**We have been fortunate enough to recieve funding from Cultural Capital of Canada - Calgary 2012 for this project, however it only covers a PORTION of the costs. We are needing to raise an extra $3600 in order to cover all the expenses in this project. We are reaching out to our family, friends, audience, and art/music/dance lovers out there for some help in realizing our dreams. 

 

Making a donation is easy, and you can donate as little or as much as you wish. As a token of our apreciation every funder will recieve a little gift from us. 

 

Many many thanks for supporting our work during this exciting time for us, 

 

49th Parallel Dance Company 

 

www.49thparalleldanceco.com

 We currently have three homes; Vancouver, BC, Calgary, AB and New York, NY, and are creating and performing new work in each of these cities whenever it is possible. We believe that contemporary dance in the 21st Century should not be limited to boarders or boundaries, and we are constantly working to extend those boarders. By working out of three cities, we have access to a plethora of new ideas and different inspirations depending on what location we are in, which keeps our artistic practice new, fresh and ever evolving. Through our work and activities, we strive to entertain and educate the public about dance and performance, making it accessible and enjoyable to all walks of life. As a company of emerging artists we feel responsible for the future of contemporary dance and we are committed to working tirelessly to ensure that this incredible art form lives on and reaches new heights.
Artistic Directors: 
Ariana ChamplinCayley HanrahanCarolyn Schmidt
 
 

About The Project
 THE WATERING HOLE PROJECT 
 June 18 - July 25th, 2012 - Calgary, AB, Canada
The goal of The Watering Hole Project is to raise the profile of contemporary dance amongst people who may be new to, or have never experienced the art form before. 
This is a multi-faceted dance project consisting of many events including:
- Creation of "Watering Hole" with 9 dancers, 3 choreographers and 2 bands
-  Flash Mob performances with live music at some of Calgarys hottest music venues and during The Calgary Stampede 
- Busking and dancing on the streets of Downtown Calgary during lunch hour
- An "Open House" at the historical John Snow House featuring dancing, live music, film, a silent auction and moderated discussions about contemporary dance and art. Friday July 20, 2012  3 - 10pm
- Full length performance of "Watering Hole" at Dancers Studio West in Calgary on July 25th at 8pm.  
** To find out all the details of our events, visit our website www.49thparalleldanceco.com **
 
ABOUT THE PIECE:
This day in age in North America, many young people and artists spend countless hours working in restaurants and bars in order to make ends meet. Using personal experiences, the choreographers are working together to create a full length dance piece that looks into the world of the local watering hole with a magnifying glass. The full dance work will be approximately 50 minutes in length and tells the story of a typical night at a popular local bar. Characters include the Bartender, Waitress, and various patrons. As the piece develops, the viewer receives close up views of all nine characters and discovers why they are at the bar on this given night. Using a language of pure contemporary dance, and set to live music by local bands The Bownesians  and Magik Spells, Watering Hole rises and falls and has moments of humor, frustration and passion.

WHY ARE WE DOING THIS?

Watering Hole is not your typical contemporary dance piece. The purpose of creating this show is not only to showcase the extraordinary talents of the dancers and musicians involved, but to build a deeper connection between dance and the community. Concert dance is often considered as "high art" and can be hard to relate to for many people. Our main goal through this project is to break the traditional boundaries of concert dance and to show our community that contemporary dance is a fun, entertaining and inspiring vehicle for expression and storytelling. By performing in public areas we aim to connect wtih as many people as we can, showing them that dance is an accessible art form that can be part of their lives. 
What We Need and How You Can Help...


Putting together a full length dance show takes an incredible amount of time, work, committment, and of course, money. We need to raise a few extra bucks to make sure this amazing project can blossom to its fullest potential. 
Here is a breakdown of the costs involved in this project: 
 
120 hours of rehearsal space = $2400
Compensation for 9 professional dancers = $4500
Pay for 3 choreographers/directors = $1500
Pay for bands to create new music = $1000
Costumes and props for the show = $1000
Theatre Rental = $500
Lighting and sound technician = $500
 
**We have been fortunate enough to recieve funding from Cultural Capital of Canada - Calgary 2012 for this project, however it only covers a PORTION of the costs. We are needing to raise an extra $3600 in order to cover all the expenses in this project. We are reaching out to our family, friends, audience, and art/music/dance lovers out there for some help in realizing our dreams. 
 
Making a donation is easy, and you can donate as little or as much as you wish. As a token of our apreciation every funder will recieve a little gift from us. 
 
Many many thanks for supporting our work during this exciting time for us, 
 
49th Parallel Dance Company 
 
www.49thparalleldanceco.com

story:
Short Summary

As I mentioned before, I believe that a for profit concern can also be altruistic and community minded at the same time. We want to organize a for profit theatre. We want to prove that you can make a living, and not HAVE to make a killing. I think that a certain amount of profit can and SHOULD be earmarked for For outreach, and charity, as well as the opportunity to offer OTHER non profits funds to further their causes.

What We Need & What You Get

The money in the beginning goes to the purchase of equipment and Mobile light, Sound, Video, and photographic equipment. It also goes for the reasonable expenses incurred with the running of a theatre group. Marketing, advertising, Licensing of scripts, Rental of stage space, Set building and dressing costuming, hair and make up, and the payment of Area professionals to offer the community workshops and lectures to advance the Multimedia and theatre education for anyone interested.

50,000.00 is the figure that we have arrived at to pursue this, and fund it properly for 2 seasons.

All donations between five and fifty dollars will receive a chance in a drawing for two free tickets one show for the first two seasons.

All donations between fifty-one and one hundred dollars receive the above plus Name in the First Program of the first season.

All donations between 100.00 and 250.00 Receive level one and Name in all programs for one Season.

All donations between 250.01 and 500.00 Receive level one and Banner sized advertisement in all programs for one season, and ONE Commemorative T shirt.

All donations between 501.00 and 1000.00 Receive Level one and 1 season ticket for one season, and ONE commemorative T shirt.

All donations over 1250.00 Receive quarter page of adspace, and two season tickets for one season, and TWO Commemorative T shirts

If goal is not met, funds will be held until other funding efforts have helped us realize the goal, and all perks will be honored.

The Impact

We truly believe, that we can combine a for profit business, with the altruistic origin of a non profit. We will NOT be able to fundraise publicly, and we will NOT receive any tax exemptions. We WILL be able to plot the course of our own theatrical destiny and rely on ourselves and our community to help as realize our goals, and to turn our dreams into our reality.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

We FULLY realize that some of you who are reading this are not able to contribute to this project and we completely understand. If you could help us spread the word to as many others as possible we would be eternally grateful.

Please use the Indiegogo share tools wherever and whenever possible.

Thank you SO much for taking the time to read this.

 

Renaissance Entertainment and Media Services LLC

story:
Description of The Project

Creation of an Indian National Classical Ballet Company

Phase One: Production of a multicultural dance creation by the Gloria Mandelik Dance Company

After a first successful tour in 2011 (see videos and photos of this tour in the Gallery section), The Gloria Mandelik  Dance Company,  combining Classical Ballet with the dance idioms of Spanish and Indian dance, has been invited by the Indian Council for Cultural Relations to make a second tour of India. The I.C.C.R. is interested in Mandelik´s new choreography, based on a classic of Hindu mythology.

The new ballet is the love story of the celestial dancer Urvashi and the mortal king Pururavas. Their trials and tribulations are a sort of Indian combination of Swan Lake and Giselle, but with a happy ending. This story is based on the ancient texts of the Satapatha Brahmanas and Kalidasa’s 4th century play and will be choreographed in Classical Western Ballet style, also bringing in elements of Bharata Natyam and Spanish dance. Gloria´s work has always exemplified the importance and rewards of close collaboration and mutual influences between East and West.

Gloria´s Career

Embracing Classical Ballet, Spanish Dance and Indian Classical Dance, the unusual and eclectic nature of Gloria Mandelik’s career has been the subject of interesting controversies since its beginning. Born in the United States, raised in France, she is has lived in Spain since 1960 and has also had 45 years of intimate and profound relations with India. The depth of her knowledge of the dance language of these three cultures can be appreciated by observing the heights to which she has risen in her career. Highlights of that career include, in Classical Ballet soloist and assistant choreographer in the Teatro alla Scala de Milan; in Spanish Dance she was star of the company of the legendary Pilar Lopez; in Indian Dance, when she danced in the UNESCO in Paris, a critic said; “Mandelik has taken the initiative to study classical dance in India and mastered it to perfection, which proves that culture is universal and has no national boundaries."

See Gloria’s website:  http://gloriamandelik.com and her YouTube channel: http://www.youtube.com/channel/UCtSeR1vgwWEJ0ix9lM4RvRg/videos?flow=grid&view=0

What we need:

For Phase one of the project, we need to raise funds for the production costs of the new ballet, for dancers´ salaries and for travel from Spain to India.

The following is a budget breakdown of the Gloria Mandelik Dance Company's 2011 tour of India. The next tour's budget will be similar, subject to slight modifications depending on planning.

Artistic Direction/Choreography_______________ $6000

Salaries 9 Dancers (Europe)_________________$22000

Salaries 2 Dancers (India)____________________$2500

Stage Manager______________________________ $2000

Light Design_______________________________ $1500

Music Recording____________________________ $1000

Rehearsal studio____________________________ $1500

Costumes__________________________________ $4000

Plane fares Spain/India______________________$9000

Costume transport and insurance______________$2000

Executive Producer___________________________ $2500

Management, Coordination & Communication__ $2500

Total_______________________________________$56500

Additional costs in India, such as local transportation, housing, meals, etc. are paid for by the I.C.C.R.

All donations to this campaign will go to the Gloria Mandelik Dance Company, whether or not we reach our funding goal  for this project by the end of the campaign. Rest assured that your donation will  be used to complete this project at such time as we do reach our funding goal. Perks relating to the performance of the new ballet will be distributed when the project is completed.

Perks:

Contributors who donate any amount up to $100 will be mentioned as “Sponsor” in the program book handed out at the performances of the new ballet and will receive by email a copy of the program book autographed by Gloria and the dancers of the company.

Contributors who donate between $100 and $500 will be mentioned as “Special Sponsor” in the program book handed out at the performances of the new ballet, will receive by email a copy of the program book autographed by Gloria and the dancers of the company and will also receive by post a tote bag or T-shirt printed with the logo of the Gloria Mandelik Dance Company.

Contributors who donate over $500 will be mentioned in the program as “Special Sponsor Extraordinaire” and will receive by email  a copy of the program book autographed by Gloria and the dancers of the company and will receive by post a tote bag or T-shirt printed with the logo of the Gloria Mandelik Dance Company and a photograph of the company, autographed with a special thank you from Gloria.

All contributors to the campaign are welcome to attend any and all rehearsals of the new production.

Supporting this project is a chance to be involved in the creation of a new work of art which could very well be the cornerstone of a future project of even greater transcendence…

The Impact

Gloria´s long-term goal is the creation of an Indian National Classical Ballet Company, an idea in which certain Indian authorities have expressed interest. The first phase of the project will provide an opportunity to tour India with a multicultural dance creation which exemplifies the type of ballet that could form the repertoire of such a company,

India is the only major Asian power that does not have such an institution. As much as Gloria reveres the Classical Dances of India, which she has studied, performed and taught, she knows that they reach only a very limited public outside of India, due to the intricacies which only a connoisseur can appreciate. On the other hand, Classical Western Ballet, due to its more abstract form of expression, can narrate any theme to an international public. Classical Ballet choreographies based on the great Hindu epics would disseminate Indian culture on a global level and bring people closer to India’s great cultural heritage. An Indian National Classical Ballet Company would also provide an opportunity for ballet dancers of the Indian diaspora to return to their motherland and be a part of this exciting institution.

Other benefits resulting from the formation of a National Classical Ballet of India are the possibilities for the company to tour abroad, and for Indian musicians trained as Classical musicians abroad and in Zubin Mehta’s Mumbai School to compose original music for new ballets, thereby enhancing the collaborative nature of these two disciplines and creating further bonds between East and West.

Taking the implications of this project even further, the future would include the creation of a school associated with the Ballet Company to train dancers of future generations.

Ways You Can Help this Campaign

A contribution of any amount will be greatly appreciated!

Spread the word. Since crowd-funding depends on the interest and contributions of many people, you can also help our campaign by using the Indiegogo share tools (above), by posting a link to the campaign on  Facebook or other social media and by telling your family and friends about it. 

Make a comment by clicking on the "Comments" tab, above.

story:
Our Story

Hanging Georgia

 

an original play with music about the life and work of Georgia O'Keeffe

 

by Sharmon J. Hilfinger and Joan McMillen, directed by Jake Margolin

 

Where: The Thick House, San Francisco, CA

When: October 8 -- 30, 2011

Who: Co-Production of TheatreFIRST and BootStrap Theater Foundation

 

Hanging Georgia is an ensemble based collaborative production by two groundbreaking San Francisco Bay Area theatre companies, TheatreFIRST and BootStrap Theater Foundation. TheatreFIRST was started in 1993 as an actor collective and has grown to become one of the finest theatrical organizations in the Bay Area. We remain committed to accessible, intimate theatre at affordable prices.TheatreFIRST's history of Bay Area premieres includes Blue Remembered Hills, Via Dolorosa, The Great Celestial Cow, Fronteras Americanas, Making Noise Quietly, The Arab-Israeli Cookbook and Welcome Home, Jenny Sutter. Awards include Best Small Theatre by East Bay Express and the Bay Guardian's Goldie Award for Theatre. BootStrap was established to help local artists bootstrap their projects to visibility. BootStrap's world premieres include A History of Things That Never Happened, Imaginal Discs, Got Water?, A Beautiful Home for the Incurable, Veracruz, What The Birds Carry, Duece and Tell It Slant about the life and work of Emily Dickinson.

 

Hanging Georgia tells the story of a young O'Keeffe struggling to make her way as a single woman teaching in Texas, painting, falling in love, painting her feelings as she becomes one of the most famous American painters in history. Georgia's journey from Texas art teacher to New York Icon is full of passion and drama and her relationship with famous photographer and art dealer, Alfred Stieglitz, provides the back drop for an exciting new play about this extraordinary female pioneer.

 

TheatreFIRST and BootStrap Theater Foundation are both 501(c)3 non-profit arts organizations and your donations are tax deductible.

The Impact

We hope you will join us in bringing this exciting new work to bay area audiences. We are reaching out to all art colleges and art galleries so that people who have been affected by Georgia O'Keeffe's work can come and learn more about this important American painter. This production is an ensemble movement-based piece that requires a lot of resources because of the extended period of time necessary to develop the piece. Several workshops over the past year and several new drafts of the script have led up to the start of rehearsals which began on August 29th. We need additional support to help pay the actors, designers, and crew members during the run of the show. Both TheatreFIRST and BootStrap are smaller companies so any and all monies donated go directly to the artists producing the work.

 

What We Need & What You Get

We are still in need of approximately $12,000.00 to help cover designer, crew and actor fees. And whether or not we reach our goal of $5,000.00 your IndieGoGo donations will go directly to these wonderful people! Because of the current climate in American theatre and the limited resources, this type of collaborative work is extremely rare. You will be providing the means to keep this type of amazing work alive and thriving.

 

Benefits for you, our wonderful donors:

 

Pledge $15 or more and receive TheatreFIRST Website acknowledgment

 

Pledge $50 or more and receive a playbill autographed by the playwright and composer

 

Pledge $100 or more and receive the above benefits as well as 2 tickets to any performance

 

Pledge $250 or more and receive the above benefits plus a signed show poster by cast, composer and playwright

 

Pledge $500 or more and recieve the above benefits plus 6 complimentary tickets to any peformance

 

Pledge $1000 or more and receive the above benefits and a wine and cheese post-show reception immediately following the post-show discussion on any one of our sunday matinee performances

 

Pledge $2500 or more and receive the above benefits, a framed show poster signed by cast, playwright and composer, donor acknowledgment in the pre-show speech, donor acknowledgment placard in lobby of performance venue, one year acknowledgment as "donor extraordinaire" on TheatreFIRST website and 8 complimentary tickets to any of the performances (don't need to be used at same performance)

 


Other Ways You Can Help

Purchase a ticket at www.brownpapertickets.com and join us for an AMAZING night of theatre! Help us spread the word about this IndieGoGo campaign and tell your friends, family and co-workers to follow us on Facebook and Twitter. Your support is always greatly appreciated...and always remember TheatreFIRST's catchphrase: You will want to be a part of this!
