story:
The University of Louisiana is producing a play about you. About us. About the cultural history of all Cajuns. 

It's called The Rabble and it's by one of the most important and celebrated Acadian authors: Antonine Maillet. The Rabble tells a story of expelled Acadians that parallels the story of Cajun people in the American south. This is the story of our ancestors, told by the only University Des Acadiens.

We are looking for financial support to help create and possibly tour this important show during the Bicentennial of Acadiana. Producing this important work allows us to tell Louisiana audiences what it really means to be a Cajun.

Any amount you donate is tax deductable - just request a letter from us in the comments field and we will contact you via e-mail with an official letter of reciept. If your donation amount meets one of the donation categories, we will place your name in the program letting everyone know you support the preservation of Acadiana’s cultural past.

Please support us in telling the story of you, me and our history.
story_txt:
The University of Louisiana is producing a play about you. About us. About the cultural history of all Cajuns. 
It's called The Rabble and it's by one of the most important and celebrated Acadian authors: Antonine Maillet. The Rabble tells a story of expelled Acadians that parallels the story of Cajun people in the American south. This is the story of our ancestors, told by the only University Des Acadiens.
We are looking for financial support to help create and possibly tour this important show during the Bicentennial of Acadiana. Producing this important work allows us to tell Louisiana audiences what it really means to be a Cajun.
Any amount you donate is tax deductable - just request a letter from us in the comments field and we will contact you via e-mail with an official letter of reciept. If your donation amount meets one of the donation categories, we will place your name in the program letting everyone know you support the preservation of Acadiana’s cultural past.
Please support us in telling the story of you, me and our history.

story:
UPDATE
 
On behalf of Ashes Company, we want to thank all of you who so generously supported this fundraising effort and helped us reach our goal within just a few days! 
 
Please keep spreading the word about Tantalus as our production is only a few weeks away.
 
And thank you again for helping us bring ideas to life.
  
PROJECT

Tantalus is a site-specific installation inspired by the classical myth of King Tántalos. There are various versions of his punishment by the gods. The multivalence of his suffering invites personalized readings. Yet its universality touches upon burdens that we all share as human beings.

Tantalus is conceived for a solo performer. The project continues our company's investigation into theatre as an art form capable of incorporating many different kinds of art. The installation exists outside any specific time. We aim to confront this classical icon, as well as the western tradition of the corpus, or body, as a problem. Spectators enter a large, modern building and descend into its depths. They approach a source of light streaming through an opening in a wall. They peer inside ...

The installation is open for 2 hours at a time. Spectators are ushered into the space, free to remain as long as they wish.

CAMPAIGN

Our goal is to raise $1,000 in 11 days.

All donations go directly towards building materials for the installation's scenic design.

You have the option to donate any amount. The amounts listed at right are the minimum for the listed perks.

Tantalus will have free admission, so this campaign is the project's primary economic resource.

Your generous contribution will bring this unique project to life and support a new company taking its first steps. In return, you will receive humble perks and our sincere gratitude for assisting in the realization of our artistic vision.

*Please note: You can contribute to the campaign via PayPal even if you do not have a PayPal account. Simply use your credit card to "Pay as a Guest" without signing in. For more information, click here.

VISION

Ashes Company explores aesthetic forms and languages that supplant literary dramaturgy. While focused on theatrical performance, the group's work extends to many different kinds of art. Ashes suggest an understanding of art as an interstitial phenomenon: the abstract crossing into visibility, rendering an irresolvable presence.

Tantalus is the second project in a series of works by Ashes Company confronting the foundations of western culture. The first production, Oresteia, performed in 2011. A video excerpt and images are available in the gallery.

SHARE

Consider using the Indiegogo share tools, located directly below the production artwork above, to spread the word about this campaign and project through your social network.

Thank you for taking the time to donate towards and/or share this campaign

PRODUCTION

Concept & Design: Jonathan Vandenberg
Dramaturge & Associate Designer: Erik Grathwohl
Performer: Adam Roper
Lighting Design: Joe Novak
Producer: Regina Vorria

Friday, June 15th, 7-9pm
Saturday, June 16th, 2-4pm
Sunday, June 17th, 2-4pm

Free admission
Convene at Teacher's College main entrance
525 West 120th Street, New York City

Contact us with any questions or comments at: info@ashescompany.org

story:
Our Story

Help support young theater artists by contributing to the second production of new theater company The Dirty Blondes. Members include Alexandra Siladi (director), Elizabeth Sarkady (stage manager), Ashley Jacobson (playwright), John Wilder (lighting designer) and Taryn Vander Hoop (choreographer). 

We hope you will contribute your love, compassion, and hard earned money to our latest original production, penned by Ashley Jacobson, to premiere as a part of the Planet Connections Theater Festivity in June. Your donation will go towards rehearsal space, costumes, printing costs, props, set pieces, and everything else needed to produce a show in NYC.

 

The Dirty Blondes present THE AMERICAN PLAY

Starring Shane Jensen, Jimmy Dailey, Rachel Napoleon, Brooke Bergen, Susan Bartolme, Cecilia Lynn-Jacobs, & Tyler McClain

Sound design by Max Letaconnoux

The American Play follows two college students, Tim and Luis, who bond over the author Bret Easton Ellis in American Lit class.  As the boys try to define themselves as men, their fantasies of a Patrick Bateman-like existence expose deep-seated insecurities and desperations that they will do anything to hide. The two-man play incorporates an all-female chorus to create a heightened, surreal, modern environment. 

The piece is concurrent with the 20th anniversary of the release of American Psycho. It's a reactionary tale about the society we live in today, where women are made to feel like potential victims, a modern culture where the "war on women" is still being waged both privately and publicly.  

Created by women and told from a male perspective, The American Play asks what makes a man a monster.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word about our campaign (and our show) -- and buy your tickets to a performance. We'd really love to see you there! 

http://planetconnections.org/the-american-play/

www.thedirtyblondes.org

 

PRESS

Check out our most recent press, TAP was highlighted in TheaterMania & Broadway World: 

http://offoffbroadway.broadwayworld.com/article/The-Dirty-Blondes-Present-the-World-Premiere-of-THE-AMERICAN-PLAY-64-623-20120515

http://broadwayworld.com/article/Hinton-Battle-to-Headline-4th-Annual-Planet-Connections-Theatre-Festivity-20120418

http://www.theatermania.com/off-off-broadway/news/04-2012/planet-connections-theatre-festivity-announces-lin_55032.html

story:
Our Story 

Enlightened Theater was founded by Artistic Director, Ashlee Katrice Thomas. She has been passionately involved in the Arts, Education, and creating conceptual work that gets into the soul of our humanity. Enlightened Theater is an avenue that allows artists to share their work with the world and serve the community. 

We are committed to creating art that enlightens the world by addressing issues that are significant to world evolution; inspiring people to question the prevailing wisdom and reflect on the impact they have on society.

The Women's Collective is a Summer project that brings together national and international artistic women who are using theater and dance as a tool for social awareness on issues that impacts our community and humanity. The Women's Collective is the culminating event of the "Enlightened Theater Summer Series". Presenting organizations will be hosting workshops throughout the summer that are open to the community.  This is an interactive show where the audience has an opportunity to participate in Creating-- one of the best gifts we have has human beings.

The Women's Collective Takes place August 20th and 21st in Downtown, Los Angeles


Contribution Perks are listed but Please feel free to Donate whatever you can. Every dollar counts!!! 

The Impact

Your donation goes further than you can imagine. It is a seed. A seed that will grow roots that impacts the world-- generation after generation. 


You are Empowering Artist: 

Your contribution to this project will provide new and reputable artist the opportunity to share their gifts. You will allow these artist to sustain themselves as they share their talent and serve the community. These artist will host free community workshops that that focus on self exploration, confidence and physical health, specifically for women.  Your contribution will expose a diverse community  to new ideas, art forms, and entertaining empowerment. 


You are transforming a child's life:

A portion of the proceeds from The Women's Collective will be used to fund for Enlightened Theater Youth Company. This program is designed for Middle & High School Students as an avenue to express themselves through theater. This program is scheduled to begin 2012. 

 

You are supporting Services for Disabled Youth:

The Sade foundation was created so that high function-disabled Youth would have access to resources that will give them freedom to live an amazing lifestyle. This umbrella foundation was inspired by my sister Sade who, despite the lack of financial resources, fights to become independent. This philanthropic goal is to provide financial resources to programs and families thats focus is creating awareness and independence in the disabled community.


Without your Seed..NONE of this is possible. 


What We Need & What You Get

Our goal is raise Pre-production cost for the event. Your contribution will go towards:

Rental space

Marketing/Advertising

Community Workshop materials, rental, artist stipend

Administrative Cost (stage manager stipend)

Supplies (Audio visual, Video/Photography)

Insurance

Lighting/Rigging


Covering pre-production cost  allows the proceeds from ticket sales to go directly to programs listed above. 

If we do not meet our campaign goal-- The Project will Still Happen!We will use the raised monies for pre-production and find creative ways to make up the difference.




Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't make a fiscal donation, Word-of-Mouth is just as valuable! By sharing this, you're giving your friends & family an opportunity to really stand for the Arts and empowering communities. You can share this via Facebook, youtube, twitter, email blast. Everything helps!

We also need Volunteers for the event and community workshops! If you're interested email us at: enlightenedtheater@gmail.com

story:
DANCE NEW AMSTERDAM’S SPRING MATCH

THE MATCH

To kick things off right, we’ve had two generous contributors commit to matching every dollar you donate with a dollar of their own up to $25,000.  That's right: your tax-deductible $10, $25, $50, or $100 donation will become $20, $50, $100, or $200!

WHO WE ARE

DNA is a vital support system for dance, touching over 65,000 individuals yearly in our studios, theater, galleries and through outreach. We advance and extend the life and career longevity of dance artists through high-quality dance education/training, opportunities for choreographic exploration, innovative performances, and artist development – from Studio to Stage and Beyond.  

DNA is a vibrant part of the Lower Manhattan community, open 360 days a week from 8:00am – 11:00pm. We offer more than 140 classes a week to children, adults, and professional dancers in contemporary, modern, ballet, hip-hop, Flamenco, yoga, Pilates, and more. DNA’s presenting programs produce over 60 performances a year, from student productions to commissioned world premieres, supporting over 450 artists yearly. Additionally, in our studios we subsidize over 700 dance companies and 12,000 training artists.  

DNA PRESENTS & programming has supported the full spectrum of artists, including Charles Atlas, Alexandra Beller/Dances, Brian Brooks, Nora Chipaumire, David Dorfman Dance, Douglas Dunn, Catherine Galasso, Ishmael Houston-Jones, Jaamil Olawale Kosoko, Urban Bush Women, and Kota Yamazaki.

Each year we sponsor international students, provide opportunities for budding choreographers and performers, support new and experimental work through residencies, and certify teachers in the Simonson Method of Teacher Training.  DNA also creates unique programs that fulfill the needs of the entire dancer—from Business of Making Arts Workshops, to new entrepreneurial initiatives.

 

WHAT WE NEED & WHAT YOU GET

We need your help to take advantage of this amazing dollar-for-dollar match. DNA is a non-profit organization, and we count on our community to help support and maintain our theatre, classes, faculty, artists, staff, and space.  In addition to the perks for donating, you’ll be joining an ever-growing community all-around awesome people. 

 

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN GET INVOLVED

SPREAD THE NEWS

Repost! Share this campaign with your friends on Facebook or Twitter, and forward it to your friends! Encourage them to support the Arts!

VOTE FOR US

It's free and easy! We ahave been selected as one of the 14 Seim-finalists for ARTSFWD. The five projects with the most votes advance to be finalists! http://artsfwd.org/challenge-voting/

VOLUNTEER

DNA is entrepreneurial, adaptive and dynamic; cross-sector and cross-discipline pollination is what makes for great art and a great organization – your skills are welcome and needed. You can make a difference by being present! Contact development at development@dnadance.org

story:
That Toy Pony

Remember that Tamagotchi you worked so hard to keep alive and poop-free? Saving up to buy that limited edition Princess Di Beanie Baby? Hot Wheels?

Just like those long lost toys, theatre demands obsession. So come obsess with us, and remember what it feels like to be completely devoted to an experience, if only for a moment.

 

That Toy Pony is comprised of four members: Ashley Monroe, Blake Bishton, Greg Redlawsk, and Natalie Kropf

 

2nd Nature

2nd Nature is a play written by Blake Bishton, directed by Greg Redlawsk, and developed by That Toy Pony. The play itself takes place in a small four bedroom apartment in Crown Heights in the midst of an otherworldly hurricane that has been battering the city for weeks. The occupants of the apartment are forced to overcome blackouts, Twinkie shortages, a girl (ew!), and a sexy, sentient laptop determined to take over the world, all the while strugging most with what it means to be alive and human in a world that has become so reliant upon technology.

 

2nd Nature will be performing the second and third weekends in April. The perfomances will be taking place in a small Crown Heights apartment, with an audience capped at 15-20 members.

 

Impact

This is That Toy Pony's first fully mounted production, and we need your help to get the ball rolling! The money we raise will be going directly to the play's production costs, and with your help we truly believe we'll be able to create something incredibly special and incredibly relevant. We thank you so much for your support, and we can't wait to share this piece with the public.



*When donating, please leave a private comment with information regarding which performance you would like to attend along with your email address in order to recieve directions to the performance space!*

 

PERFORMANCE DATES:

April 11-14, 18-20

TICKETS: http://2ndnature.brownpapertickets.com/

story:
Who We Are and What We Are Doing
Please help Hub Theatre Company of Boston, Inc., launch its debut season's production of Lebensraum by award-winning Massachusetts-based playwright and screenwriter Israel Horovitz.
In this fascinating “what-if” story, the German government extends an unprecedented gesture of good will to the Jewish people, resulting in unintended political, social, economic and personal consequences on both sides. This complex and creative drama requires us to contemplate our moral code, forces us to confront complicated ethical dilemmas, and inspires us to forgive but never forget. 
 
Why Should You Give
Hub Theatre Company of Boston, Inc., is a non-profit organization committed to entertaining and emotionally engaging theatre in intimate settings. In order to cultivate a diverse audience spanning all ages and backgrounds, all tickets are Pay-What-You-Can! Your donation helps us in our mission to lower the economic barriers between art and audience.  Also all your donations are TAX DEDUCTIBLE!!!
 
Where Does The Money Go
Every penny donated goes into making this production the best it can be!  Our Indiegogo goal is to raise $1,000, but the actual cost of putting on this show is over $12,000!    
Your donation with help us:
-Rent the necessary lighting and sound equipment
-Build fantasic masks, puppets, and props
-Costume our actors
-Pay for our performance space
-Pay our actors and designers
-Cover insurance costs
  And Much More
 
Who Is Involved In This Production
We have assembled a top-notch cast and crew that includes the talents of John Geoffrion, Jaime Carrillo, Lauren Elias, Kevin Paquette, Erica Magelky, Tyler Brewer, Ian Thal, Mike Wonson,
 Cara Chiaramonte, Jason Weber, Paul Ezzy, Matt Martino, Lurie Armandt and Matthew Murphy!
 
How Can Else I Help
-Spread the word. Word-of-mouth is our best (and most cost-effective) marketing tool! Tell your friends who we are, what we do, and why we do it. Talk about us through whatever means you have at your disposal, be it social media (Facebook, Twitter, etc), internet (blogs, email, etc), phone, pen/paper, shouting from rooftops, morse code, mime, whatever.
-Donate your spare office equipment and supplies. Have enough poster paper to cover the continental US-let us take some off your hands for you!  Never going to use that gift card to Kinkos-no worries we sure will!
-Volunteer your time- let us know your interests and we will be glad to have your assistance!

We have assembled a top-notch cast and crew that includes the talents of John Geoffrion, Jaime Carrillo, Lauren Elias, Kevin Paquette, Erica Magelky, Tyler Brewer, Ian Thal, Mike Wonson,

 Cara Chiaramonte, Jason Weber, Paul Ezzy, Matt Martino, Lurie Armandt and Matthew Murphy!
 
How Can Else I Help

-Spread the word. Word-of-mouth is our best (and most cost-effective) marketing tool! Tell your friends who we are, what we do, and why we do it. Talk about us through whatever means you have at your disposal, be it social media (Facebook, Twitter, etc), internet (blogs, email, etc), phone, pen/paper, shouting from rooftops, morse code, mime, whatever.
-Donate your spare office equipment and supplies. Have enough poster paper to cover the continental US-let us take some off your hands for you!  Never going to use that gift card to Kinkos-no worries we sure will!
-Volunteer your time- let us know your interests and we will be glad to have your assistance!

story:
The Brothers Kassel

The Brothers Kassel is a new play by Lisa Dellagiarino and Kara Poe. Opening in the Fall of 2012, we need your help to make it happen!

The Brothers Kassel takes place in the fairy tale kingdom of Arthenon, where two brothers, Bartholomaus and Trentonshire, have received a royal decree. The beautiful Princess Josephina Phillipa Marie has been kindnapped, poisoned, and all seems lost. To receive wealth and love, but mainly wealth, Bart and Trent go on a seven day quest to rescue the princess before time is up. Along the way they meet monsters such as The Tree of Unsolicited Advice, The Evil Wizard Greg, and the monster version of a Turducken. Will they rescue the Princess in time? Probably.

 

What we need--7,500!

  • More than half (5,000) will go to space for a six week run, including promotional materials and insurance.

  • The rest covers the designers(for a beautiful kingdom!), rehearsal space, fight choreographers (for excellent, awesome and safe swordplay!), and as much as possible to compensate everyone for all of their hard work!

  • And if we go overgoal we will for sure have puppets. Think about it.

 

What You Get

  • Our forever appreciation and love!
  • One of the killer perks you see to the right of your screen.
  • Handsome boys fighting monsters

story:
Watch the video above to learn more about the project!

Click on the UPDATES tab above to check out extra goodies from the cast and crew: pictures, videos, cast bios, director's notes, playwright info, music, and art will all be posted here over the course of the campaign!

PUNKPLAY

by Gregory S. Moss, directed by Fly Steffens

produced by The World's Stage Theatre Company in Milwaukee, Wisconsin

Sept 6th-8th in the basement of Cream City Collectives in Riverwest (click HERE for tickets to the CCC show, and check out the promo video HERE)

September 13th-15th at Bucketworks in Walker's Point (click HERE for tickets to the Bucketworks show, and check out this other promo video HERE)

Closing Night afterparty with food, a raffle, and live Milwaukee punk bands after the show on September 15th!

Featuring: Liz Leighton, Emily Rindt, Tim Palecek, and Chen Chen

A history of America in the 1980s, an idiosyncratic genealogy of punk rock music, and a personal narrative of growing up as an outsider, punkplay is a mix tape tribute to the excesses and energy of adolescence. Mickey, a thirteen-year-old suburban mist, is befriended by an angry runaway named Duck. Together, they boys attempt to reinvent themselves using punk rock, but as reality threatens to crash in on them, their fabricated world of amped-up music and shocking band names becomes just as oppressive as the society they're desperate to reject.

Our rehearsals start in August, and we are utilizing our event 

BUDGET to be funded by this fundraising campaign:

  • Space - $350 (Split between The CCC and Bucketworks) Supporting our production also supports these event spaces, as they will use the money we pay them to continue their artistic and activist missions!
  • Printing Costs - $150 (Programs, Advertising, Supplemental and Rehearsal materials) We want to get people as excited about the project as we are by being able to create posters and other advertising materials, having programs where we can thank all of our generous donors. We also want to make the program a great take-away item for the audience by putting in some punk rock art and history!
  • Props/Costumes - $250 - Duck and Mickey might scoff at the idea of Punk Rock being a fashion statement, but we want to make sure our actors look good. A leather jacket, a prom dress, hair dye, and ROLLERSKATES are just a few of the items we need (bought used from thrift stores). There is an extensive prop list that includes massive amounts of records, tape cassettes, and comic books - as well as a model of a space shuttle, several puppets, and a rubber Ronald Reagan mask...

We're really excited to feature these up-and-coming actors in this production, housed in intimate and non-traditional theatre spaces, with a new play and original music!

Learn more about The World's Stage Theatre Company by visiting http://www.facebook.com/worldsstagetheatre

 To find out more about Cream City Collectives, please visit: http://creamcitycollectives.wordpress.com/

To find out more about Bucketworks, please visit: http://bucketworks.org/

story:
Alyson Laury Dance originated in Pittsburgh, PA in 2011. The company recently relocated and is now based out of New York City. The work of the company focuses on the athleticism and fluidity of dancers, requiring a strong technical foundation and modern base. The company is comprised of dancers that have graduated from universities throughout the country with B.F.A and B.A degrees in dance and/or the performing arts. The artistic director and company members work cohesively together to create movement that is engaging both artistically and intellectually.Our mission is to always connect with the audience and create an invigorating experience for both the performers and the audience.

Alyson Laury Dance is seeking funding for our 2013 season. The funds raised will go towards making our upcoming performances a success. Your donations will help us afford studio space for rehearsals, costumes, dancer fees, travel expenses, technician fees, and more.

The company strives to provide young emerging artists opportunities to perform and be seen in the dance community. Please help us continue this process and grow as a company. Your contribution will help us enrich young artists and the dance community with our passion and creativity. Any contribution helps! $5, $15, $20, even $1! Every cent is appreciated! Thank you!

story:
Our Story

The Black Theatre Ensemble (BTE) was founded to promote and enhance the development of theatre that portrays the black and African-American experience. We do this by hosting two major productions throughout the school year. 

This fall, our production is: Funnyhouse of a Negro by Adrienne Kennedy! Funnyhouse is a deeply psychological play that delves into the psyche of the mixed raced protagonist, Sarah, as she battles issues with her identity and race.

The curtain rises on our production Friday, December 7, 2012 at 8pm and Saturday, December 8, 2012 at 3pm and 8pm at the Glicker-Milstein Theatre at Barnard College. Tickets are available at: http://www.cuarts.com/calendar/view/type/4/event_id/15086. 

After each performance, there will be a talk-back with the cast to discuss the process of performing in their various roles. We want to bridge the gap between art and discourse and we want you all to be a part of it! 

Who's Involved

Cast

Negro-Sarah ............................................. Morgan Owens

Duchess of Hapsburg ................................ Kai Johnson

Queen Victoria Regina ............................... Sabaah Jordan  

Jesus ...................................................... Lamar Richardson

Patrice Lumumba ...................................... Randolph Carr 

Sarah’s Landlady/Funnyhouse Lady ............. Jasmine Sudarkasa

Raymond/Funnyhouse Man ........................ Sophie Jelke   

The Mother ............................................... Sophie Jelke

The Father ................................................ Igor Kuwonu

Jazz Singer ............................................... Shelby Sykes 

 

Production

Director .................................................... Rebecca Clark

Producer .................................................. Nissy Aya

Assistant Director ...................................... Rae Binstock

Stage Manager ......................................... Bintu Conteh

Costume Designer .................................... Amanda Perry 

House Manager ........................................ Keith Williams

Assistant House Manager/Crew .................. Momoh Osilama

 

What We Need & What You Get

With your help, we hope to make this production bigger and better than any production we have ever done! Our team of talented actors and creative team are putting together an astonishing production of this play complete with period costumes, live music and unbelievable talent! 

Your donations will be used for everything from technical costs to costume pieces, making you an integral and much appreciated part of this production. Our goal is set at $500 but we can truly use all the help we can get!

To thank you for your help, we have some perks available for you to choose from! Check out the right hand side of this page for all the perks. Feel free to donate multiple times to get multiple perks, or donate more than the minimum for whichever perk you like.

Other Ways You Can Help

There are many other ways you can help. Hit the share button or pass on the link to family and friends or just talk about us! Every little bit counts and helps and we are grateful for anything and everything we receive. 

You can also support by coming to see the production on Dec 7th and 8th! Tickets are available now through the Ticket and Information Center in Lerner Hall, Columbia University and online at: http://www.cuarts.com/calendar/view/type/4/event_id/15086.

story:
Thank You for Checking Out Our Indiegogo Campaign!

Hi we are Oh Dragon Theatre from Austin, Texas. We provide audiences with shows that highlight amazing performances and compelling stories.

Our next project is Sam Sheppard’s award winning play, True West. For our production we will be producing our show in The Magic Barn Fantastic, an amazing venue in the up and coming East Austin neighborhood.

We can only make this happen with the help of supporters like you. As a volunteer theatre company our visions come to fruition with the help of contributors who truly believe in the value of live theatre.

What We Need & What You Get!

We need to raise $3,400 to make our production a reality. We're creating a set using a large amount of props. Due to the nature of the show, we will have to have extra props to replace ones that will be broken nightly. We also have to have cabinetry built for our kitchen set and provide our own lighting and seating which can prove to be costly additions.

The ensemble of True West will be working tirelessly to build set pieces, scavenge for props and costumes, and promote this amazing show. Below is list of all necessary costs for our production.

Venue - $900.00

Royalties- $900.00

Chairs- $360.00

Props and costumes- $360.00

Lighting- $330.00

Set - $250.00

Programs & Advertisement- $100.00

Rehearsal space- $200.00

                                       Total goal = $3,400

Any amount you can contribute is a huge help. We also have some pretty sweet gifts if you donate to our campaign at certain levels. From a fond place in our hearts to the full VIP package, there is something for everyone! Check out all the great perks we have to offer!

Even if we don’t reach our goal, your contribution will go straight to production costs and help us make this production the best it can be.

The Impact

Oh Dragon Theatre Company was founded in Summer 2012 by six individuals looking to start an Austin based theatre company that was truly actor-centric. Our commitment to spotlighting and developing exceptional performances are what makes us unique.

 We are dedicated to creating theatre that fully engages the audience and leaves you thinking long after you leave the theatre.

This is a place where amazing acting and amazing minds come together to create exceptional works of art. Our passion is introducing Austin theatre to a rich, full, emotional season of plays that shines a light on the actor's craft and journey.

We love pushing the boundaries of what we can present to our patrons, but we need your help to do it!

Other Ways You Can Support!

We know things are tough right now for everyone, not just small volunteer theatre companies. But you can still help us if giving money doesn’t work for you right now.

Spread the word out about our campaign and this amazing show we are putting on! Shout it from the rooftops, share it on your facebook page, or tweet it to your friends with the hashtag #TrueWestAustin! You can help us just by letting people know about our company and what we are trying to do.

story:
What is Tallgrass Gothic?

Tallgrass Gothic is a haunting play about love, lust, and imminent reckoning in rural America.  Its gut-wrenching story was penned by Melanie Marnich and was first staged at the Actors Theater of Louisville.  

Why Another Off-off-Broadway play? 

Its heightened text and physical specificity make this play more than just your average play about unhappy rural Americans.  It has the emotional height of Eugene O'Neill with the irreverence of David Mamet. It's sincere, jarring, and deeply personal.

Who is Grey Room?

Grey Room is a new theater company interested in making immediate, engaging, and raw theater. We want to invite the audience in to make a space with us – that’s the grey room. In April we want to put in our grey room the play Tallgrass Gothic, by Melanie Marnich. It’s a romantic thriller of a bible-belt ghost story and we think you’ll like it.

Since graduating from our conservatory program at NYU together, we have been putting on a number of small projects, most of which we've built from the ground up. However, this is a unique moment for us because this is the FIRST FULL PLAY we are putting on with funds, space, and rights acquired entirely by ourselves.

What's this money business about?

We're broke! We spent our last pennies putting down a deposit on a beautiful theater space in the theater district of Manhattan and buying the rights to the play.  To make this happen, we really need a sweep of generosity to flow our way!  We need costumes, equipment, rehearsal space, a backseat of a car and so much more to make this production happen!  We're seeking help in any way.  Whether you want to come paint the set with us, or support our company as one of our honorary "designers" listed below, any and all is welcome support!  So far, the production team has been working round the clock to get pre-production secured.  We are fully dedicated to seeing this production come to fruition in the most conscientious, collaborative, and yes, frugal way possible.  Our goal, with the help of our visionary director Jake Beck, our judicious stage manager Matt Davis, and our proficient Producer Laura Barbiea, is to be as transparent and prudent as possible in this process.  See our "perks" below to get a real-budget comparison for how your money will be spent.

What's in this for you?

You're supporting the arts!  What a rapturously beautiful thing! Also, if you give above the $50 level, you will get a ticket (or two!) to see the New York premiere of this heart-pounding play!

 

What happens if we don't meet our goal?

The show must go on!  We have the rights for the play, so we could end up wearing plastic bags and performing under the Queensboro Bridge. But we hope it won't come to that!

story:
About the GL&M Dolls: 


GL&M Productions which is the premier company for your visual entertainment, would like to introduce you to our newly founded GL&M Dolls. The GL&M Dolls is a team of professional performers with a wide range of performance abilities. They are glamorous, talented and will add that extra special touch to any event.

Our professional team ranges from dancers, fire performers, hoopers, aerialist, stilt walkers, mimes, Hula Hoop performers, live tables and promo models. Any performance our team brings, will add magic to your event.

Our dolls are based out of Michigan and you can catch our dolls at many events and festivals across the United States. Each performer has various experience and have shared the stage with some of the largest acts known both nationally and internationally, particularly in the Electronic Dance Music community. Whether you need just one performer or an entire group, our team will come dressed to impress in their custom designed creations. They will keep your crowd engaged and excited from the beginning of the event until closing time.

GL&M provides dolls for large events, festivals, corporate events, promotional modeling and even smaller private events.

 

Why A GL&M Dolls Calendar? 

More Like Why Not?!?  GL&M loves their fans and we wouldn't be anywhere without their support.  We thought this would be a fun & great way to raise money, so that we can provide you with an amazing 2013 Calendar to start off your New Years Right!! 

 

Can't Donate... It's ok :)

If you can't afford to donate, don't worry the dolls still love you for all your support.  One thing you can do though to help, is promote this Calendar for us.  To your friends, Co-Workers & Family.  

A little bit of promoting, Can help in a really big way.  

 

What will the funds be used for? 

Getting photos, editing, designing calendar format and printing all calendars. If we reach our goal, we will also donate 5% to the local humane society. 

 

THANK YOU SO MUCH FOR THE SUPPORT!!

 

LOVE,

 

YOUR FAVORITE DOLLS

Our dolls are based out of Michigan and you can catch our dolls at many events and festivals across the United States. Each performer has various experience and have shared the stage with some of the largest acts known both nationally and internationally, particularly in the Electronic Dance Music community. Whether you need just one performer or an entire group, our team will come dressed to impress in their custom designed creations. They will keep your crowd engaged and excited from the beginning of the event until closing time.
GL&M provides dolls for large events, festivals, corporate events, promotional modeling and even smaller private events.
 
Why A GL&M Dolls Calendar? 
More Like Why Not?!?  GL&M loves their fans and we wouldn't be anywhere without their support.  We thought this would be a fun & great way to raise money, so that we can provide you with an amazing 2013 Calendar to start off your New Years Right!! 
 
Can't Donate... It's ok :)
If you can't afford to donate, don't worry the dolls still love you for all your support.  One thing you can do though to help, is promote this Calendar for us.  To your friends, Co-Workers & Family.  
A little bit of promoting, Can help in a really big way.  
 
What will the funds be used for? 
Getting photos, editing, designing calendar format and printing all calendars. If we reach our goal, we will also donate 5% to the local humane society. 
 
THANK YOU SO MUCH FOR THE SUPPORT!!
 
LOVE,
 
YOUR FAVORITE DOLLS

story:
I-DANCE  (Inspiring Dance: American Nations' Choreographic Exchange)

Campaign to Connect American Choreographers and Latin American Dancers

Dancers, choreographers and teachers in Latin America are working incredibly hard against the odds that keep them isolated- and they are hungry for more contact with the global dance community. They are also in need of exposure to the trends and developments that have occurred during many years of isolation. Like a band of travelers that has survived many hardships, they lack the resources that will bring them back to a more robust health and vitality, namely interaction with artists and companies that are vibrant examples of the art form in the 21st Century. But they also have incredible stories and a unique spirit to share with their North American counterparts.

I-DANCE brings choreographers, teachers and performers from the USA to Latin American countries in order to promote an "inspiration exchange". Started in 2007, with a visit to Managua (Nicaragua) by internationally recognized dance teacher Kevin Irving, I-DANCE brings artists of stature to dance communities in Latin America with the goal of bridging the gaps that currently exist. We like to think of this as a "Johnny Appleseed"-type approach - sowing the seeds of creativity to foster growth throughout the Latin American region.

The creative impulse behind artistic expression through dance is remarkably similar the world over - but the crucial ingredient for the creation of meaningful and innovative dance often only arises from direct contact with artists that push dancers to explore beyond the boundaries of known experience.  In I-DANCE projects everyone gains from the increased contact as knowledge, experience and inspiration are shared through formal classes and performances, as well as the personal bonds that are quickly formed between dancers regardless of nationality, background or training.

 

Our Track Record

The 2010 project, which brought American performer and choreographer Lindsay Gilmore to Managua was a huge success, thanks to many generous donations. Lindsay not only created 2 short works while there, she also performed in the International Contemporary Dance Festival.  In 2011, renowned choreographer Nicolo Fonte, from Brooklyn, NY, created "Codiciosos" for Compani­a Nacional de Danza de El Salvador during a 1 week residency in El Salvador; that work has now been performed by CND on tour throughout Latin America and the Caribbean. I-DANCE also funded another return to Managua in 2011: Jennifer Chin, teaching the technique of Jose Limon, taught workshops in Managua, Granada and Diriamba and also performed in the International Contemporary Dance Festival.

Founder/Director Kevin Irving has been recognized by the American Embassy in Nicaragua for his contributions to the Nicaraguan cultural sector.

 

We Need Your Help!

I-DANCE is urgently seeking help in funding new projects to send Rachel Tess to Costa Rica in August and Christopher Roman to Peru in February 2013.

story:
PRESENTING

BY SAM SHEPARD

 

Directed by Kristen Tomanocy

 

 

 

WITH THE POETIC TALENTS OF

James Warren

TJ Natole

Zach Hilton

Mary Anne Rojas

Tom Bair

 

 

 

WHAT WE’RE DOING

 

THE PLAY

One of Sam Shepard’s most popular and critically acclaimed plays, Fool for Love is the story of one of theatre’s most infamous couples. Eddie and May have been rambunctious lovers for fifteen years; they are time-worn wheels on a rodeo trailer in the wilting American West. They cannot survive with each other or without each other. No simple love story, the play is also an investigation into the inheritance of family dysfunction. Shepard’s own family life was a source of sadness and a pain that has colored his entire playwriting career.  Fool for Love, which he wrote in sixteen drafts, (only adding a father figure in the final draft) bites the questions about what family is to the quick and leaves them bleeding on a rickety kitchen table, even after company comes over.

 

The play takes place in a grubby motel room, where May has been trying to stay on the wagon and get her life together when suddenly Eddie bursts through the door with tequila, a shotgun, a lasso, and spurs on his boots. He wants May back. Again. An Old Man watches from his chair beside the stage as May and Eddie come together. And pull apart. And make each other sick. And love each other harder than any two people have ever loved each other before. We would love to have you there for the ride.

 

THE POETRY

The play is not the only part of the show. Working together with local New York City poets and writers, we are planning a unique experience that combines both theatre and performance poetry. We have asked several poets to write pieces surrounding themes inherent in Fool for Love, giving it new, fresh voices. The poets will open up the evening with performances of poems that take place within the very motel room Eddie and May later tell their own story in. The result is an expansion of the dimensions and facets of the play and its characters; New Yorkers get to see their own city, their own people in Shepard’s world of the American West.

 

THIS IS WHERE WE NEED YOU

Your donation will help pay for our rental of the Zoo Theater at Triskelion Arts in Brooklyn, New York, sets, costumes, props, programs, flyers, scripts, the rights to the show, copies and other production expenses.

 

Your support goes to making great theatre with this hard working gang possible! May and Eddie’s story couldn’t possibly fit into someone’s living room.

 

Reserve tickets for our play at poeticfoolforlove@gmail.com. Tickets are suggested donation only.

 

WHAT IF I CAN'T CONTRIBUTE?

 

Come see the show! Click HERE for tickets!

Get the word out to your friends and family!

 

THE PEOPLE INVOLVED ARE:

Kristen Tomanocy - Director

Steve Hart - Assistant Director

Elyse Marcus - Stage Manager

Meaghan Cross - Producer

Robert Stevenson - Set Designer

John Lavigne - Sound Designer

 

Photo Credit to Jonathan Weiskopf

story:
DNAWORKS needs your support in raising funds 

to underwrite the cost of a Touring Stage Manager for 

HaMapah/The Map 

as part of the 20th Anniversary of DAH Theatre, 

Belgrade, Serbia, June 13-16, 2011

 and the Spoleto Fringe, Umbria, Italy, in July.

 

The goal? To raise $4500 to pay for the travel, accommodation, per diem, and fee for the show's professional Touring Stage Manager and related costs in order to present the highest quality of performance.

 

DAH Theatre is one of Europe’s most active political theatres and was instrumental in the overthrow of the dictator Slobodan Milosevic with its political actions. “Passing the Flame” celebrates the world of theatre artists making a difference in the world through their art and activism. The Spoleto Fringe, in its third year, coincides with the Spoleto Festival of Two Worlds in the historic town in Umbria.

HaMapah/The Map has been invited to Dah’s “Passing the Flame” conference on theatre and peacebuilding because of the strife remaining in Serbia due to the war that fractured families and former Yugoslav society. There is much healing to be done in this region, especially for those citizens who embody multiple cultures. Similarly, the Spoleto Fringe has invited DNAWORKS because of the unique nature of the performance and current issues surrounding identity, heritage, and immigration in Western Europe.


HaMapah/The Map is a multimedia, genealogical dance journey, conceived of and performed by former Alvin Ailey American Dance Theatre dancer Adam McKinney, that traces his African American, Native American, and Jewish heritages. The performance is followed by a community dialogue that offers the audience an opportunity to share with each other their personal stories and reflect on the themes of the piece – identity, heritage, and ancestry.


About DNAWORKS: 

DNAWORKS is a multi-disciplinary organization dedicated to dialogue and healing through the arts. DNAWORKS generates creative projects opportunities for self expression with communities around the world.


About our Fiscal Sponsor: 

DNAWORKS is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the purposes of DNAWORKS must be made payable to Fractured Atlas and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

story:
Blacklight Burlesque Summer Tour 2013

The Ultraviolets Burlesque troupe is a black-light theater troupe that is very excited to share our unique, innovative, and sexy vaudevillian variety show with audiences outside of our little island home in Maui!

Each act that we present to our audience is an original work of art created by the performers themselves. So much time and creativity goes into the conceptualization, the music selection, choreography, costuming, & prop-making that make each act unique and entertaining. It's truly inspiring to work so closely with a group of amazing, self-reliant women who are constantly producing new material that showcases the variety of talents that we have within the troupe. 

Through parody, song, comedy, dance, aerial performance, and magical visual illusions which are emphasized by the beauty of black lights, the Ultraviolets redefine human sexuality and creative expression in a extraordinary comedic and surrealistic way not seen before in burlesque.  Each act has a storyline to support the burlesque elements as well as handcrafted props and puppets that enhance the audience's entertainment.

"Silly is the new sexy," director Rachel Deboer says, "we pride ourselves on empowering people through visually stunning props and costume media along with the live sensual themes and human relationship scenerios we make fun of and examine."

Not only do we entertain through burlesque and dance; we also incorporate magical illusions using the negative space of a black background and black light to make characters and props appear and dissappear.

We will be kicking off our tour in Vancouver, Canada and traveling all down the west coast through Seattle, Portland, and the Bay Area.  Our goal of $6500 after all campaign fees will cover the initial plane flights needed (around $3600) to get our 6 versatile and spunky black light beauties to the mainland as we call it here in Maui. Also your donation is going towards purchase of a tour van ($2400) to transport our mistresses of the black light in between cities. Lastly, your kind donation to our kick off tour will help to bring mass levity and social healing through this completely visually vanguard and liberating expression for the modern day woman and man.

About the Ultraviolets:

We are a cast of 6 women who share a unique theater vision concerning love, sex, relationships, and life.  Each member is a passionate artist in her field of  dance, improvisationsal comedy, aerial performance, song, and visual costume and prop design. 

For more information on individual performers, visit our website:ultravioletsburlesque.com

Enlightening the World One Flash at a Time:

We have created a "Diary of an Ultraviolet" blog that is featured on our website.  Each member has their own private and transformational stories to tell. As we travel and connect with audiences we will update our "Diaries" on our website to reach out to blossoming performers and humans alike in their search for creative self expression.  The Ultraviolets have taken Maui by storm by their style of burlesque and have been featured on the cover of Maui Time, Maui's largest independent publication as well as performed all over the island for thousands of people.

We feel we have a theatrical message and visual presence that is so original and needed in today's world. "Sensuality can be funny and female clowns, dancers, and singers bringing that message to the masses is powerful and transformative", says Rachel Deboer.

Please support our efforts to bring this journey to life and receive some of our UV perks!! You can pledge any amount and choose your perk. Check back to see the updated list of Perks and pictures in our gallery tab above as the campaign progresses. Look for new cast photos and shout-outs to funders, too!

Please contact us at: quenchthewench@gmail.com
We will get back to you!

Other ways to help:

Spread the word and make some noise, please tell everyone you know about The Ultraviolets!

Like us: Ultraviolets on Facebook and Blog, Twitter and promote The Ultraviolets any way you can think of... Everything helps!

Thank You!!!

Rachel Deboer & The Ultraviolets

story:
Magic Futurebox is raising money for the NYC premiere of Tommy Smith's Demon Dreams, with sound design and beat production by the one and only Paul D. Miller AKA DJ Spooky, presented as a fundraiser for Japan at the Gene Frankel Theatre this July. 

Demon Dreams

July 6th - 17th
Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Fridays at 7:00 pm
Saturdays at 12:00 pm, 3:00 pm, and 7:00 pm
Sundays at 3:00 pm

About the Project:  

About a year ago, Magic Futurebox teamed up with award winning playwright Tommy Smith to produce three of his works. For July, we decided on Demon Dreams, Tommy’s hip-hop story theater play based on traditional Japanese Noh folklore.  In a broken-down temple after the end of the world, 3 demons and 3 immortals debate the merits of the human race by telling stories and spitting rhymes.

 

Then, in March, more than 400 miles of Japan were devastated by a massive earthquake and resulting tsunami.  Suddenly, a story set in a near-future Japan where cataclysmic disaster has destroyed the human race took on a very different tone. Magic Futurebox decided to go forward with the show, but to donate the proceeds of the box office to the Japanese prefectures most affected by the disaster. 

 

The Impact:     


If we can hit our goal with this campaign and sell out this show, we stand to donate $15,000 to relief and rebuilding efforts.  

What We Need & What You Get: 

We need $7,000.00 to pay for the performance space-- the cast and crew are working for free, Tommy donated the rights to the play, the generous DJ Spooky donated 5 original compositions to the show, and we've had fantastic patrons donate their old clothes for us to make costumes, so all we need is the rent! 

 

With your (tax-deductible!) donation above $15, you’ll not only help us get this show up, you’ll even get a ticket to come and see it! You’ll like it.  It’s fast, funny and stylish, with great music and the cast is as charming and good looking a bunch of actors as you’d ever want to see on stage. We’ve also got limited edition collectors’ cards by comic artist Chris Booth, an aftershow party with the cast and crew, a workshop so you can learn all about making story theatre yourself, and a whole lot more!


NOTE ABOUT THE WORKSHOP: The Story Theater Workshop (available at $100 level and up) will have 2 times: Friday, July 8th and Friday, July 15th. Both workshops are 11:00 am - 4:00 pm.

story:
Who We Are...

kerPlunk dance is a contemporary dance company based in Queens, NY.  Constructed of five dynamic dames, we have Plunked our way from state to state along the East Coast in the past year.  Don't let the age of our company fool you.  Founded by Artistic Director Katherine Richardson in January 2010, we have spun out an impressive first year of performances and workshops, including Jacob's Pillow Inside/ Out stage and our own self produced show at New York City Center Studios. 

In 2010 kerPlunk dance met Andrew Sorg of the Atlantic Brass Quintet after performing at the Charles River Dance Festival in Boston.  Little did we know that our by-chance meeting would turn into an exciting artistic endeavor involving five kerPlunk dancers and the five musicians of Atlantic Brass Quintet.  The dancers of kerPlunk have already been working over the past several months creating phrases, developing subtext, and experimenting with how we can incorporate the presence of the musicians on stage. 

The Company:

Katherine Richardson- Artistic Director
Sarah Wiechman - Rehearsal Director
Meghan MacAlpine
Jenny Gillan
Michelle DuVall 

What We're Doing...


As an artistic collective we look to influences within time and space, unveiling our own personal histories by exploring the anamorphic range of the female body.  In our newly formed artistic partnership with the Atlantic Brass Quintet, kerPlunk dance will be working with ABQ to bridge the gap between historic and contemporary contexts buried within the structure of classical music.  The end result, a fresh program with an old-world feel that is inventive, intriguing, and celebratory of the evolution of performance art.  

The program itself will pay homage to the Baroque composer Pergolesi, with the presentation of Igor Stravinsky’s ballet Pulcinella Suite. The kerPlunk and Atlantic Brass collaboration will also feature the music and dance of the Balkan nations, a great brass music tradition of fascinating, dazzlingly virtuosic, and passionate music bound in Christian, Jewish, and Muslim traditions.  This spirited music will be equally matched by the dancers mapping of a contoured world, brought to life through invigorating partnering, cascading ensemble work, and intimate stillness.   

Over the next year we will be developing the characters and or subtext of various small scenes that will be explored in the work.  We will begin by defining the space and the people who inhabit it through our interpretations of the music.  The coloring of the music lends itself well to the creation of defining various characters within each piece.  The dancers will deconstruct the melodies and embellishments that have become a characteristic of the various musical traditions in the program, and explore the foundation of each composition. 
  
As various sections of the program solidify we will be work-shopping/performing excerpts throughout the Summer and Fall of 2011 as well as traveling to and from Boston to work with the Atlantic Brass Quintet as we begin to integrate them into the staging of the work.  The finished program will culminate into an evening of live music and dance.  With proper funding we are looking to the beginning of 2012 as the starting point for performing this work at various venues.

How you can Help!



Box office sales only cover so much of our expenses of producing a show, let alone rehearsal rentals, dancer pay and travel.  Even though we are actively pursing a hand full of grants for this season, government funding of the arts as well as independents (fellowships, grants, etc) have been cut dramatically over the past few years.  Your generosity has and will continue to be our main source of income as a grassroots endeavor.    


We are looking to raise a portion of our budget, $2,000, to cover the initial expenses of creating this body of work. Rehearsal space, insurance, dancer stipend, and travel for out of city rehearsals with the Atlantic Brass Quintet are just a taste of our preliminary expenses.  No donation is too small!     


If you would rather make a tax-deductible contribution, please visit our fiscal sponsor, The Field*, at https://www.thefield.org/Profile.aspx?SAID=2229.


Thank you for your unending support!

-kerPlunk dance


*Katherine Richardson / kerPlunk Dance is a Sponsored Artist with The Field, a not-for-profit, tax-exempt, 501(c)(3) organization serving the New York City performing arts community. Contributions to The Field and earmarked for Katherine Richardson / kerPlunk Dance are tax-deductible to the extent allowed by law. For more information about The Field contact: The Field, 161 Sixth Avenue, 14th Floor, New York, NY 10013, (212) 691-6969, fax: (212) 255-2053, www.thefield.org. A copy of The Field's latest annual report may be obtained, upon request, from The Field or from the Office of the Attorney General, Charities Bureau, 120 Broadway, New York, NY 10271.
story_txt:
Who We Are...
kerPlunk dance is a contemporary dance company based in Queens, NY.  Constructed of five dynamic dames, we have Plunked our way from state to state along the East Coast in the past year.  Don't let the age of our company fool you.  Founded by Artistic Director Katherine Richardson in January 2010, we have spun out an impressive first year of performances and workshops, including Jacob's Pillow Inside/ Out stage and our own self produced show at New York City Center Studios.  In 2010 kerPlunk dance met Andrew Sorg of the Atlantic Brass Quintet after performing at the Charles River Dance Festival in Boston.  Little did we know that our by-chance meeting would turn into an exciting artistic endeavor involving five kerPlunk dancers and the five musicians of Atlantic Brass Quintet.  The dancers of kerPlunk have already been working over the past several months creating phrases, developing subtext, and experimenting with how we can incorporate the presence of the musicians on stage.  The Company:Katherine Richardson- Artistic DirectorSarah Wiechman - Rehearsal DirectorMeghan MacAlpineJenny GillanMichelle DuVall  

What We're Doing...

As an artistic collective we look to influences within time and space, 
unveiling our own personal histories by exploring the anamorphic range 
of the female body.  In our newly formed artistic partnership with the 
Atlantic Brass Quintet, kerPlunk dance will be working with ABQ to 
bridge the gap between historic and contemporary contexts buried within 
the structure of classical music.  The end result, a fresh program with an old-world feel that is inventive, intriguing, and celebratory of the evolution of performance art.   The program itself will pay homage to 
the Baroque composer Pergolesi, with the presentation of Igor 
Stravinsky’s ballet Pulcinella Suite. The kerPlunk and Atlantic Brass 
collaboration will also feature the music and dance of the Balkan nations, a 
great brass music tradition of fascinating, dazzlingly virtuosic, and 
passionate music bound in Christian, Jewish, and Muslim traditions.  
This spirited music will be equally matched by the dancers mapping of a 
contoured world, brought to life through invigorating partnering, 
cascading ensemble work, and intimate stillness.    Over the next year we will be developing the characters and or subtext of various small scenes that will be explored in the work.  We will begin by defining the space and the people who inhabit it through our interpretations of the music.  The coloring of the music lends itself well to the creation of defining various characters within each piece.  The dancers will deconstruct the melodies and embellishments that have become a characteristic of the various musical traditions in the program, and explore the foundation of each composition.     As various sections of the program solidify we will be work-shopping/performing excerpts throughout the Summer and Fall of 2011 as well as traveling to and from Boston to work with the Atlantic Brass Quintet as we begin to integrate them into the staging of the work.  The finished program will culminate into an evening of live music and dance.  With proper funding we are looking to the beginning of 2012 as the starting point for performing this work at various venues.

How you can Help!
Box office sales only cover so much of our expenses of producing a show, let alone rehearsal rentals, dancer pay and travel.  Even though we are actively pursing a hand full of grants for this season, government funding of the arts as well as independents (fellowships, grants, etc) have been cut dramatically over the past few years.  Your generosity has and will continue to be our main source of income as a grassroots endeavor.     

We are looking to raise a portion of our budget, $2,000, to cover the initial expenses of creating this body of work. Rehearsal space, insurance, dancer stipend, and travel for out of city rehearsals with the Atlantic Brass Quintet are just a taste of our preliminary expenses.  No donation is too small!      

If you would rather make a tax-deductible contribution, please visit our fiscal sponsor, The Field*, at https://www.thefield.org/Profile.aspx?SAID=2229.

Thank you for your unending support!

story:
Our Vision!

      "...Equal parts provocative and hilarious, sobering and loving, this show tells our story of endless war through clowning." Katherine Malachuk MBA, author of You're Accepted

      This project is inspired by interviews conducted with military veterans from USA, Israel and Canadian armies. It also includes the director's own experiences as an EMT in the Israeli military. In opposition to movies and popular media that portray the dramatic, violent or extreme moments of soldier’s lives, this project portrays the behind the scenes stories about the less known or "heroic" side of the military; moments that are mundane, tender and absurdly hilarious.

      The military structure demands many people to 'quiet down' or give up large parts of their personality whether it be their creativity, emotional expression, freedom of choice, and in many other ways. Clowning, on the other hand, is the exact opposite of military training. The clown fully experiences each moment and expresses their unique point of view to the audience. This project's goal is blend these two opposing worlds and show the hilarious possibilities that can arise.

      Racheli Mendelson, the play's director and writer is a native Israeli who has spent the last 4 years in Boulder, Colorado studying Performance and Peace studies at Naropa University. Her creation, Shoot, Cry & Forget About It! is an attempt to reveal and celebrate soldiers' full humanity. It is dedicated to an audience of veterans, soldiers in active duty and civilians. By donating to this project your generosity will greatly help us promote a creative conversation about militarism and war. Our ensemble wants to end war and we think it’s possible through creative and expressive acts such as this performance. We believe that clowning and performance is one way to cultivate a strong connection to our aliveness, our humanity and to each other. Through this connection we can slowly but surely give up the old habit called war.

 **This project is not designed to dishonor or criticize soldiers or veterans. It does however aspire to critique the military structure and the effects it has on the people who are in it (i.e. soldiers and other military personnel).

 

Community Events:

      The cast of Shoot, Cry& Forget About It! in collaboration with Boulder Veterans for Peace and Colorado's Iraq Veterans Against The War will hold a community conversation during the Fringe Festival in Boulder Colorado this upcoming Fall. The goal of the conversation is to create a space where audience members can meet with veterans, share stories, and encourage community members to take part in these organizations that are working for peace. We believe that through creating close relationships with veterans and soldiers in active duty we can help demystify the experience of war, support soldiers, and eventually dismantle the military structure.

Campaign Funds!

Artist’s stipend: $3300

Space rental: $700

Props and costumes: $150

Marketing materials: $150

Note: as you can see most of the funds will be going directly to your beloved friend artists who are working so hard to bring more peace and creativity into our communities. Each one of these performers are highly trained and put in more than a hundred hours of voluntary rehearsal work towards this project already! AMAZING! These funds will help give them a small stipend to show respect for all their incredible and hard work. Please support artists and their livelihood!!! In case we don’t reach our goal most of the funds will still go to your beloved artists.

 

Perks!

Please check out our elaborate and fabulous list of perks that are available to you with your donations!

 

Reviews!

        "...Equal parts provocative and hilarious, sobering and loving, this show tells our story of endless war through clowning. Though war and clowns may seem like an odd or even distasteful combination, Racheli skillfully enters a long tradition of comedic tragedy with inclusion, humor and curiosity and never even a hint of self-righteousness. It is a rare person who can transmute anger and frustration into clarity and wisdom, let alone through a troupe of clowns. With her writing, direction, and performance, Racheli demonstrates that this piece is only the beginning of a long, stunning artistic career. She will no doubt bring offering upon offering to our collective consciousness. Racheli Mendelson is going to shake it up and, in so doing, wake us up."    

                                                 Katherine Malachuk MBA, author of You're Accepted

 

  "This tender and poignant clown show about war and soldiers brings together the great tradition of social protest and theater. We recognize ourselves, we laugh but our heart is sad.  Clown practice is deep. It asks us to make fun and also to see the truth of being human.The performers gave their all!  They were never aggressive and in a play about war that is mighty!"

                                         Barbara Dilley, performer and teacher, Naropa University                

 

Other Ways You Can Help!

       Please share our campaign with your friends and family and use the Indiegogo share tools! Every dollar helps to get this movement going.

story:
Van Cougar Theater Company, established in 2007, has produced three full-length plays in NYC: Rocky Philly (2009), Gonna See a Movie Called Gunga Din (2012), and TUBE (2012). 

VAN COUGAR WEBSITE

In June, we are workshopping our first play, Rocky Philly, as an initial rehearsal period for its west coast premiere in Los Angeles (2015). Van Cougar created this play in 2009 for the Bushwick Starr theater in Brooklyn, NY. The script was built from stories we recorded of people born and raised in Philadelphia. We took those stories and layered them over the movement of the classic film Rocky. 

The results are startling and illuminating—human oral histories running in syncopated rhythms alongside a major Hollywood fairy tale. The physical and mental execution that the work demands of the actor takes performance from mere emotional vulnerability to virtuosic athleticism. We have built two additional plays exploring these techniques and now we are ready to remount our first and most personal piece in its fullest manifestation.

VILLAGE VOICE REVIEW OF ORIGINAL PRODUCTION of ROCKY PHILLY

To accomplish our goal, we need to raise an additional $3,000 on top of the $3,000 we have already raised through our mail campaign. This sum will cover rehearsal space expenses and will enable us to fairly pay our actors and production team for their time and work. 

To be fully transparent we include this breakdown of our budget:

  • $1,000 = renting a rehearsal space for 50 hours - $20/hr 
  • $4,000 = $500 stipends for each actor - 8 actors, 2 weeks of work
  • $1,000 = $500 stipend for the director and the stage manager
  • Total = $6,000 - we have already raised $3K - help us meet our goal!

The following opportunities to contribute are available:

  • $25 - Email of Gratitude
  • $50 - Postcard from Mark and Erica
  • $100 - Invite to Rocky Philly Rehearsal
  • $250 - Van Cougar T-shirt (first batch ever!)
  • $500 - Van Cougar Recording with your friends

Your contribution to this IndieGoGo campaign is not tax-deductible. To make a tax-deductible contribution to Van Cougar, please visit: www.vancougar.org/donate/

If you made a donation here but would like it to be tax-deductible please email us: info@vancougararchive.org.

story:
Thank you for considering support  Paradox of Tales 2: The Royal Wedding.  Porodax Praductions is a family based company bringing entertainment to Fayetteville, NC and the surrounding areas while also giving back to the community. Porodax was established based on the successful dinner theater play “Paradox of Tales” which was written and directed by Julionne Johnson who is a writer, director, and up & coming actress.  Paradox of Tales is a family based dinner play filled with comedy, drama, and adventure involving your favorite fairy tales characters such as Cinderella, Sleeping Beauty, Snow White, Peter Pan, and Beauty and the Beast who took matters into their own hands.  Within a timeframe of two and a half months a script, casting calls and rehearsals with an amazing cast consisting of 60 actors throughout Southeast Region, some coming from as far as Georgia and Florida, put on three performances in one day, and sold close to 300 tickets with very little advertisement.

         




Under our new production company “Paradox of Tales 2: The Royal Wedding” which is the sequel to Paradox of Tales will be coming summer 2014.  With the royal wedding coming there is even more going on behind the scenes with our old characters and some new characters joining the adventure.

                          

Porodax is excited to offer the Performance Sponsor Program, which allows sponsors to take a larger role in our public relations and advertising campaign.  Instead of allowing sponsors to only place an internal ad within our theater programs, our performance sponsors now have a variety of ways to reach Porodax patrons.

Your support makes it possible for us to bring entertainment through theater, maintain high quality production, support local and aspiring actors, allow for family bonding, our youth to increase their public speaking skills and self-confidence, and the outright joy of theater to thousands of children and adults in our–your– community.  Porodax sponsorship makes good business sense, as it can bring tangible benefits to your business. Here is a partial list of what your donations will go towards:

  • Venue Location
  • Production Equipment
  • Set Design
  • Props
  • Feeding as many as 80 talent and crew on performance day

We are offering you the opportunity to participate in our Performance Sponsor Program.  Based on the amount of your Sponsorship please see some the perk you can receive:

  • Billboard Advertisement
  • VIP Dinner Tickets
  • Executive Producer Recognition
  • Banner with your Name/company logo
  • Special shout on Facebook and Twitter page
  • Production Poster and T-Shirt
  • Full Color AD page
  • Digital DVD copy of the play
  • Your name/company logo will be prominently feature directly on any and all media attention Paradox of Tales receives: Social media; Printing material; Radio/newspaper
  • Your name/company will mentioned in our before/after show “Curtain Speech”
  • Any sponsor contributing $350.00 or more will also include a vendor table to display product during the play at the venue location and discounted professional security camera if needed.


Please Help Get The Word Out!!!

Even if you give $25 or $1000, that donation will be greatly appreciated and we thank you so much in advance for giving what you can. But if you are not able to support our production financially, you still can help. Please help us by by posting, sharing,  and tweeting to as many people that you can. You never know who might want to help with this production.  You may know of a business or an individual that want to advertisement in the program book that will be seen by hundreds of patrons. To stay update with the production please follow us on Facebook and Twitter and help spread the word.

Use the IndieGoGo sharing tools at the top of this page and the more you can share, like, and tweet this page, the higher the IndieGoGo increases that can lead exposure to our production and even mention in the press or news.

Please contact us at porodaxpraductions@gmail.com if you have any questions and check out Indiegogo Help Center if you have any questions in regards  to making contributions.

Thank you for supporting our Production "Paradox of Tales 2: The Royal Wedding".  We look forward to working with you.  

Parodax of Tales 2 The Royal Wedding - Ballroom Crown Center, Fayetteville, NC
