story:
Who's Lying Down in Your Heart?

WHO'S LYING DOWN IN YOUR HEART? by Bishop writer Eva Poole-Gilson is a searing drama that examines the relationship between two sisters who share a childhood filled with painful secrets. 

Poetic Justice Project will present this groundbreaking live theatre/film hybrid production in Shell Beach, at the San Luis Obispo County Women's Jail, in Mammoth Lakes and in Ridgecrest. 

WHO’S LYING DOWN IN YOUR HEART? is directed by Traci Mettler-Bradbury and produced in partnership with Allan Hancock College's Film & Video Department. 

As sisters Ellen and Veronica explore their painful past through a series of telephone calls, remembered scenes from their childhood appear on a screen above them. Real-life sisters Rosemary and Tina Grace play the fictional sisters. Guillermo Willie plays Grampa.

Appearing on film are Bull Chaney, Toni De La Guerra, Leonard Flippen, Jorge Manly Gil, Janet Guess, Alex Lopez, Renee Lopez, Barbara Reeger, Topanga Saldana, Maux Samuel and Chris Sanchez.

A program of the William James Association, Poetic Justice Project began in Santa Maria, California in 2009, with the vision of unlocking hearts and minds with bold, original theatre. We are the only theatre company that engages formerly incarcerated actors in the original plays that address crime, punishment and redemption.

What We Need & What You Get

WHO'S LYING DOWN IN YOUR HEART? is funded in part by the California Arts Council and the National Endowment for the Arts. Poetic Justice Project needs your help to raise $5000 toward production costs: cast and crew stipends, venue rental, sets, costumes and travel costs.

The play will be presented at 7 p.m. on Saturday, May 10 at La Perla del Mar Chapel, 205 Windward Ave. in Shell Beach. On Saturday, May 17, there are two shows, at 2 p.m. and 7 p.m. at Edison Theatre, 100 College Parkway, Mammoth Lakes. On Sunday, May 18, the play will be performed at 3 p.m. at the USO Building, 230 W. Ridgecrest Blvd. in Ridgecrest. 

Everyone who donates $15 or more will receive a gift from Poetic Justice Project!

Changing Lives!

Poetic Justice Project is a life-changing theatre company. More than 80 actors have appeared in PJP's productions since we began in 2009. Only two have returned to prison. For every 20 people we empower to stay in the community, California taxpayers save $1 million each year.

Our audiences are changed, too, by our performances. A sampling of audience responses to one our recent plays:

    • Actors were great!
    • It affected me emotionally.
    • The play gave me a different perspective on life in prison.
    • Cons R people 2.
    • High level of professionalism—great acting.
    • Surprisingly, I’m more hopeful because these folks are so inspiring.
    • Watching redemption process!

Other Ways You Can Help

Please help us get the word out, and if you're nearby, attend one of our performances of WHO'S LYING DOWN IN YOUR HEART?
story_txt:
Who's Lying Down in Your Heart?
WHO'S
LYING DOWN IN YOUR HEART? by Bishop writer Eva Poole-Gilson is a searing drama
that examines the relationship between two sisters who share a childhood filled with painful secrets. Poetic
Justice Project will present this groundbreaking live theatre/film hybrid production in Shell
Beach, at the San Luis Obispo County Women's Jail, in Mammoth Lakes and in Ridgecrest. 
WHO’S LYING DOWN IN YOUR HEART? is directed by Traci Mettler-Bradbury and
produced in partnership with Allan Hancock College's Film & Video
Department. 
As
sisters Ellen and Veronica explore their painful past through a series of
telephone calls, remembered scenes from their childhood appear on a screen
above them. Real-life sisters Rosemary and Tina Grace play the fictional sisters.
Guillermo Willie plays Grampa.
Appearing
on film are Bull Chaney, Toni De La Guerra, Leonard Flippen, Jorge Manly Gil,
Janet Guess, Alex Lopez, Renee Lopez, Barbara Reeger, Topanga Saldana, Maux
Samuel and Chris Sanchez.A program of the William James Association, Poetic Justice Project began in Santa Maria, California in 2009, with the vision of unlocking hearts and minds with bold, original theatre. We are the only theatre company that engages formerly incarcerated actors in the original plays that address crime, punishment and redemption.What We Need & What You GetWHO'S LYING DOWN IN YOUR HEART? is funded in part by the California Arts Council and the National Endowment for the Arts. Poetic Justice Project needs your help to raise $5000 toward production costs: cast and crew stipends, venue rental, sets, costumes and travel costs.
The play
will be presented at 7 p.m. on Saturday, May 10 at La Perla del Mar Chapel, 205
Windward Ave. in Shell Beach. On
Saturday, May 17, there are two shows, at 2 p.m. and 7 p.m. at Edison Theatre,
100 College Parkway, Mammoth Lakes. On
Sunday, May 18, the play will be performed at 3 p.m. at the USO Building, 230
W. Ridgecrest Blvd. in Ridgecrest. Everyone who donates $15 or more will receive a gift from Poetic Justice Project!Changing Lives!Poetic Justice Project is a life-changing theatre company. More than 80 actors have appeared in PJP's productions since we began in 2009. Only two have returned to prison. For every 20 people we empower to stay in the community, California taxpayers save $1 million each year.Our audiences are changed, too, by our performances. A sampling of audience responses to one our recent plays:
Actors were great!
It affected me emotionally.
The play gave me a different perspective on life in prison.
Cons R people 2.
High level of professionalism—great acting.
Surprisingly, I’m more hopeful because these folks are so inspiring.
Watching redemption process!
Other Ways You Can HelpPlease help us get the word out, and if you're nearby, attend one of our performances of WHO'S LYING DOWN IN YOUR HEART?

story:
Hello! 

Eclectic Full Contact Theatre is a Chicago-based theatre company whose mission it is to foster and strengthen the bonds between audience and performer. Established in 2011 by a group of seasoned theatre professionals with a combined 40+ years of experience, our name comes from our desire to do strong, affecting theatre regardless of period, style, or subject matter (Eclectic) and our mission to make theatergoers an integral part of the creative process by allowing them behindthe scenes every step of the way. (Full Contact) To that end, we open our read-thrus and dress rehearsals to the public, post behind-the-scenes rehearsal blogs and videos, and offer multiple talkbacks with the cast members during the run of the show.

Eclectic's inaugural season last year garnered critical and audience acclaim for all three of our shows. ("Music From a Sparkling Planet", "Six Degrees of Separation", and "The Complete Works of William Shakespeare [Abridged]") "Complete Works" was so successful, we were able to extend the run at the Metropolis Performing Arts Center in Arlington Heights. To see more of the critics' comments, and to find out even more about us, you can go to www.eclectic-theatre.com

The second show of our second season is the world premiere drama, "Unshelved", by Beth Kander. It deals with the effects of early onset Alzheimer's on a typical American family, and poses the question--who's identity is more changed, the victim's, or the victim's family's? It is a gripping and touching show which everyone at Eclectic Full Contact Theatre fell in love with and feels very passionate about. The subject is one that touches everyone in the country in one way or another, and we all feel that it is an important play that needs to be seen. It is just the kind of story-oriented, character-based play that we got into theatre to present. Since it is a world   premiere, getting the word out about the show is imperative, since it doesn't have instant name recognition. To that end, the need for advertising is increased, which requires extra funds. We are endeavoring to create a much greater ad presence for this show, to ensure that it gets the audience we all feel it deserves. We are raising funds to help offset those costs and make sure the expenses for the rest of the production don't fall below the high professional standards we have already  established through four shows.

Not only is your donation to Eclectic Full Contact theatre tax deductible as we are a 501(c)3 nonprofit corporation, but your donation also gets you perks such as free tickets, autographed memorabilia, recognition on our website, chances to meet the cast, invitations to Eclectic celebrations and social events, and much more. Please help us bring this incredible show to the stage and help us get the word out about it. Even if you are unable to donate, feel free to share this Indiegogo page with anyone you know who is interested in helping create a funny, touching, affecting piece of art.

story:
About the Show

Yama and Kalindi follows the story of Alan, an astrophysicist who understands the multiverse better than he understands love. He's about to make the discovery of a lifetime as he tracks two binary stars (Yama and Kalindi) and their descent into a black hole, when Margo enters his life...

Yama has climbed the highest mountain and reached the heavens to collect a gift for his wife Kalindi. But what he brings her is what neither of them could have ever expected: Death.

With dance, mime, mythology, romance, humor, caryatids, glowing spheres, and multiple realities,Yama and Kalindi: A Transdimensional Love Story promises to be a like no love story you've ever seen.


Who We Are

Hey Rube Productions is a very small theater company committed to bringing high-quality, original work to the Twin Cities. Our current project is "Yama & Kalindi: a Transdimensional Love Story" and will be performed as part of the Minnesota Fringe Festival 2014. 

For us, this is not simply a hobby or diversion. Theater is our life and as artists, we take nothing more seriously. To make this production happen (pay for actors, props, sets, marketing, etc), we need to raise $2,500. If you can help us even with $10, $20, $30, you will be sponsoring a tremendously important endeavor. 

Check out our Facebook page for rehearsal pictures, ticket information, and details about performance times: https://www.facebook.com/events/848048905222383/


What We Need & What You Get

Additionally, donors at the $250 level will receive two tickets to the show, show poster signed by the cast, and an original painting by local watercolor artist Almira Downs.

At the $150 level, two tickets to the show plus show poster signed by the cast.

At the $100 level, two tickets to the show.

Everyone else receives the benefit of knowing they help make a memorable theater project come to life.

Thank you all and see you on opening night!


Contact: Marcus@around-around.com

story:
THE TRIBE

 A new theater company that is dedicated to devising and producing provocative work that viscerally reawakens our audience and helps them see the world in a new way. We are dedicated to asking the big questions that are facing us as a society right now and inspire people to live in a bolder freer way.

Our first production as a company will be Punk Rock by Steven Simons, a hyper-realistic play with a theatrical flair about modern adolescence and what it takes to survive in modern culture

The Tribe functions as an ensemble theatre company but we are first and foremost a family. We come from different backgrounds but are connected through our love of art and each other.  We look forward to learning from our collaborators, you and all our adventures as The Tribe. 

What We Need 

As a new Theatre Company we are building from the ground up.  We have started to build a beautiful community. 

We need the funds to realize this production and share it with our new theatre

family.

The $4000 will help cover the cost of...

  • Meet the Tribe

Nick Browne / Tom Driscoll / Melessie Clark / Johnny Pozzi / Kevin Donohue 

Julia Warner / Maddie Bucci / Phil Feldman / Alex Walton / Alexis Cash

story:
Scorched - A Fiery New Musical

In an impossibly perfect kingdom, Princess and Prince encounter something wholly unfamiliar on the eve of their wedding: doubt. When the world as they know it goes up in smoke, Princess and Prince, King and Queen, dragons and witches are left to struggle with how and what to rebuild from the ashes.

With book/lyrics by Molly Houlahan and music/lyrics by Benji Goldsmith, SCORCHED is a whimsical examination of the stories we tell and how they shape us. A contemporary frame on a classic narrative, SCORCHED is a multi-generational show that will inspire millennials, parents, and children alike to reimagine what it means to seek a happy ending.

The Team

  • Our team consists of over thirty enthusiastic theater makers — musicians, producers, designers, and performers all united by a belief in the power of good storytelling. Many members of our creative team met at Yale, and the full team comes from a diverse set of backgrounds, with experience at the Public Theater, the A.R.T., Williamstown Theatre Festival, Disney Theatrical Group, Second Stage Theatre, the Eugene O'Neill Theatre Center, and more. To learn more about everyone working on our show, please visit our website.
  • Molly Houlahan - Director & Writer/Lyricist 
    Molly Houlahan just finished the year as the Bret C. Harte Directing Fellow and the assistant to the Artistic Director at Berkeley Repertory Theatre, where she assisted Sean Graney on The Hypocrites’ The Pirates of Penzance, Daniel Sullivan on Macbeth starring Frances McDormand and Conleth Hill, and Mary Zimmerman on Treasure Island. She has also assisted Kate Whoriskey on Sweat by Lynn Nottage at both Oregon Shakespeare Festival and Arena Stage. She previously worked with The Public in the Producing Department and at Steppenwolf Theatre Company. Her directing work has been featured in FringeNYC, TinyRhino Short Play Festival and New York Theatre Workshop’s Jonathan Larson Lab. Molly won the Louis Sudler Prize for Excellence in the Performing and Creative Arts upon graduating from Yale.
  • Benji Goldsmith - Composer & Lyricist
    Benji Goldsmith is currently an MFA student in NYU’s Graduate Musical Theatre Writing Program. He began performing at a young age, singing in the Metropolitan Opera Children’s Chorus from 2000-2005, and, as a pianist, has won several competitions and performed at Carnegie Hall’s Weill Recital Hall. Benji studied Composition at Yale and with a focus on Music Direction. He music directed several musicals such as the Mainstage productions of Hair and The Drowsy Chaperone, while also spending five summers working as a Music Director and Teaching Artist at Acting Manitou, a summer theater program in Waterville, ME. Benji was also the Musical Director of the Yale Whiffenpoofs, the oldest a cappella group in the United States. As a composer and lyricist, Benji has written three full-length musicals, The Average Achievers (with bookwriter Jonathan Karpinos,) Swamplandia! (with bookwriter Andrew Bezek,) and, of course, Scorched. He is a recipient of the ASCAP Foundation Morton Gould Young Composer Award, Yale’s Beekman Cannon Friends of Music Prize, and NMI’s New Voices Project.

The Araca Project

SCORCHED has been chosen as a member of the sixth season of The Araca Project, an initiative by the Araca Group to foster the growth of young producers. This summer, our producing team attended a week of producing intensives designed to help us get our show off the ground in the best way possible. Additionally, the Araca Project provides our theater space and serves as a source of guidance along the journey of producing SCORCHED. To learn more about The Araca Project and the other shows performing this season, visit their website.

What We Need & What You Get

Our total budget is $25,000. Because we have just five performances, ticket revenue will only account for a small portion of our full budget. We aim to raise $9,000 through our Indiegogo campaign, with the remainder coming from individual donations.

Our budget consists of three major categories:

  • Artist Stipends - $6,000
    • Our production team is composed entirely of young artists. We believe that it is of the utmost importance to compensate all creative professionals for their work, and this is especially true for emerging artists who are too often shoehorned into working for free with the promise of gaining experience and exposure. As excited as we are to provide our team with this invaluable opportunity to add to their portfolios, we are equally excited to help them pay the bills!
  • Production - $15,000
    • Although Scorched exists in a fairy tale kingdom, we need real-world resources to bring it to life. Production expenses range from build materials such as lumber, paint, and fabric to sound and lighting equipment to rehearsal space rentals.
  • Marketing, Administrative, Miscellaneous - $4,000
    • Our miscellaneous business expenses include creation of marketing materials, fees associated with our website, program printing, trucking, and more.

With your help, we are confident that we can create the premiere production SCORCHED deserves. In addition to the ability to support this show, we're also offering our donors some fabulous perks (which can be found in the column to the right).

  • Your donation will be tax-deductible thanks to our fiscal sponsor, Fractured Atlas.
  • You can also receive behind-the-scenes SCORCHED content by following our social media platforms (Facebook, Instagram, Twitter) and by visiting our website.

The Impact

By backing SCORCHED, you will be supporting a passionate group of young theater makers and helping bring this phenomenal show to life.

  • Everyone working on this show is a young artist eager for a platform on which to display their incredible talent. By donating, you allow us to produce this show at the scale that will provide the most fulfilling process for all involved. 
  • We believe in the impact of theater. Our audience is anyone who has ever been told, has told, or will tell a fairy tale. Employing themes of gender and sexuality, perception and identity, SCORCHED evokes all the nostalgia of fairy tales while also imploring us to reconsider the truths we've always been told. We hope for SCORCHED to propose a new, updated fairy tale for the next generation. Help us craft and spread this powerful message of celebrating difference and breaking convention.

Risks & Challenges

There are many challenges involved with producing any show, let alone a brand new musical in New York City; difficulties such as issues with equipment rentals, manpower limitations, and condensed rehearsal timelines can impact productions of all sizes. Our team feels especially well-prepared to face such challenges head-on. The producing team alone shares more than ten producing credits among them, and all held major leadership positions in one of the oldest and largest undergraduate theater organizations in the country. Additionally, every member of our team has significant experience in their respective field. We are confident in our abilities to overcome each and every obstacle that comes our way.

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that not everyone is able to provide a fiscal contribution, but that doesn't mean you can't help us out in other ways!

  • Make sure to share this page with anyone who might be interested in donating (there are share tools at the top of the page).
  • Follow and share any our social media accounts to help us get the word out (Facebook, Instagram, Twitter).
  • Come see SCORCHED! Check out the performance details below.
  • If you are interested in providing an in-kind donation or placing an advertisement in our program, please contact producer Yuvika Tolani.

Performance Details

We'd love to see you at a performance of SCORCHED in October!

Performances will take place October 6th-9th at the John Cullum Theatre at the American Theatre of Actors. Ticket information will be posted on our website in September.

 

SCORCHED is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non‐profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of SCORCHED must be made payable to “Fractured Atlas” and are tax‐deductible to the extent permitted by law.

story:
The Pitch!

"More Than All the World" details the true story of England's King Edward II, whose controversial 14th Century reign was wrought with scandal. His love for a knight named Piers Gaveston was so mighty that his contemporaries referred to Piers as Edward's "husband" some 700 years before marriage equality started to spread across the Western World. This remarkably brazen love caused such strife in his kingdom, that it led to Edward's forced abdication at the hands of his wrathful wife, Queen Isabella, whom history has dubbed "The She-Wolf of France". Our tale is rakishly narrated by famed 16th Century wordsmith and raconteur Christopher Marlowe, who wrote a fearlessly candid play about Edward II during his brief, lustrous career.

Libertine Idol Productions has successfully executed concerts, staged readings, backers auditions and full productions of musicals in New York City since its founding in 2012. Until now, we have only worked on small shows of eight actors or fewer but, with your help, we plan to execute a world-premiere staged reading of our largest, most ambitious piece to date, "More Than All the World". The reading will be presented as part of the acclaimed reading series at the illustrious York Theatre Company in Manhattan. This is just the first step for a show that our team feels has a great deal of promise for a future on stages in the U.S. and abroad, perhaps even the Great White Way... Just think of the bragging rights if that happens! And, we're fiscally sponsored through Fractured Atlas, so all donations are tax-deductible!

What are you helping us pay for?

Since this is our first time presenting "More Than All the World" and since we're being hosted by the esteemed York Theatre Company, our goal is to make sure we present the show in the best possible light, so we can impress the producers and industry professionals who will attend the reading. Your contribution will see that we can afford:

·  The world-class creative team we've assembled, including director Rachel Klein (Around the World in 80 Days, Anthem, GRINDR the Opera), Music Director/Arranger Andy Peterson (Atomic, Stalker the Musical) and playwright/composer Erik Ransom (GRINDR the Opera, Coming: A Rock Musical of Biblical Proportions, Happy Yummy Chicken the Motion Picture.)

·  A talented, culturally diverse band of twelve performers from the Broadway community and beyond, who can do justice to the rich characters and sweeping musical score represented in the musical.

·  A casting director to give us access and advice on whom to approach for the roles.

·  Publicity to make sure the right people are in the room when we present the reading.

·  Rehearsal space rental.

·  Printing of scripts, scores and other materials, as needed.

·  And more!

The Impact

Touching on timeless themes in grandiose scope, King Edward's is a little known albeit remarkable true story that we'd love to introduce to modern audiences. We think people will be surprised to see how, though much has changed in 700 years, there's also much that's strikingly similar. With your tax-deductible donation, we can bring Edward, Marlowe, Isabella and Gaveston to life once more for our March 15th reading at the York!

You know your donation is going toward a secure, successful brand with Libertine Idol Productions. Our last presentation was the staged reading of "GRINDR The Opera" which was discussed in the worldwide press in seven languages and was written up in such noted publications as Salon.com, The Guardian, The Daily Beast, The Telegraph and Playbill.com. That show was optioned by a producer and is currently fundraising for a full-production Off-Broadway! We also produced "Coming: A Rock Musical of Biblical Proportions" which was one of the top-selling shows at FringeNYC 2014. We believe "More Than All the World" has the potential to exceed even those achievements! It's a show that will teach people about two engaging historical periods, one of the most noted Elizabethan playwrights and it's a genuinely interesting, relatable story about love, war, classism, homophobia and otherness with as many twists and turns as a season of "Game of Thrones"

Risks & Challenges

The biggest challenge we're facing here is the fundraising! We only have a month to get the funding together, so we can present an awesome reading at the York! Getting people into a reading can also be difficult as well, but we plan to put some of these funds toward getting the word out to producers, artistic directors and literary offices from the commercial and non-profit theatre communities! We believe "More Than All the World" could thrive in either context.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't afford to contribute money to our campaign, we'd love for you to get the word out about our show! Please 'like' our page on Facebook and share our campaign with your friends!

"More Than All the World" is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of "More Than All the World" must be made payable to Fractured Atlas only and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.
story_txt:
The Pitch!
 
"More
Than All the World" details the true story of England's King Edward II,
whose controversial 14th Century reign was wrought with scandal. His love for a
knight named Piers Gaveston was so mighty that his contemporaries referred to
Piers as Edward's "husband" some 700 years before marriage equality
started to spread across the Western World. This remarkably brazen love caused
such strife in his kingdom, that it led to Edward's forced abdication at the
hands of his wrathful wife, Queen Isabella, whom history has dubbed "The
She-Wolf of France". Our tale is rakishly narrated by famed 16th Century wordsmith
and raconteur Christopher Marlowe, who wrote a fearlessly candid play about
Edward II during his brief, lustrous career. 
Libertine Idol Productions has successfully
executed concerts, staged readings, backers auditions and full productions of
musicals in New York City since its founding in 2012. Until now, we have only
worked on small shows of eight actors or fewer but, with your help, we plan to
execute a world-premiere staged reading of our largest, most ambitious piece to date,
"More Than All the World". The reading will be presented as part of
the acclaimed reading series at the illustrious York Theatre Company in Manhattan.
This is just the first step for a show that our team feels has a great deal of
promise for a future on stages in the U.S. and abroad, perhaps even the Great

story:
WHO WE ARE

We are Lady Junk theatre, presenting our debut show BUTTER, which will open at VAULT Festival in 2016.

 


Lady Junk Theatre began as Bethan McEvoy, Emily Bairstow, Ruby Thompson, Tallulah Brown and Zena Carswell, but we are a growing collective of actors, directors, writers and practitioners who make theatre together. We have a number of writers working on BUTTER, and loads of people involved behind the scenes, allowing us to take this project a from the page to the stage. 

These are the wonderful women have already contributed to the making of BUTTER (although the list keeps growing): Ali Dowling, Emma Ballantine, Faye Thomas, Loren O’Brien, Norma Butikofer, Sonia Jalaly, Jenny Eggleton and Victoria Gimby (along with our associate producer, Hugo Nicholson).

ABOUT BUTTER

In a society filled with complex relationships, our play explores one of the most complicated of all: women and food. 

                                                

Based on the stories of real women, BUTTER delves into the joy, sadness, nostalgia, rage and indifference that comes when women and food meet, raising playful and serious questions about the delight, the despair, and the decisions surrounding eating and the modern woman. 

WHAT WE NEED TO RAISE

With your help, we hope to raise £1,325, and we're offering a load of perks to entice you... Please check them out to see what's on offer. We need to cover the following costs.
rehearsal space (£625)
2016 will be a rehearsal space odyssey. We need space not only to rehearse the show, but to actually make it happen: workshops are an essential part of our development process. 
set design and props (£225)
Although our set will be minimal, it will be essential for realising our vision for BUTTER. We’ll be performing in The Cavern at VAULT Festival – it’s magnificent, but imposing, and we need to do it justice.

technician hire (£200)
We will be employing a tech-legend to help orchestrate and operate the technical side of the show.

flyers and posters (£125)
There’s nothing better than getting an unexpected flyer when you’re trying to get somewhere in hurry. In all seriousness, though, these will be vital in getting the word out about BUTTER.

costume (£100)
Costume is crucial, and there are a lot of people in the cast. 

food (£50)
Without giving too much away, there’s going to be a lot of food in this show. Don’t worry – it won’t be going on Marks and Spencer all-butter cookies; it’ll be on Lidl delicacies for use in the show only.



THANK YOU FOR READING

Thank you so much for reading this, and for any support you can offer!

story:
MONEY & RUN MARATHON

THEATER SCHMEATER CELEBRATES OUR 25TH SEASON

We wanted to do something special for our 25th anniversary -   something Schmee, something unique, something BIG.

So we hit on the idea of presenting 3 different episodes of Wayne Rawley's hilarious action and adventure epic, Money & Run. A late-night favorite at our old basement space in the early 2000's, we are excited to bring these shows back to life with two episodes on weeknights and all three episodes, back to back to back, on Saturdays, running from May 10th to June 10th, 2017.  

And as a special treat, each episode will feature a different cast! That's over 30 actors! For a little 50 seat theater like us, this represents a production akin to Cecil B DeMille's Parting of the Red Sea! Or the battle scenes in Lord of the Rings (if they weren't CG'd!). In short, this IS BIG!

At best, box office revenue supplies about half the production costs for any given show; the other half is raised through other means.  A fraction comes from civic grant money, but the vast majority comes from individual donations - that is just a fact of life in non-profit arts.  So we are asking for your help in raising additional funds to produce our Money & Run Marathon. We are determined to bring our audience the best show possible (the best things come in small boxes!) but to do so, to meet our standards, does take actual money.  Your generous donation will help pay for artist stipends, costumes, props, wood, paint, screws, lighting-- well, all the things that go into producing quality theater on the stage and off.

For 25 years Theater Schmeater has proven itself as the little theater that could. From operating in a basement garage overcoming financial ups and downs, to building a new home in Belltown, we have met our share of challenges and have come through even stronger. That is something to celebrate! Join the party with this special return of Money & Run by Wayne Rawley - bigger and better than ever!  Because art, and laughter, and people, are important.

Please help us make this production the talk of the town.

We will see you at The Schmee!

 

 

 

Short Summary

Contributors fund ideas they can be passionate about and to people they trust. Here are some things to do in this section:

  • Introduce yourself and your background.
  • Briefly describe your campaign and why it's important to you.
  • Express the magnitude of what contributors will help you achieve.

Remember, keep it concise, yet personal. Ask yourself: if someone stopped reading here would they be ready to make a contribution?

What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • Explain how much funding you need and where it's going. Be transparent and specific-people need to trust you to want to fund you.
  • Tell people about your unique perks. Get them excited!
  • Describe where the funds go if you don't reach your entire goal.

The Impact

Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know the difference their contribution will make:

  • Explain why your project is valuable to the contributor and to the world.
  • Point out your successful track record with projects like this (if you have one).
  • Make it real for people and build trust.

Risks & Challenges

People value your transparency. Be open and stand out by providing insight into the risks and obstacles you may face on the way to achieving your goal.

  • Share what qualifies you to overcome these hurdles.
  • Describe your plan for solving these challenges.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that's all there is to it.

story:
When we hear the words "Heart Disease" - we do not often associate it with the YOUTH. According to the World Heart Foundation, The unhealthy lifestyles that lead to heart disease often begin at a young age, and ESPECIALLY with today's increase in child obesity, maybe it's time for a NEW PERSPECTIVE.  

The question is: How could we INSPIRE the YOUTH to live a HEALTHIER and ACTIVE lifestyle? 

OUR ANSWER: "DANCE YOUR HEART OUT". 

What we need are TRUE believers- To spread the MESSAGE 

That- "WIth PASSION, the Youth will BEAT heart disease"


STORY BEHIND THE CAUSE & "DYHO" NOW

"I never imagined going through an open-heart surgery at the age of 21.

Let alone, Dance Your Heart Out." - Christine Coco. 


THUS, “Dance Your Heart Out” is a Fundraiser Event & Cause aimed at increasing awareness about heart disease among the youth through artistic forms of self-expression that derive straight from the heart such as music and dance. It has become a movement to inspire the youth in finding  passion in living, as we feel may be the foundation to living a healthier and active lifestyle, and in turn - BEAT heart disease.

What we hope to ask from you is to keep your hearts REACHING out to the YOUTH.

With YOUR support & others', we will be able to spread the MESSAGE while raising funds for charitable organizations.

This year's 2nd Edition : "Dance Your Heart Out" Remix 2013 Fundraising Event", is taking place on November 29th at le National, in Montreal, Canada.  

All profits will be going to the Heart and Stroke Foundation of Quebec as this year's selected charitable organization. http://www.fmcoeur.qc.ca/

OUR GOAL / HOW WE CONNECT

We aim to raise a minimum of 10,000$  in profits for the  Foundation &  Hope to  INSPIRE the YOUTH to FIND PASSION in LIVING. 

WHY GIVE TO "DYHO"? 

You will be: 

1) Helping provide a medium of self-expression for the youth.
2) Helping spread the message and the PASSION.
3) Helping the YOUTH beat HEART DISEASE/ INSPIRING EACH OTHER. 

YOU WILL MAKE THAT DIFFERENCE.

Your contribution will help us reach our goal to be an inspirational movement, a reality.

·  Dance Your Heart Out 2011 raised $4,000 and was donated to the
   Montreal Heart Institute, where Christine Coco had her heart surgery.

·  Heart disease and stroke are two of the three causes of death in Canada, and the          number 1 killer, worldwide. - It AFFECTS us all. 

By joining our journey in beating heart disease, we will be able to spread AWARENESS, and make heart disease, HISTORY. At DYHO,  Statistics depend on the beat of your heart. 

YOUR HEART SPEAKS LOUD.

So, we understand you may not have the means to contribute, but you can still help us make a difference.

HOW?

  • "Like" our Facebook Page and follow our journey on Twitter. Spread the message to loved ones, friends, family, even strangers? 
  •   By simply Sharing and liking our page as well - YOUR voice will SPREAD.
  • Ask your friends and family if they can donate to our Indie Gogo campaign!

On that note, “Dance Your Heart Out” is a way of life. It’s living without any limitations- with your heart” at its fullest potential. When you really “Dance Your Heart Out”, anything is possible - Why not Listen to your heart, "Dance Your Heart Out".

story:
Roving Shakespeare is a company formed by MFA graduates of the Shakespeare & Performance program of Mary Baldwin College in Staunton, VA.  Seeking to work together after graduation, the company will produce disparate productions across the country in 2013-14, including performances in Staunton, Chicago, Austin, and the San Francisco Bay Area.  These productions, that are led and supported by the original Rovers currently spread across the country, will engage local actors, theatre makers, and audiences within their own communities and on a national level. Roving Shakespeare combines scholarly and acting training in early modern theatre to bring a fresh perspective to Shakespeare and his contemporaries, as well as plays inspired by early modern theatre. 

Roving Shakespeare marks its Bay Area premiere with a Renaissance Style production of William Shakespeare’s The Merry Wives of Windsor on November 16th and 17th at 8 pm at the Fetterly Playhouse in Vallejo.  The play will be rehearsed and staged in a matter of 20 hours, before performing for the public November 16th and 17th.  The Renaissance Style of rehearsal attempts to recreate the rehearsal conditions of Shakespeare’s time, consisting of short rehearsal time and no formal director or designers. It gives modern audiences an opportunity not only to see a story unfold, but literally theatre in the making.

The Merry Wives of Windsor consists of both local actors of the San Francisco Bay Area and members of the original 13 Rovers across the country.  The original Rovers act as creative and supporting staff in areas such as production (Angelina LaBarre), graphic design (AJ Sclafani), publicity (James Byers), music direction (Elizabeth Rentfro) and dramaturgy (Stephanie Tschetter) while the local actors take care of the work on stage.

We are happy to announce those local actors are Derrick Karimian (Falstaff), Nestor Campos Jr (Host), Don Miller (Simple/Ford), Stephanie Rivas (Mistress Ford), Justin Hernandez (Fenton/Shallow),  Justin DuPuis (Page), Justin Lucas (Slender/Pistol),  Daila Vidor (Bardolph/Dr. Caius), Lindsay Stoltz-Karimian (Mistress Page), and Curt Thompson (Sir Hugh Evans).

------------------------------------------------------

The Rovers have already begun their season in Staunton, VA with their production of Hamletmachine, but now that we’re moving out across the country we need your help building the foundation of our digitally connected company. The funding we develop now will not only help with The Merry Wives of Windsor in Vallejo, CA, but also the future productions slated for the rest of the season.  Your donation will go beyond this production, but onto the rest of the “Roving Across the Country” season.

All donations will go to covering the rental costs of performance spaces, the purchasing and building of props and costume pieces, the printing costs, and best of all, paying our theatre makers for their work.

Even if you can’t make a donation, spread the word!  Tell others about us, come see The Merry Wives of Windsor, like our facebook page, or just chat us up. The Rovers welcome your support and the opportunity to engage locally, digitally, and nationally. Who knows, maybe we can rove to your city next.

its Bay Area premiere with a Renaissance Style production of William
Shakespeare’s The Merry Wives of Windsor on
November 16th and 17th at 8 pm at the Fetterly
Playhouse in Vallejo.  The play will be
rehearsed and staged in a matter of 20 hours, before performing for the public
November 16th and 17th.  The
Renaissance Style of rehearsal attempts to recreate the rehearsal conditions of
Shakespeare’s time, consisting of short rehearsal time and no formal director
or designers. It gives modern audiences an opportunity not only to see a story
unfold, but literally theatre in the making.
The Merry Wives of Windsor consists of both local actors of the San Francisco Bay Area and members of the original 13 Rovers across the country.  The original Rovers act as creative and supporting staff in areas such as production (Angelina LaBarre), graphic design (AJ Sclafani), publicity (James Byers), music direction (Elizabeth Rentfro) and dramaturgy (Stephanie Tschetter) while the local actors take care of the work on stage. 
We are happy to announce those local actors are Derrick
Karimian (Falstaff), Nestor Campos Jr (Host), Don Miller (Simple/Ford),
Stephanie Rivas (Mistress Ford), Justin Hernandez (Fenton/Shallow),  Justin DuPuis (Page), Justin Lucas
(Slender/Pistol),  Daila Vidor
(Bardolph/Dr. Caius), Lindsay Stoltz-Karimian (Mistress Page), and Curt Thompson
(Sir Hugh Evans).
------------------------------------------------------

The Rovers have already begun their
season in Staunton, VA with their production of Hamletmachine, but now that we’re moving out across the country we
need your help building the foundation of our digitally connected company. The funding we develop now will not only help
with The Merry Wives of Windsor in
Vallejo, CA, but also the future productions slated for the rest of the season.  Your donation will go beyond this production,
but onto the rest of the “Roving Across the Country” season.
All donations will go to covering the rental
costs of performance spaces, the purchasing and building of props and costume
pieces, the printing costs, and best of all, paying our theatre makers for
their work.
Even if you can’t make a donation,
spread the word!  Tell others about us,
come see The Merry Wives of Windsor,
like our facebook page, or just chat us up. The Rovers welcome your support and the opportunity to engage locally, digitally, and nationally.
Who knows, maybe we can rove to your city next.

story:
Short Summary

As we roll into our fourth season of presenting artists and facilitating new connections, SPARK is looking to the future more than ever.  We've hosted 3 seasons of sold out performances, showcased over 35 artists and performers, while always keeping one thing in mind: providing a networking platform for collaboration amongst creators and their audience.  

Last year we saw musicians, vocalists, a film maker and a dancer open the show with a collaborative, multimedia original performance, all built from artists who met at SPARK.  We also closed the season with an improv jam hosting over 30 movers at the AFAC to bring audience and artists into the same playground.  

This year we want to achieve all of that and more!  With your help,  and a little luck, SPARK will present its 4th and most successful season yet.  We have opened the month of May with another SPARK hosted improv jam, bringing our past movers and their networks right into the heart of SPARK. At the end of May, we will host our first ever Works in Progress informal showing, where past SPARK artists can share their latest creative endeavors for a familiar and maybe not so familiar group of art lovers.  This provides our fabulous artists the chance to reconnect with fellow cast members, showcase their work for fresh eyes, ask questions and receive feedback about their work.  

Our 4th installment of SPARK will take place on September 30th and October 1, 2016 and we are thrilled to return to the AFAC in downtown Brooklyn.  Applications will be available for this season starting in June!

But before all of these exciting things, SPARK is seeking support in our efforts to continue our mission.  Your support not only continues to provide a performance experience for NYC artists, but keeps the conversation about networking alive.  We believe that artists thrive and advance in their careers when they are supported and collaborating with like-minded creative souls. The right partnership can take a work from grassroots to revolutionary! Please take a moment to support us and our mission, as we seek to continue this important conversation in the NYC arts scene.

What We Need & What You Get

  • Presenting a performance season is no simple task, as we have spent the past 3 seasons working and growing through this process!
  • It takes time, effort and, of course, funding.
  • Your support helps us pay for:
  • Theatre Rental in downtown Brooklyn.
  • Afterglow (after show) reception goodies
  • Theatre rental insurance
  • Independent contractor pay (our team!)
  • Programs
  • Publicity and marketing materials
  • Tech rehearsal rental
  • Studio rehearsal rentals
  • Travel costs associated with SPARK's expansion
  • And all the little things that come up, like providing our cast with water and snacks.

The Impact

  • SPARK was created by and continues to thrive from the support of artists and forward thinking art-lovers. 
  • Our goal represents our true need this season and we know that with help both big and small, we can achieve it.
  • We thank you for checking out our campaign and supporting our mission.

Risks & Challenges

  • We are proud to say we have hosted 3 sold out performance seasons in Brooklyn over the last 3 years, but growth is a whole different beast.
  • As we aim to make a bigger mark on the world around us, we have developed new ways to expand our network.
  • On May 6th, we hosted our 2nd Dance Jam, providing artists with a donation-based improvisation class where they can move, reconnect with fellow cast and meet new movers.  
  • On May 27th we will host our 1st ever Works in Progress showing where former cast come together to share, take risk and exchange.  
  • This summer, SPARK has been accepted to the Detroit Dance Festival to showcase work by SPARK co-founder Kate Bishop, performed with her other half, SPARK co-founder Martha Dobbs.  This trip will mark the beginning of a new relationship between SPARK and Detroit.  
  • In the coming years, SPARK aims to bring it's performance series to cities like Detroit and this is the beginning of that goal.  

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that not everyone is in a place to give, but there are other ways you can support the SPARK 2016 season!

  • Visit our website at www.SPARKDanceForum.com and sign up for our email list!
  • Volunteer your time!  We always need help, especially during our fall season.
  • Follow us on Facebook, Instagram & Twitter @ SPARKDanceForum
  • Submit your work and perform with us (applications open in June)
  • Come to our workshops and jams!
  • And most importantly, come see our shows!

story:
Short Summary

★★★★
"Entertaining series of musical vignettes"
Matthew Partridge, Remotegoat. 

★★★★
"Outstanding performances" 
Lee Cogger, London Theatre 1.

★★★★
"Punchy, rhythmic and daring"
Laura Milas, West End Wilma. 

★★★★
"Slick writing...and ironic comic delivery"
Hannah Roe, Female Arts.

After two sell out productions A Working Title is ready to take on the UK. Twenty somethings across the country, in the middle of a quarter life crisis, need us and we need you!

It's about living in the city in a generation of renters, Tinder swipers, never-left-the-nesters, budget shoppers, internshipers, minimum wage workers, sofa surfers and daydreamers. It's about turning 25 and not having your sh*t together.

A Working Title is visiting Manchester, Camden and Edinburgh Fringe this summer, but we need some help. 


What We Need & What You Get


We need to raise money to cover all the little things you need to spend money on to put on a show:
- Venue Hire
- Regestration Fee
- Rehearsal Room Hire
- Accommodation
These are our big outgoings and put us back a long way before the word profit can come into play. Profit means wages. Wages would be great!! 
In order to say Thank you for parting with your own hard earned cash we have put together some wonderful rewards. Please check these out!

The Impact
A Working Title was developed mostly by accident, growing from conversations between a motley collection of disillusioned twenty somethings, who all felt that everyone else in the world was much better at life than they were. 

We felt, at Original Impact, that much of the widespread upset and frustration we saw in our generation was down to the fact no one was talking about it. Everyone felt very much alone, which is easy as a young person in a big city. 

The trick, we thought, was letting everybody in on the big secret that, whatever your spotty sixteen year old self thought, no one ever really grows up. Even at the grand old age of twenty-five. Everyone is pretending (sometimes very convincingly) that they are real grown-ups who know what they’re doing, rather than letting on that they’re just making it up as they go along. 

And, being a theatre company, we made a show about it. 

Watching the reactions from the audience, it was very touching to see so many people leaving freer, happier and a little bit more content with their lot. In short they left knowing that it was all going to be ok, which is something we all need to hear sometimes. 

Your money, in helping us take our show to lots of different people, across the country, will help to spread that feeling, and hopefully make a bewildered and panicking generation just a bit happier. 

We couldn’t think of a better thing to invest in

Risks & Challenges

We are under no illusions about the fact that there are a lot of theatre companies out there, and there are a lot of things for people to go and watch, which does make our job a bit tricky. 

However, we have already proven, twice, that we can sell and, amazingly enough, sell out (and not just because our mums come every night). 

We think this is because we have a very clear audience. We know who they are, we can spot them in the street and be bang on with who will actually hang on to that flier. Anyone in their mid twenties, or anyone who remembers the pit falls of that age, we know will relate, and having a cracking night. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Come to the show!

Share this link!

Tell everyone about the show!

Seen the show? Liked it? Tell everyone you’ve ever met!

Tweet us at @originalimpact to tell us your #quaterlifecrisis stories!

See the show! All the info can be found at our website www.originalimpacttheatre.com

(Or, give us a bit of dollar, as any struggling twenty something knows, a spare fiver can go a long way)

story:
UPDATE: Goal Reached!!

THANK YOU to everyone who has already donated - we've reached our goal with over a HUNDRED individual contributions! We are humbled by all your generosity!

We still need support, of course. Any additional contributions at this stage go directly towards our set and compensation budgets, so don't be shy. Let's make RubberMatch as awesome as we possibly can!

What is RubberMatch?

RubberMatch is a new play by Paz Pardo. An O'Neill Semifinalist written while Paz was completing her Fulbright Scholarship in Buenos Aires, RubberMatch will be the first production presented by RED CARAVAN.

Ten years after tragedy drives a group of college friends apart, two are unexpectedly reunited: Ceci, fleeing a broken relationship, tries to find a new home by moving in with Nina. But when their attempts to reconnect uncover old wounds, Nina's repression is pitted against Ceci's self-destructive tendencies. RubberMatch asks: when can a friend's “help” become an act of violence?

Why This Play?

RED CARAVAN aims to tell relevant, human stories through accessible, high-quality theater. 

RubberMatch is an intimate look at a contemporary, complex female friendship; it’s thought-provoking, funny, and very real. We want to see more plays like this being produced, so we’re producing it!

Who Is Involved?

RED CARAVAN, in association with BootStrap Theater Foundation, presents RubberMatch:

Production Team

Playwright - Paz Pardo
Director - Andrew Willis-Woodward
Producers - Rosie Kolbo, Kara Ayn Napolitano, and Adam Wennick
Production Consultant - Sarah Matteucci
Scenic Design - Peiyi Wong
Lighting Design - Jason Fok
Property Design - Cherie A. Roberts

Cast

Ceci - Kayla Jackmon
Nina - Meredith Owens

Where Does Your (Tax-Deductible) Donation Go?

Producing theater ain’t easy. It takes so much more than a village. Your generous support helps us…

  • Pay for our theater space (theaters are very not-cheap)
  • Pay for rehearsal space
  • Build a realistic set that will help pull our audiences into the world of the play
  • Purchase insurance to keep our team protected
  • Create promotional materials to get the word out about the production
  • Pay our actors and designers for all of their hard work

What Do You Get?

If you donate to our campaign, not only will you be a part of the creation of new theater, you’ll also receive perks! Check them out ---------------->

Other Ways You Can Help

Like us on Facebook

Follow us on Twitter

Check out our Website

COME SEE THE SHOW - tickets go on sale early April!

story:
ABOUT US

The Puerto Rican Cultural Center (http://prfdance.org) is the only center in Texas and the Southwest affiliated with the Institute of Puerto Rican Culture for ongoing cultural programming that could not otherwise be experienced in this region. Founded in 1997 by Taino blood-descendant Dr. Ana María Tekina-eirú Maynard, the mission of our nonprofit 501(c)(3) is to promote cultural awareness and pride through educational programs, performances, and cultural events based in folklore, history and traditions -- dance, music, community theatre, and indigenous cultural traditions. Since 2001, our achievement and quality have been validated by repeat support by the National Endowment for the Arts, an NEA Chairman's Award (2007), the Texas Commission on the Arts, the City of Austin through the Cultural Arts Division, and Humanities Texas (since 2011).

ABOUT OUR PROJECT

Each year our performing company, Puerto Rican Folkloric Dance (PRFDance) preserves and transmits oral history researched among Island elders who remember a past that has never been written down. Through community theatre featuring live music and dance, our plays give the community a vibrant vehicle to better embrace, learn, and retain history.   

On December 3 & 4, 2016, Puerto Rican Folkloric Dance debuted our 14th bilingual play that shared the story of the first Boricua (Puerto Rican) Migration to Hawaii in 1900.  An original script based in oral and documented history, this play honored the brave men, women and children who went to Hawaii in search of a better life after Hurricane San Ciriaco devoured Puerto Rico in 1899.  

Recovery from Puerto Rico’s most destructive hurricane in history was not possible in any reasonable timeframe.  In a year’s time, 11 voyages would bring 5000 Boricuas to Hawaii, attracted by three year contracts to work the Hawaii sugar plantations.  Only 100 would ever return; those who remained  never forgot who they were -- Borinkis (of Boricua descent).

This original musical is the 14th bilingual play created by Dr. Ana Maria Tekina-eirú Maynard for PRFDance based in oral and documented history.  This year's play benefited from knowledge and memories shared by Jesus Reyes (Juncos, Puerto Rico), as well as Puerto Ricans living in Hawaii whose families were part of this history: Marian Montalbo and Kathy Marzan Montalbo (Hawai'i), and Clifford Pagan (Maui). 

MORE INFO ON MUSICAL:  https://www.facebook.com/events/160550427692660/


 

What We Need & What You Get

This production debuted on December 3-4, 2016 at Eastside Memorial Theatre in East Austin. Donations will subsidize production closing costs including (in priority order): tech crew, theatre and equipment rental (lights & sound).

The Impact

Since 2004 we annually bring to life oral and little-known documented history through soul-stirring application of acting, folklore, and cultural traditions. Each year this project transmits history and cultural heritage to our community at large through a creative folk life experiences.  Our goal is to instill cultural awareness and pride, and shine a positive light on this unique slice of Hispanic culture.

Community theatre provides a vibrant vehicle for the community to embrace, be inspired by, and more easily learn and retain history. Through this project, all ages will enjoy the memories of elders preserved through an original play featuring folkloric music and dance. Each year, elders in our local community enjoy our original plays and share their own surfaced memories of a history their families were once a part of. Others enjoy learning about -- comparing and contrasting -- a history of struggle and triumph that resonates with their own cultural history.  The new generation becomes interested in learning more about a history they never knew. This project is important because Puerto Rico's rich culture has contributed much to the Americas. Our projects bring deeper understanding of ethnic origins shared across Hispanic cultures, to all who enjoy learning about them.

Risks & Challenges

Funding is always a challenge in the arts community -- even more-so when serving a resource limited community.  Thankfully with generous donors, creative alternatives, and God's help, our 19 year history of high-quality artistic programming proves that we can succeed -- even in the toughest of times. We are grateful to those who help us be the "little engine that can" !!  

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot donate, we are grateful for your help to bring visibility to our mission. Share on social media --  those who appreciate the unique programming we bring to Central Texas may donate! In a world that is becoming more advanced everyday, there is nothing that replaces the power of personal recommendation from someone who appreciates what we do.    Thank you for helping us attract donors!

Thank you!  Jajom!  Gracias!

Funding is always a challenge in the arts community -- even more-so when serving a resource limited community.  Thankfully with generous donors, creative alternatives, and God's help, our 19 year history of high-quality artistic programming proves that we can succeed -- even in the toughest of times. We are grateful to those who help us be the "little engine that can" !!  

Other Ways You Can Help
If you cannot donate, we are grateful for your help to bring visibility to our mission. Share on social media --  those who appreciate the unique programming we bring to Central Texas may donate! In a world that is becoming more advanced everyday, there is nothing that replaces the power of personal recommendation from someone who appreciates what we do.    Thank you for helping us attract donors!
Thank you!  Jajom!  Gracias!

story:
What is RITUALS?

Life is a roller-coaster of emotions and events, no two lives are the same, but there are some experiences we can all share.

  • How do we celebrate? How do we mourn?
  • What can be told without words and what must be spoken out loud?
  • What is the line that connects us all, despite our circumstances?

 

What We Need & What You Get

Where is your money going?!

  • First things first, we want to PAY our ARTISTS
  • Rehearsal and Performance space, costumes and props
  • Aiding women producers to create new, meaningful theatre with the goal of developing a profitable company in the upcoming year

The Impact

Why is this project important to us? Why will it be important to you?

  • Rituals is loosely written piece, our actors will be creating the intimate life beyond the words
  • This is an all female led, written and produced project
  • Rituals effectively communicates life's intimate and private moments, through minimal dialogue and a through line of family and routine

Risks & Challenges

Although we are thrifty and creative artists, many of our needs will be fulfilled by our artists and producers. Despite this, we intend to take Rituals to an Off-Broadway house and Edinburgh Fringe by 2018.

  • One of our producers, Jordan Donohue, has successfully produced and written indie theatre earlier this year. The livestream and live audiences totaled over 500 viewers.
  • We need many props for this production, but with the help of our artists we can scavenge and recycle props from previous productions- which contributes to our need for creating sustainable theatre.

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't Donate? Spread the word! Donate Props!

  • Don't forget to share this campaign on social media ;)
  • If you have anything to donate to help reduce our environment impact, we will accept any prop donations.

And that's all there is to it.

story:
Short Summary

We are the Voyeur Theater Collective, an independent group started last year around the wild idea of creating performance events designed by our generation, for our generation. Theater in its undeniable beauty has unfortunately been overshadowed by the non-stop entertainment of a millennial’s life (i.e. smartphones, Facebook, video games, Netflix etc.) Our mission is to bring the attention of the current generation back to one of the oldest art forms. We will do this by integrating what is usually shunned from theater—phones, media, and video— into a show called about:blank. We hope to reach out to all millennials and get them interested in contemporary theater.

What We Need

The three biggest costs that we face in putting on this performance are renting out space for the event, design construction of our set, and obtaining a full sound system. These costs, along with costumes, props, promotional materials, and a few other small things comprise our total estimated budget of $5,000. We are starting from nothing, which means that we have less than two months to raise the capital that we need. Please help us achieve our dream of creating a life-changing performance!

The Impact

Our production will hopefully contribute to campus life by bridging the gaps between different social communities. All art can be experienced and discussed by its viewers, but live theatre is unique in that it physically brings people together for this exchange. VTC takes this notion a step further by bringing together a team of people with completely different worlds and mindsets within the Northwestern community. Bringing different mindsets together, and general inclusion, is essential to our mission because we believe the best learning that can be done is in a diverse environment. We hope to create a platform that will not only give the cognitive science and flute major the chance to meet, but also one that promotes discussion and exchange of ideas between them by presenting topics they can both relate to and speak knowledgeably about from their varying perspectives.

Additionally, VTC is now in it’s second year, and many of last year’s team members are now NU alumni, or students/alumni from other universities, who currently live and work in the greater Chicagoland area.  Though the production will be based at NU and primarily marketed to our community, the VTC community extends beyond our insular Evanston bubble. When members of last year’s team come back to support and engage with the work being created, they too are afforded the opportunity to share their unique views and responses, forging ties between NU students and a network of other artistically-inclined millennials in the area, making us more aware of our greater Chicago community and potentially opening NU students up to new opportunities.

Risks & Challenges

As a fledgling organization in just its second year, Voyeur Theatre Collective is not eligible to receive traditional funding from Northwestern University. This means that we must resort to alternative means of raising funds such as merchandise and bake sales. However, these methods only get us so far, and we really are relying on this Indiegogo page to be our primary source of funding.

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you cannot donate, please pass along our link to friends and family! Every single contribution gets us one step closer to being able to create our show!

story:
(日本語をご希望の方は、英文の下をご覧ください。)

We are a not-for-profit organization using dance and music to conduct cultural activities in New York City.  In 2012 we started a parents’ association to facilitate contact among Japanese parents who are raising their children in New York and who want those children to maintain contact with Japanese culture.  This issue is not only true for the Japanese, of course. In this country, where varied cultures and races come together, identity issues are common.  When we saw the innocent faces of the children at our parents’ meetings, we were strongly moved to introduce these children to their origins, a project that was within our reach.


(Photo from "Kaguya-Hime", 2014)

This was how this project was born. Since that time, we offer a yearly concert in which we use dance and music to present an ancient Japanese folktale.  We do not use any speech since not all the participating children are Japanese.  Many talented and thriving Japanese professional artists in New York perform in the show.  Though all the participating children will learn about Japanese culture, we hope that those who are of Japanese descent will feel a special resonance as they learn about their roots.

(Photo from "Kaguya-Hime" 2014)


This year, we presented “Urashima-Taro, A Fisherman’s Tale” in which a young fisherman saves a turtle from bullying children.  The turtle brings him to a dragon’s palace at the bottom of the ocean. In the beautiful, mysterious world of the deep sea, what does he see and experience? How does he think and act? And what happens to him?

Urashima Taro and Otohime, the Dragon Princess, were performed by magnificent ballet dancers. Turtle was performed by a fantastic hip-hop dancer/actor. And varied and talented dancers and singers supported the main characters.

(Urashima Taro Rehearsal - L-R Norihiro Maruta as the Turtle and Shogo Honda as Urashima Taro.)
(Urashima Taro, Rehearsal)

The show is consists of many forms of music and dance, as we produced the show for everybody to enjoy, no matter their origins.  Most of the artists and staff are volunteers. We do not create for money, but to express and share the best of ourselves. For us, creating something from nothing is the most joyful of experiences. We create this presentation to bring a shine to the children’s eyes when they see the story unfolding on stage.

We are trying to raise funds in all possible ways to make this project possible to continue. We wished use the money contributed for this production to invite as many children as possible as our guests. Although, we wished to gather enough money to make all seats, for children and for adults, free, unfortunately we could not achieve the goal before the presentation. Yet, many people came to see the show paying for it and had a great and moving time. And we wish to extend the show to everybody who could not come. If you donated more than $15, we will send you a video link of the show when it is ready. The donation is available from all over the world using your credit card. And your such contribution will make us to continue working on this project.

Please send your warm support and enjoy the show at your home with your family!

(Photo from "Kaguya-Hime" 2014)
SACRA! "Urashima Taro or A Fisherman's Story"
Performed: Sunday, June 21st.
Riverside Theatre, 490 Riverside Dr, New York, NY 10027

(Urashima Taro Rehearsal)

　私たちはニューヨークでダンスや音楽の文化活動を行う非営利団体です。2012年、私たちはニューヨークで子供を産み育てる日本人のために父母会を始めました。海外で子育てをする日本人の親たちの横の繋がりを作りたかったのです。集まった子供たちを見て、私たちはこの子たちが抱える宿命の一つに気づきました。この子たちは、アメリカの文化と言語の中で育つけれども、いつか自分が日本の血を引くことを意識して、自分が何者かを問う時がくるだろう、ということです。それはもちろん、日本人だけではありません。雑多な人種と文化が混然と同居するこの国で、誰もが抱くアイデンティティーイシューです。この子たちに心のふるさとを知らせるために、私たちに何ができるだろうと考えました。 

　こうしてこの企画、アーツキュア民話企画は生まれました。この企画では、日本に古くから伝わる民話をダンスと踊りで表現します。子供たちの両親は必ずしも日本人とは限りません。そのため、この舞台では全く台詞は使わないことにしました。ニューヨークで芸を磨き、活動する日本人アーティストが多く演じます。そして、ニューヨークで育つ子供たちも演じます。自らこの企画で演じながら、子供たちの心は物語の世界を泳ぐことでしょう。そして、自らの中に流れるルーツを知ってほしいと思います。

(Photo from "Kaguya-Hime" 2014)

　今年、私たちは「浦島太郎」を上演しました。亀を助けた心優しい漁師の浦島太郎は、その恩返しに亀に連れられ、竜宮城へ行きます。美しくも不思議な海中の世界。そこで太郎は何を見、何を経験したのでしょう？そして太郎は何を考え、どう行動したのでしょう？そして何が太郎に起こったのでしょう？

　浦島太郎と乙姫は素晴らしいバレエダンサーが、亀はパワフルなヒップホップダンサー件俳優が演じました。そして、この主役たちを様々なジャンルの実力あるダンサーや歌手が支えています。

(Urashima Taro Rehearsal)
 

　舞台は様々な音楽と踊りで構成されます。音楽やダンスは世界中に通用する共通伝達手段です。国境を越えて、誰もが楽しめる舞台に仕上がりました。出演するアーティストや製作するスタッフのほぼ全員がボランティアです。私たちはお金のために作品は作りません。自分の心の表現のために、そしてそれを人々と分け合うために作品を作ります。そして、そのためには自分の全てを注ぎます。私たちにとって、何もないところから形あるものを作ることはこの上もない喜びなのです。私たちは舞台の上に物語を展開させ、多くの子供たちの目を輝かせるために、この製作を実現させ続けたいと思います。



(Urashima Taro Rehearsal)

　しかし、舞台を実現させるためには、大変な費用がかかります。最低限の条件を満たす舞台にするために、私たちはあらゆる方法で資金を集めようとしています。ここに掲げる＄5,000という目標は、全席を無料にし、少しでも多くの子供たちを招待するためのものでした。しかし、残念ながら今年はこの目標を公演前に達成することはできませんでした。それでも多くの人たちが$15/席のチケット料金を払ってこの舞台を見に来てくれ、そして多くの感動を得て帰ってくれました。この舞台を見られなかった人は、決して手遅れではありません。もし、これからこのサイトで$15以上寄付してくださった方には、この公演のビデオリンクをお送りします。

　海外に住む子供たちに心のふるさとを見せてあげるために、是非皆様の暖かいご支援をお願い致します。ご自宅でリラックスして、ニューヨークで行われたこの公演を、ご家族でお楽しみください！


(Photo from "Kaguya-Hime" 2014)
SACRA! 「浦島太郎」
公演日：6月21日（日）午後4時半開演
会場：Riverside Theatre, 490 Riverside Dr, New York, NY 10027

story:
PIG, un petit cochon qui cherche sa maison

LA VIE DE PAUL EST COMPLIQUÉE : neuf ans, deux mamans, pas de papa, et l’irrépressible envie de devenir une Muse. Une chance qu’il y a Sunny, son baby-sitter, qui lui révèle le cinéma de Polanski et la beauté sublime de Sharon Tate. Une chance aussi que sa maman #2, Phoebe, lui a permis de se confectionner en cachette pour l’Halloween une merveilleuse robe de Muse ; alors que Claire, sa rêche maman #1, lui a imposé un costume de cochonnet. Or, le soir de l’Halloween, au moment où le cochonnet va se métamorphoser en Muse, Paul disparaît dans la nuit noire, laissant ses deux mamans dans un profond désarroi.

CETTE PIÈCE S'EST MÉRITÉE:

  • le cochon du peuple lors du Gala des Cochons d'or 2014 (Prix du public)
  • le cochon de l'acteur de l'année 2014 - Gabriel Szabo
  • le cochon de l'actrice de l'année 2014- ex equo entre Marie Charlebois et Violette Chauveau
  • nominations aux Cochons d'or 2014 pour la scénographie et les éclairages
  • nomination aux Prix de la critique 2013-2014

« Une ingénieuse recomposition des événements se déploie sous nos yeux, un chapelet d’indices et de motifs récurrents qui captive […]. Paré signe un spectacle drôle, poignant, mystérieux et même angoissant grâce aux éclairages et à la musique. La réussite est fondée sur la direction d’acteurs impeccable et une adroite utilisation de l’espace. » C. Saint-Pierre, Le Devoir.Les critiques et le public ont aimé, et nous en sommes bien heureux. Cependant, nous n'avons pas reçu les subventions espérées. PIG est une production coûteuse (cinq comédiens sur scène, une régisseuse et cinq concepteurs). Pour que tout le monde soit bien payé, nous avons besoin de 2500$. Cet argent -précieux, il va s'en dire- servira à assurer un salaire aux artisans de ce spectacle.  Des artisans talentueux, qui méritent d'être payés à la hauteur de leur talent et de leur implication.QUI SONT-ILS?

AUTEUR: Simon Boulerice

METTEUR EN SCÈNE: Gaétan Paré

COMÉDIENS: Marie Charlebois, Violette Chauveau, Karine Gonthier-Hyndman,Philippe Robert et Gabriel Szabo

RÉGIE ET ASSISTANCE À LA MISE EN SCÈNE: Alexandra Sutto

CONCEPTEURS: Clélia Brissaud, Marie-Aube St-Amand Duplessis, Estelle Charron , Sara Fauteux  et Gaétan Paré

DIRECTION DE PRODUCTION : Marilou Huberdeau

DIRECTION TECHNIQUE : Alexandre Paquet

VISUEL: Jean-François Poisson 


D'autres façons d'aider

Vous pouvez aussi, bien sûr, nous encourager en achetant des billets ici, sur le site du Théâtre Prospero:

http://www.theatreprospero.com/spectacle/pig-3/

THÉÂTRE PROSPERO
BILLETTERIE 514.526.6582 1371, RUE ONTARIO EST, MTL.

À noter aussi qu'Abat-Jour Théâtre organise une soirée de financement le 23 avril 2015. Pour cette représentation particulière, à 20 h 15, les billets seront au coût de 50$.  Nous vous remettrons une coupe de vin avant la représentation (dès 19 heures), en plus de vous offrir la possibilité d’échanger sur scène avec les comédiens et le metteur en scène, après la représentation. Nous ferons également tirer cinq exemplaires de la pièce publiée chez Leméac, signée par tous les artisans de ce spectacle. Pour vous procurer des billets de cette soirée unique, il suffit de passer, encore une fois, par la billetterie du Théâtre Prospero. Merci de nous encourager. Abat-Jour Théâtre vous en sera très reconnaissante.

Ne vous gênez pas pour passer le mot et faire de la publicité autour de notre projet. Merci de votre aide. Et merci, Indiegogo.
story_txt:
PIG, un petit cochon qui cherche sa maison
LA VIE DE PAUL EST COMPLIQUÉE : neuf ans, deux mamans, pas de papa, et 
l’irrépressible envie de devenir une Muse. Une chance qu’il y a Sunny, 
son baby-sitter, qui lui révèle le cinéma de Polanski et la beauté 
sublime de Sharon Tate. Une chance aussi que sa maman #2,
 Phoebe, lui a permis de se confectionner en cachette pour l’Halloween 
une merveilleuse robe de Muse ; alors que Claire, sa rêche maman #1,
 lui a imposé un costume de cochonnet. Or, le soir de l’Halloween, au 
moment où le cochonnet va se métamorphoser en Muse, Paul disparaît dans 
la nuit noire, laissant ses deux mamans dans un profond désarroi. 
CETTE PIÈCE S'EST MÉRITÉE:

le cochon du peuple lors du Gala des Cochons d'or 2014 (Prix du public)
le cochon de l'acteur de l'année 2014 - Gabriel Szabo
le cochon de l'actrice de l'année 2014- ex equo entre Marie Charlebois et Violette Chauveau
nominations aux Cochons d'or 2014 pour la scénographie et les éclairages 
nomination aux Prix de la critique 2013-2014


« Une
 ingénieuse recomposition des événements se déploie sous nos yeux, un 
chapelet d’indices et de motifs récurrents qui captive […]. Paré signe 
un spectacle drôle, poignant, mystérieux et même angoissant grâce aux 
éclairages et à la musique. La réussite est fondée sur la direction 
d’acteurs impeccable et une adroite utilisation de l’espace. » C. Saint-Pierre, Le Devoir.Les
 critiques et le public ont aimé, et nous en sommes bien heureux. 
Cependant, nous n'avons pas reçu les subventions espérées. PIG est une 
production coûteuse (cinq comédiens sur scène, une régisseuse et cinq 
concepteurs). Pour que tout le monde soit bien payé, nous avons besoin 
de 2500$. Cet argent -précieux, il va s'en dire- servira à assurer un 
salaire aux artisans de ce spectacle.  Des artisans talentueux, qui 
méritent d'être payés à la hauteur de leur talent et de leur 
implication.QUI SONT-ILS?

METTEUR EN SCÈNE: Gaétan Paré

story:
Ninjaz Of Drama is excited to be staging in the fall-winter San Francisco actor/playwright Rey Carolino's horror-comedy that combines the beloved folk tale and the popular zombie apocalypse genre and will be played at a venue in San Francisco's historic theater district. Ninjaz Of Drama, a proud company member of Theatre Bay Area, is a group of non-professional actors group based in San Francisco, CA, and has staged numerous productions of classical and contemporary works by both established and local playwrights. Their most recent productions were William Shakespeare's Romeo and Juliet, Spring 2014, and Vodka With A Dream Chaser by Rey Carolino, short romantic comedies, Winter 2014. Ninjaz Of Drama is one of many vibrant small theatre companies throughout the San Francisco Bay Area and enjoys the collaborations of actors, dancers, singers, musicians, designers, and technicians of all levels of experience and from all walks of life including college and high school students that engage in the mutual pursuit of imaginative, inclusive, and entertaining theater.

Please contribute whatever you can, however small the amount. We hope with your kind contributions we can acquire theatre rental, rehearsals, costumes, special make-up/masks, a stage manager, light-sound operator, publicity,  stage manager, light-sound operator, publicity, and event insurance. Your generosity is truly appreciated. 

If you aren't able  to contribute at this time, please, if you can, spread the word of this campaign to your friends.  We're hopeful the play can be the kind of unique theatrical event that people would love to see in December.

Thank you very much your kind consideration and for supporting the arts and little theater. 

*Poster designed by Jennifer Bowyer
