story:
About the Story

This is a story about a boy and a girl. It’s sometimes about a dog instead. There are words, and there’s music. I am trying to tell you something about sound. About making it, and about hearing it. About language and other auditory connections. I am trying to tell you something. I’d like you to listen.

I began Fundamental Frequencies in “Sound of Words,” a writing class that focused on the intersections between writing and music. The piece alternates between two different stories, united by the idea of auditory relationships, the role that sound and music plays in human interactions.

After a couple years of working on the story, I realized it needed more than words. To fully embody this story and its message, I needed to incorporate live performance and sound.


About the Show

Through Hybridge Arts Collective’s Blueprint Breakout Series, I’m creating a theater and music performance with the help of composer and musician Joo Won Park. Fundamental Frequencies will remind people that language isn’t everything. It’s not our only tool for communication. It’s not the only thing that matters. And it sure as hell isn’t as precise as you think.

As a writer, I believe that the meaning of a word depends on myriad factors. I believe word choice and even sounds matter as much as plot. Working on Fundamental Frequencies as part of the Blueprint Breakout Series will force me to defend that claim on new levels, to explore auditory relationships in a way that emphasizes sound beyond words.

It’ll also force me to think of an ungodly number of music puns until this is funded.


About Amelia Longo

Hi, I’m Amelia. I’m a writer and native Philadelphian. I’m fascinated by the way we value stories and by how we choose to craft them, and I enjoy playing with the boundaries between poetry and prose, truth and fiction, words on the page and out loud. I’ve studied writing at the University of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia Stories, the Greater Philadelphia Wordshop Studio, First Person Arts, and the Rutgers Camden Summer Writing Conference, and I once spent a year in Vienna studying an obscure Austrian writer. My work has been performed as part of the First Person Arts Festival (True Stories) and the SoLow Festival (So Cruel: a sibling serenade). Additionally, I work in the performance and writing communities outside of my personal creative work. My dance writing has been published on Thinking Dance, and I help publish other local writers with APIARY Literary Magazine. I’ve also worked with students at Mighty Writers, Mighty Post, and Camp Sojourner Girls’ Leadership Camp. You can check out my blog at viciousandmultiple.blogspot.com.


About the Money

Money can’t buy me love. But it can pay for artistic costs like fees for performers, a musician/composer, and outside eyes, production costs like lighting, set, and costumes, and marketing costs like a graphic designer, photographer, and videographer to get the word out there. This is the first time I’m committing to paying the folks I work with, and I’m pretty darn psyched about that.


Other Ways to Help

Want to support the show in non-monetary ways? You got it!

  • Come see the show (and shoot, bring a friend!)
  • Spread the word: tell your friends, share the facebook event, share this link, hang up posters in your local coffee shop, gush about me to strangers on the subway
  • Follow my blog: viciousandmultiple.blogspot.com
  • Volunteer at one of the performances by emailing info@hybridgearts.org.
  • Recommend a good story or album. I’m always looking for inspiration.

story:
My name is Alyssa LeClair.


I'm from Hamilton, Ontario, Canada. I'm 21 going on 22 and I'm headed off to NYU Steinhardt next year as a Masters of Music student and I'm trying to raise funds by doing a benefit show in Hamilton, Ontario on August 2nd.

My tuition is literal hell. There's no other way to describe it and I'm just coming out of undergrad and would love to lower my amount of crazy and unneccessary debt.

I can't begin to describe what your donations and support would do for me and my family. As a student who has found solace in theatre as a vehicle to express myself fully, it would be an unreal opportunity to get through my Masters with as little debt as possible.

 

What am I doing?

I'm hosting a benefit show on Friday, August 2nd, 2013 in Hamilton, Ontario.

My biggest problem?

Most of my friends and support system don't live near me and can't support me by coming to my one woman show.


The tickets are only $10, so that's all I could ever ask for.
But with the price of the venue, with the struggle to save money for the show, I'm asking you to donate to my cause on here! That way, you can leave guilt free knowing that you couldn't drive all the way down here but you helped me in the tiniest way possible!

 

If a donation is out of the Question HELP ME MAKE NOISE!

I'm not just any kid trying to capture a dream.
Steinhardt has a 25% acceptance rate, and only 17 students are accepted to my program, I am the youngest and I need your help!

If you can't donate, please share my story with people!
If I'm not forever in actual debt, I'll be forever in your debt.

story:
Our Story

Performing Tribute 9/11: Ordinary People, Remarkable Stories 

On September 11th I lost my cousin who worked for Cantor Fitzgerald in the North Tower.  In 2005 I began volunteering with the Tribute Center WTC visitor center. Tribute has a unique mission they call “person to person” history.  Every volunteer has a personal connection to 9/11 and we lead tours of the site, stopping to tell our personal stories during the tour.

It was volunteering with Tribute that gave me the idea of creating a piece of theatre that would weave together several stories of 9/11.  My concept for Performing Tribute has always been that the play would be performed by the actual people who experienced 9/11 and not by actors.  Performing Tribute presents the perspectives of 8 individuals who were separately yet directly impacted by the events of 9/11— family members who lost loved ones; survivors of the North and South Towers; an evacuated area resident; a retired FDNY firefighter who responded to the site, a New Jersey resident who volunteered in the aftermath with the Salvation Army and volunteers who helped in the rescue and recovery.  The individual experiences are told first-hand in a theatrical presentation that shares these unique and inspiring responses to 9/11. 

Performing Tribute was first produced by the Tribute Center in 2008 at Tribeca Performing Arts Center.  It has since been presented at a few Long Island High Schools and at the annual NY Fire Chief’s convention.

To commemorate the 10th anniversary of September 11th we have organized 5 free performances of Performing Tribute in New York City and New Jersey.   

The Impact

Everyone involved in Performing Tribute feels strongly that the stories of 9/11 must be told and that the 10th anniversary year is a unique opportunity for us to honor those we lost.  In addition to the five free performances we have organized in Manhattan and New Jersey we have also created a 30-minute version of the script that we are distributing, also free, to High Schools across the US to stage their own reading for the 10th anniversary.


"I really thought late, late that night on September 11 that my life was over.  But I hold in my heart a story my grandmother told me. Her youngest brother fought over in Germany in WWII, and he had a young wife at home and they had no children. He used to write her letters and in one of the last letters he wrote her, before he was killed in the war, he said if something happens to me, don’t let this war ruin two lives.  They took 2,750 lives at the World Trade Center that day but they didn’t take mine.  And I think it’s a credit to all those who died to make the most of this life." - Kate R., Performing Tribute


What We Need & What You Get

We have been given the theatre spaces for each production of Performing Tribute free of charge and the cast and crew are all donating their time.  We need funds to pay for the technical side of each production i.e. renting sound equipment, a video projector and a technical director.  The total amount we need is $2400.  We received a grant from the Lower Manhattan Cultural Council for $1000 in March so we are trying to raise $1,400 to meet our goal.  We thank you in advance for making a donation of any amount.  All donors will be listed on the Performing Tribute web site. 


Other Ways You Can Help

Please sign up for our newsletter at www.performingtribute.com

story:
the choreographer

Gillian

the dancers

Peter
Erik
Gina

the mission

Short term: 
March 2012: Perform work-in-progress at the Senior Showcase at Columbia University
April 2012: Perform 15 minute piece at festival of contemporary dance in Paris, 
April 2012: Perform piece again at studio presentation of Gillian's work.

Long term: 
Start a revolution in dance. Break down all the barriers between contemporary dance and people, across cultures and genres, spark an international arts dialogue beyond politics and cultural differences. Open dance back up to people. Communicate beyond language. Invent, create. Move beyond post-modernist arrogance and meaninglessness. It's time. 


the goal

Four round trip plane tickets JFK to Charles de Gaulle, by the end of February. 

why you care

Because you too have gone to a theater and watched strange, abstract movement, and thought, what happened to dance?

Because you too are hungering for meaning in the arts. 

Because you too think that young people don't care enough about dance and the arts. 

Because you too have thought about a dance piece, I don't get it. 

Because you know this is beyond just dance, but about dialogue, about passion, about creation, about reimagining and going for something better than what is. 


Because you want this revolution to happen just as much as we do, and by helping us live it, you make it happen. We cannot do it alone.

story:
One Youth Dance are a youth dance company based in islington who offer training opportunities to young people, aged 11-19, who may not otherwise have access to dance and the arts. 

The Pyjama Dance-a-thon is the first ever One Youth Dance Fundraiser! Over all we want to raise £3,000 in order to offer bursaries to 12 dancers who may not have the means to cover the cost themselves.  Our dancers have gained sponsors from their friends and family and we want to add a contribution to this by raising £500 online, which would cover 40% of two dancers fees for the year! 

On the 18th October, in partnership with Platform, we'll be challenging young dancers to complete a 12 hour dance marathon.  The day will be made up of amazing classes and workshops by some of the company's favourite teachers and alumni! 

The day is going to kick off our fundraising, towards the £3,000 target, with a bang - help us to offer weekly training and amazing performance opportunities to the young people who need it the most! 

Visit our website at www.onceyouthdance.com to find out more about the company and what we've been up to!

story:
JOAN: The Ballet 

A story of adventure and empowerment.

I'm Brigette Cormier, the choreographer and director of JOAN: The Ballet. Miami based professional dance artists and myself take on my original independent dancework JOAN: The Ballet in a soft premier performance at the RIFT Blackbox Theater Nov 1st & 2nd. I have been developing this 60 minute ballet since 2011, and recently through the Pioneer Winter Collective and Jared Sharon at the RIFT Black Box Theater, I was able to participate in a work exchange, teaching ballet & tap classes for children, for a discounted theater rental and a reduced rehearsal space rate for the soft premier. 

 Inspired by the Salem Witch Trials and Joan of Arc, & led by my passionate curiosity, JOAN: The ballet is a series of dances focusing on strength, perseverance, and forgiveness. Through the language of contemporary ballet and modern dance, a passionate story of friendship and awareness emerges bridging contemporary concepts with historic expressions.

The Details

We need to raise $1,800

As the creator of JOAN: The Ballet I understand that the funding needed to produce this independent work is coming from my pocket. With your help, I will provide a modest stipend to all the artists involved for their participation and time investment.  In addition, this is the Miami soft premiere of JOAN: The Ballet; Your contribution will help make this production a success. We hope to reach our goal and to, potentially, surpass it!

The Breakdown:

Compensation to the artists- $1,300

Costuming & Props- $300

Flyer/Postcards- $200

Additional funds after $1,800 will go towards our next performance of JOAN.

  • If you donate to our campaign your perks can include original autographed photos of the dancers in action, an invitation to view a sneak peak of JOAN in a rehearsal,  and tickets to our show!
  • If we don't reach our entire goal I will compensate out of my pocket.


Other Ways To Help

The greatest support we can receive is to have you seated in our audience.  Even if you are unable to contribute personally to Indiegogo, we hope that you will pass along this link.  Please share this campaign on Facebook, Twitter, or to friends via Email.  Most importantly, help us spread the word about JOAN: The Ballet and fill the house!  Tickets can be purchased here or at the link JOANtheBallet.eventbrite.com

JOAN: The Ballet 

November 1st at 8pm & Nov. 2nd at 2pm

at the RIFT Blackbox Theater

222 NE 25th St Suite 102 

Miami, FL 33137


The Impact

  • I feel my project is a valuable contributor to my community. Energy is contagious, and the message in JOAN: The Ballet is one of peace, unity, and equality for all, so I hope that this energy will resonate widely. When my dancers and I present this ballet, we hope that our vibration of love and change will cause a ripple effect of peace across the globe.
  • We've only had one other indiegogo campaign before, and it went great! I raised money to build dance studio/theater inside of a warehouse, and that's where I created the first half of JOAN: The Ballet.
  • Check out my multi/interdisciplinary website to see all of the endeavors I've been artistically exploring at www.LoveSteadyArts.com. Find more about my personal mission and career at www.BrigetteCormier.com.

Find more about my personal mission and career at www.BrigetteCormier.com.

story:
Take It Away Dance is a homegrown Philly percussive dance collective that is committed to presenting the most innovative tap and music projects in Philadelphia.   I am a tap dancer who grew up in Northeast Philadelphia, and Philadelphia is where I want to create, to perform, and to collaborate.  I am committed to creating and presenting forward-thinking choreography, commissions, collaborations and projects.

For the second year in a row, TIAD continues its mission of drawing attention to the bodies of work of world-renowned female tap choreographers.  In June 2014, TIAD presented the show "Meet Us At The Corner," which was partially supported by a grant from the Pennsylvania Council on the Arts.  This tap and music project celebrated the interdisciplinary work of Dorothy Wasserman, through the restaging and performance of two of her concert pieces.  You can read more about it here and also watch some videos from the show here.

This year's invited choreographer is Heather Cornell, the founder and artistic director of Manhattan Tap.  Over the course of six months, Heather will work closely with Philadelphia dancers and jazz musicians to restage her 1991 piece, (Tap) But Not For Me.  Heather will also lead two community master classes during the weekend of January 16, 2015.  The restaged piece will be performed June 6, 2015 at Cross-Rhythms, TIAD's annual concert show, which will be held at Levitt Hall, University of the Arts. 

We are thankful that this year's project is also partially funded by Pennsylvania Council on the Arts, but we need your show of support to see the project to a successful conclusion.  Your donation will be used to support dancer and choreographer rehearsal time, pay musicians and cover additional overhead costs. 

If you believe in continuing the relevance, power and necessity of tap dance as an American art form - specifically, in Philadelphia, which was once the tap capital of the world - then I hope you will consider donating whatever you can to this project.

story:
ITS SOOO SIMPLE

> YOU BUY A SET OF POI - for Balinese kids.

> WE TEACH THE KIDS HOW TO USE THEM


This is your chance to transform the life of a child in Bali by simply buying them one of the most incredible toys. 

We are dreaming up the world, as the beautiful playground that it is. A place where we feel safe to share our true hearts yearning for the freedom and spirit of play.

THE DREAM AWAKENING

This is our 4th year of coming to together as family, with the intention to co-create magic, harmony and transformation. In April 12 circus performers and clowns will be put together a colourful extravaganza for the local schools in BALI. We believe in change, and that inspiration is the road that leads us there. Come and play with us sometime! 

www.divineplayground.org

story:
Short Summary

Picture it. Four British actors in New York City, training at The American Academy of Dramatic Arts. They are Amy, Dave, Mai and Robb. When not taking classes, they're waiting tables, serving beers and flipping burgers. Like all actors, they want to tell their stories. David and Mai have an idea: let's found a theatre company dedicated to telling new, fresh, thought provoking and socially aware issues, and let's tell them in America and Britain. Amy and Robb agree. Welcome to The Peasants Club.

The company's first production, Moonfleece, by Philip Ridley, played to sold out houses Off-Broadway in 2013. Returning to the UK in 2014, the company commissioned the South London writing duo Chesper Harland and Charlie Wolf to write a new play looking at gender and housing in 21st century Britain. That play, You And Me And The Devil Makes Three opens at The Tea House Theatre, Vauxhall in July 2014.
 
YAMATDM3 is a play about three friends, living together since college, have their bohemian lifestyle shattered by the arrival of a baby. Chris, the father of the child, develops Couvade Syndrome during his partners pregnancy, which turns into full scale post natal depression after the baby's arrival. In the midst of this mess, the ever cheerful Lettie dispenses her unique sense of humor and copious amounts of alcohol whilst secretly being in love with Tig. The arrival of a beautiful Romanian model and her Tarot deck lays waste to the friendships and romance at the heart of this play and leads to a tragedy which none of the characters could have foreseen.

The Peasants Club are really excited about this play as it was written specifically for the company and really represents what the company is about.


What We Need & What You Get

Your support will help us in achieving the following goals:

  • Hiring the theatre to stage the play
  • Marketing the play; advertising, print distribution
  • Hiring rehearsal space
  • Once we have performed a run at The Tea House Theatre we would like to take the play to a larger fringe theatre in London. We have many contacts in theatre in New York and it is our hope to raise enough funds so that the show becomes self-funding and we are able to take our work across the pond! And perhaps around the world...

The Impact

We're holding a fundraiser at The Tea House Theatre on 7th June, we've enticed some extraordinary talent and worked around the clock to make this project happen. We're on a roll, but should we for any reason fall short of the full target, we will use what we raise to put on the play for three nights at The Tea House Theatre, therefore creating such a surge of interest that we can do it full justice later this year at a larger theatre.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can donate, then we are very grateful! Any donation, however little, helps. But if you can't you can still help us out!

  • Share! Link people to the campaign, our website and facebook page. Follow @thepeasantsclub on twitter. Stop people in the street and describe to them the brilliance of this project!

story:
Holladay is an adventurer, super mom and an awesome pole dancer! She is a professional pole performer  and has been training, teaching students and entertaining audiences for almost a decade. She is AFAA and Studio Soirée certified. As a theatrical pole dancer, she is known as an emotive powerhouse performer who will draw you in and keep you captivated with her graceful athletic style! 

She currently performs with Cloud City Circus in Portland OR and previously had performed at Sky Club. In the past few years she has performed at circus shows, EDM events, drag shows, festivals and pole dance showcases.  Specifically, she has performed at HOWL, White Out, Delirium, Halfway Home, Burning Man, Caravan Of Glam and Down the Rabbit Hole. 

As she continues to train and gain recognition as a performer,  she has been asked to perform in several venues without a safe pole apparatus available. The purpose of this campaign is to help Holladay purchase a safe portable pole apparatus (that includes shipping bags and a travel cart) that she can also use to teach students with. She also is seeking funds to help update her performance costuming and help with travel costs for continuing education. If her goal isn't reached, she still will put all funds towards the purchase of a portable pole. 
Please help Holladay reach her ultimate goal of owning her own safe portable performance apparatus! This would mean the world to her and every donation is greatly appreciated!
Thank You so much for your time reading this campaign story!

story:
We, the American Conservatory Theater's Graduate Acting Class of 2015 embark upon our biggest adventure yet...The MFA Showcase of 2015!

This Showcase will be the culmination of our three years of intensive actor training, and will allow us to perform for theater and film agents, managers, and casting directors in SF, NYC, and LA!

While A.C.T. is able to provide some support for our Showcase expenses, we rely on the generosity of our friends, family members and colleagues to help with the remaining costs.  

Your gift, no matter what the amount, will help us rent Showcase venues, produce publicity materials, and host industry professionals in each of these cities.

If you believe in our journey as artists, actors, creators and culture-keepers, we ask for your help as we take this next step into our professional careers by making a tax-deductible contribution to A.C.T. in support of our promising futures!

Help support the next generation of artists! 

What We Need:

We are aiming to raise $18,000 to cover:

  • Venue Rental: All the world's a stage...but we actually need to rent theaters.
  •  Publicity Materials: Nothing like a first impression! We need to introduce ourselves to Agents, Managers and Casting Directors via our Showcase Booklets!
  • Hosting Expenses: This is a rare opportunity for us to network with professionals in an informal setting. We will provide the space and refreshments for these events, so that the industry leaders can get to know us better, and we can get to know them better.  The best actor/agent relationships come out of natural professional chemistry, which is aided by events like these.
  • Travel Expenses:  If we exceed our goal, your donation can also help aid each of us individually in the form of a travel reimbursement. (Fingers crossed!) 

The Impact 

Members of our class have already made significant contributions to the artistic fields of theatre and acting. Your contribution will help us continue our work in the world. The Class of 2015 remains committed to:

  •  Award-Winning excellence in the Craft of Acting- Stefanee Martin and Rafael Jordan received recognition from the Theatre Bay Area with a Nominations for their work last summer in Sweet Maladies at Brava Theatre Center and American Buffalo  at Aurora Theatre, respectively; Joel Bernard was honored with the Joan Sadler Award for his consistency and professionalism while at A.C.T.
  • Education Ourtreach and Community Engagement- Dominique Salerno spearheaded a weekly Improv Initiative for underserved high school students and has launched a sustainable program for both current students and alumni; Josie Alvarez organized an annual residency at a local elementary school, E.R. Taylor.
  •  International Artistic Dialogue- Kemiyondo Coutinho took her one-woman show "Kawuna... You're It" to The South African National Arts Festival Grahamstown- one of the largest international festivals in the world- and created her own festival Nuvo in her hometown of Kampala, Uganda; Ben Quinn starred in Half: A Divorce Farce in the Rome Fringe Festival directed by Dominique Salerno.
  • Sharing Talents Nationwide- Glenn Stott was a featured lead in the Livermore Shakespeare Festival's Summer Repertory Season (Pride and Prejudice, Much Ado About Nothing); Danielle Frimer has worked multiple summers in Portland, Oregon with Post5 Theater Company  as a featured lead (Love's Labours Lost, Twelfth Night); Ryan Williams-French has worked as a featured lead in Chautaqua Theatre Company's Summer Residency, and will be touring A.C.T's production of Mr. Burns at The Guthrie Theater in Minneapolis. 

These are just a few of our past accomplishments, and your support can help us continue work like this... and much more!

Challenges

Being a professional actor means waking up everyday and putting your art first, wearing your heart on your sleeve, and making personal sacrifices to do what you love.  Financial support can be invaluable in providing a secure environment for creativity to flourish. Your patronage of our artistic paths can significantly diminish these challenges  and provide a springboard for our success.

    Other Ways You Can Help

    Even if you can't contribute financially, you make a huge impact on our campaign. Here's how:

    • Promote our campaign on social media: https://www.facebook.com/pages/ACT-MFA-Class-of...
    • Forward our emails to your friends and colleagues!

story:
NOUVEAU VIDEO !!
IL RESTENT SEULEMENT 5 JOURS !!



Production d’un programme double à la Rotonde les 27-28-29 novembre 2014 :

La compagnie ARIELLE ET SONIA présente sa première production en salle.  Ce programme double est composé des œuvres : Femmes-bustes des chorégraphes Jozef Frucek et Linda Kapetanea (Rootlessroot) de la Grèce et Les femmes de la Lune Rouge de la chorégraphe montréalaise Annie Gagnon.  

Interprétées par Arielle Warnke St-Pierre, Sonia Montminy et  Josué Beaucage, musicien en direct, les représentations auront lieu les 27-28-29 novembre 2014 à 20h00 à la salle Multi de Méduse et font partie de la programmation de la Rotonde, Centre chorégraphique contemporain de Québec. Egalement, Femmes-bustes fera l'objet d'une diffusion au Baumstrasse Studio, situé au cœur d’Athènes, à Votanikos en juin 2015.


Production of a double-program at la Rotonde November 27-28-29, 2014:
The recently formed company, Arielle et Sonia will present: Femmes-bustes choreographed by Jozef Frucek and Linda Kapetanea (Rootlessroot, Greece) and Les femmes de la Lune Rouge, choreographed by Annie Gagnon (Montreal).

Interpreted by Arielle Warnke St-Pierre, Sonia Montminy and Josué Beaucage, musician live, the performances, programmed by La Rotonde, centre chorégraphique contemporaine de Québec, will take place on 27-28-29 November 2014 at 8pm at la salle Multi de Méduse in Quebec City.Femmes-bustes will also be presented at the Baumstrasse Studio, located in the heart of Athens, Greece in June 2015.

Pourquoi un support de la communauté?
La solidarité et l’entraide sont des valeurs sociales que nous avons à cœur. Nous croyons au pouvoir du nombre. Cette plateforme représente pour nous une façon concrète d’associer nos proches à notre projet, qu’ils en connaissent davantage les détails et les fondements et qu’ils puissent par le fait même profiter d’une fenêtre sur notre profession.  

Parce que nous souhaitons vous remercier d'une façon singulière, chaque don sera accompagné d'un cadeau-pensée symbolique inspiré de notre production. Vous trouverez les descriptions ci-contre.

Why solicit community support?
Solidarity and self help are central to our vision. We believe in the power of numbers. This fundraising platform is a concrete way for us to connect our project to people, to share our creative process and offer an intimate glimpse of our profession.

It is important for us to thank every donor. Each contributor will receive a special gift inspired from our production. (See descriptions in English at the bottom)

Budget:
Grâce au précieux support de plusieurs partenaires, nous avons réuni plus de 90% de notre budget global (65 000$). Nous avons besoin d'un dernier coup de main! 

7000$ ! Il ne reste que ce dernier montant à amasser! 

Nous faisons appel à vous maitenant pour y prendre part!

** Et si nous dépassions notre objectif! Cet argent sera investi dans la promotion et la diffusion du spectacle ainsi que dans les productions à venir. Il y a tant de projets en incubation, nous saurons en faire bon usage! **


Budget:
Through the generous support of many partners, we have gathered more than 90% of our overall budget ($ 65,000).

There remains only $ 7,000 to raise!

We appeal to you to be a part of this project!

** If we exceed our goal! the excess money will be invested in tools to promote the show and will also be invested in future productions. We have scheduled numerous projects, we will make good use of your contribution! **

Biographies :

SONIA : Je suis interprète en danse contemporaine depuis plus de dix ans. Ce qui m’inspire le plus c’est la rencontre avec l’univers créatif des chorégraphes avec qui je travaille. J’ai envie de me laisser porter par leur vision et d’arriver à l’incarner par ma danse. Ces rencontres sont pour moi très précieuses et elles font partie intégrante de mon cheminement artistique et personnel. En bref, j’essaie d’évoluer physiquement et psychologiquement en étant une meilleure personne jour après jour.  J’adore également les sensations physiques fortes, ce qui explique mon intérêt pour le travail de harnais acrobatique qui me fait justement sentir vivante et fougueuse.  Je me nourris aussi par mon travail de répétitrice, qui me permet également de peaufiner mon art par l’observation et l’aspect critique de ce travail.

ARIELLE : J’évolue au sein de la communauté de la danse à Québec depuis plus d’une dizaine d’années. À travers mes expériences comme danseuse-interprète et également comme chorégraphe et enseignante, j’ai cultivé une passion viscérale à creuser au fond de moi-même pour nourrir ma danse. Mon parcours en mouvement est intrinsèquement lié à mon évolution comme femme sur cette terre. Ils se nourrissent l’un de l’autre et tendent vers l’intention d’être le plus en connexion possible avec le monde qui m’entoure.  D’un point de vu organisationnel, je mets beaucoup de cœur à prendre part à l’émancipation de la danse dans ma communauté, notamment à travers l’organisme L’Artère, développement et perfectionnement en danse contemporaine.

COMPAGNIE :Arielle et Sonia nous permet d’imaginer des contextes précieux de rencontres. Assister à l’émergence de l’œuvre chorégraphique qui nait de la réaction des chorégraphes et collaborateurs invités face aux espaces choisis est un pur bonheur. Nous sommes fières de proposer le premier spectacle en salle de la compagnie.  Toutes les œuvres précédentes ont été créées et présentées au Musée de la civilisation dans diverses expositions.  Le but premier était de pouvoir s’inspirer d’un terreau artistique déjà existant et d’en proposer une lecture différente. Désormais, les horizons s’élargissent pour nous et nous permettent des rencontres artistiques d’une grande richesse avec divers artistes et notre communauté. Ce projet nous permet de créer un pont entre l'espace muséal et un espace dédié à la danse.

THE COMPANY: Arielle et Sonia is a context that allows us to construct our own singular creative universe. Our creative process is fueled by the feedback from the participating choreographers and collaborators invited to meet each other and confront selected  themes. All our previous creations have been presented at Le Musée de la Civilisation (Quebec) during various thematic exhibitions. Our first goal was to be able to draw on an existing artistic ground and propose a different reading of it through dance. Femmes-bustes and Les femmes de la Lune Rouge  is our first production as a company and we are proud to present it in a theatre. This project allows us to create a bridge between the museum space and a space dedicated to dance.

L'equipe:

Chorégraphes : Jozef Frucek et Linda Kapetanea de Rootlessroot (Grèce) , Annie Gagnon (Montréal)
Interprètes : Sonia Montminy, Arielle Warnke St-Pierre, Josué Beaucage
Concepteur musical: Josué Beaucage
Répétitrice: Annie Gagnon (Montréal)
Artiste visuelle : Valérie Potvin
Conceptrice des costumes : Julie Levesque
Concepteur d'éclairage : François Marceau

Vous souhaitez nous aider d'une autre façon :
1. Venir voir les représentations les 27, 28, 29 novembre, 2014 à 20h00
Salle Multi de Méduse : 541, rue Saint-Vallier Est, Québec, QC

2. Acheter votre carte-repas (45$ taxes incluses) pour notre soirée de financement au restaurant Le Mezzé, le 12 novembre 2014 à 18h30!
Contactez sonia_bailar@hotmail.com ou ariellewarnke@yahoo.ca

3. Obtenez un espace-publicitaire dans le programme du spectacle!

Contactez sonia_bailar@hotmail.com ou ariellewarnke@yahoo.ca

POUR PLUS D'INFORMATION: http://www.larotonde.qc.ca/spectacle/femmes-bustes-les-femmes-de-la-lune-rouge/



Productions Recto-Verso + Le Musée de la civilisation + Le Conseil de la culture des régions de Québec et Chaudière-Appalaches + L’Artère, développement et perfectionnement en danse contemporaine + David Pressault Danse / Transformation + Caisse d’économie solidaire Desjardins de Québec


---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Gift Descriptions:
$ 10 CAD / POSTER
Poster autographed by the performing artists
$ 20 CAD / WISH
In Greece, we will whisper a wish of your choice in the ear of a statue!
$ 35 CAD / THE MOON
Arielle et Sonia photographed howling at the moon!
$ 50 CAD / THE EARTH
Planting your special wish in the sands of a Greek island!
$ 75 CAD / EARTH + MEMORIES
Planting your special wish in the sands of a Greek island! + Some memorable photos of our show
$ 100 CAD / THE SCREAM
Video-capture of a scream of your name into a hand-dug hole in Quebec earth or Greek sand (your choice)!
$ 300 CAD / CONVICTION
Video-capture of a text of your choice recited (with great conviction!) in a location of your choice! On top of a mountain / On a Greek island / In the middle of a stream
$ 500 CAD / OLIVE OIL
Mason jar filled with cold pressed olive oil from Jozef and Linda’s olive groves!
$1,000 CAD / FULL MOON + OIL
Video-capture of an excerpt from Les femmes de la Lune Rouge danced under the full moon + Mason jar filled with cold pressed olive oil from Jozef and Linda’s olive groves!
$ 2,000 CAD / MEGA THANKS
Video-capture of an excerpt from Les femmes de la Lune Rouge danced under the full moon + Meditation by Arielle and Sonia for 30 minutes, guided by an intention of your choice + Some memorable photos of our show + Poster autographed by the performing artists
story_txt:
NOUVEAU VIDEO !! IL RESTENT SEULEMENT 5 JOURS !!Production d’un programme double à la Rotonde les 27-28-29 novembre 2014 :La compagnie ARIELLE ET SONIA présente sa première production en salle.  Ce programme double est composé des œuvres : Femmes-bustes des chorégraphes Jozef Frucek et Linda Kapetanea (Rootlessroot) de la Grèce et Les femmes de la Lune Rouge de la chorégraphe montréalaise Annie Gagnon.  Interprétées par Arielle Warnke St-Pierre, Sonia Montminy et  Josué Beaucage, musicien en direct, les représentations auront lieu les 27-28-29 novembre 2014 à 20h00 à la salle Multi de Méduse et font partie de la programmation de la Rotonde, Centre chorégraphique contemporain de Québec. Egalement, Femmes-bustes fera l'objet d'une diffusion au Baumstrasse Studio, situé au cœur d’Athènes, à Votanikos en juin 2015.Production of a double-program at la Rotonde November 27-28-29, 2014:The recently formed company, Arielle et Sonia will present: Femmes-bustes choreographed by Jozef Frucek and Linda Kapetanea (Rootlessroot, Greece) and Les femmes de la Lune Rouge, choreographed by Annie Gagnon (Montreal).Interpreted
 by Arielle Warnke St-Pierre, Sonia Montminy and Josué Beaucage, 
musician live, the performances, programmed by La Rotonde, centre 
chorégraphique contemporaine de Québec, will take place on 27-28-29 
November 2014 at 8pm at la salle Multi de Méduse in Quebec City.Femmes-bustes will also be presented at the Baumstrasse Studio, located in the heart of Athens, Greece in June 2015.Pourquoi un support de la communauté?La solidarité et l’entraide sont des valeurs sociales que nous avons à cœur. Nous croyons au pouvoir du nombre. Cette plateforme représente pour nous une façon concrète d’associer nos proches à notre projet, qu’ils en connaissent davantage les détails et les fondements et qu’ils puissent par le fait même profiter d’une fenêtre sur notre profession.  
Parce que nous souhaitons vous remercier d'une façon singulière, chaque don sera accompagné d'un cadeau-pensée symbolique inspiré de notre production. Vous trouverez les descriptions ci-contre.Why solicit community support?Solidarity and self help are 
central to our vision. We believe in the power of numbers. This 
fundraising platform is a concrete way for us to connect our project to 
people, to share our creative process and offer an intimate glimpse of 
our profession.It is important for us to thank every donor. Each
 contributor will receive a special gift inspired from our production. 
(See descriptions in English at the bottom)






Budget:Grâce au précieux support de plusieurs partenaires, nous avons réuni plus de 90% de notre budget global (65 000$). Nous avons besoin d'un dernier coup de main! 
7000$ ! Il ne reste que ce dernier montant à amasser! 
Nous faisons appel à vous maitenant pour y prendre part!
** Et si nous dépassions notre objectif! Cet argent sera investi dans la promotion et la diffusion du spectacle ainsi que dans les productions à venir. Il y a tant de projets en incubation, nous saurons en faire bon usage! **


Budget:Through the generous support of many partners, we have gathered more than 90% of our overall budget ($ 65,000). There remains only $ 7,000 to raise!We appeal to you to be a part of this project!**
 If we exceed our goal! the excess money will be invested in tools to 
promote the show and will also be invested in future productions. We 
have scheduled numerous projects, we will make good use of your 
contribution! **

story:
Video conceived by Regina Vorria; footage by Michael Economou, Kelly Foskolou, Nadia Foskolou, Aaron Minerbrook, Regina Vorria; editing by Alexandra Verykokkou; music by Erato A. Kremmyda


What is Hôtel Méditerranée?

Hôtel Méditerranée is a new theatre piece adapted and directed by Nadia Foskolou that will make its world premiere at Between the Seas Festival 2014. 

Performance dates: July 21 at 8pm & July 26 at 8:30pm

at The Wild Project / New York

Hôtel Méditerranée  is a collage of live performance and video based on two source materials: the play Matisse’s Self Portrait by the avant-garde American playwright Charles Mee, and the Greek film documentary Yiannis Moralis by Stelios Charalambopoulos. It follows the lives of two renowned painters—a fictional Henri Matisse and the real Yiannis Moralis—and explores the angsts and pleasures behind all great creativity, and behind all human existence by investigating the negotiation of creative process and the everyday need to make a living.


Production team & Cast

Adapted and directed by Nadia Foskolou

Produced by Regina Vorria Set Design Mikaela Liakata Lighting Design Drew Florida Costume Design Kristin Isola Music/Sound Design/Music Direction Erato A. Kremmyda Lyrics Maggie-Kate Coleman Projection Design Aaron Minerbrook Production Stage Manager Liz Nielsen

Performed by a bilingual cast in English and Greek with English supertitles: Fotis Batzas, Kristina Siapkara, Kalliopi Tzermani, Nathan Wright, Tina Yotopoulou 

A co-production with Between the Seas Festival


What We Need & What You Get

We need to raise $3,500 to cover the bare minimum production costs. ANY donation amount would help. 

Even though the festival provides us with many tangible means of support–performance space, basic marketing and publicity, some technical assistance–we are still responsible for many other aspects of the production. 

Here's what we plan to do with your money:

  • Pay people: some of our designers, performers, including the director, have traveled all the way from Greece on their own expenses just to do this show. The least we can do is offer our team a small fee for their hard work and commitment. Total fees: $1,900
  • Pay for production expenses: The piece is minimal with heightened physicality and playfulness.  We still need to acquire some set pieces, costumes and some extra sound, projection equipment. Total production expenses: $1,600 
Rest assured you will receive our infinite gratitude for supporting us. 


What's the risk?

By the time we found out we were accepted to the festival, most grant deadlines had passed by and we found ourselves with very restrictive sources of income. Still, we decided to embrace the challenge and go for it.  And, well. Here we are.

How do you pronounce Hôtel Méditerranée?

You didn't take French in school? Guess what. Neither did we. Here's your two-word French survival guide:

Hôtel (hotel): http://abt.cm/1smXAMq

Méditerranée (mediterranean) http://bit.ly/1i9fyOn


Did anyone say side project?

Hôtel Méditerranée has been running an ongoing side project.

I AM AN ARTIST is part video blog, part social [media] experiment. We invite all artists of any discipline and from all over the world to film themselves on a smart device while responding to the following question: What is your greatest fear/anxiety right now?  

The goal is to create a public forum where artists can share their angsts, investigate how fear and anxiety is interpreted by each individual, and eventually explore if and how the various responses deviate, or not, from our overall anxieties as human beings.  See videos & participation guidelines here: iamanartist-blog.tumblr.com


Other Ways You Can Help

You can share this campaign on your social media and/or you can come to see the show. This would still mean the world to us.

story:
The Unfortunates is back after the incredibly successful world premiere last year!

About The Unfortunates

A one-woman play written by Aoise Startford, based on the provocative, poignant, true story of Mary Jane Kelly, Jack the Ripper's final victim. Mary walks into the Ten Bells pub, looking to sell her last possession. Instead of finding a bar full of regulars, there is only one lone stranger. Will he buy what she's selling, ensuring her safety? Or will he turn out to be Jack the Ripper…

 

The World Premiere

Three years ago, The Unfortunates was presented as a staged reading in the Women Playwrights Festival at Centenary Stage Company. Winning the festival gave The Unfortunates its world premiere in 2012. I had the pleasure of being that one woman in both the reading and the premiere. From the moment I read the play, I was drawn to the incredible story. The victims of Jack the Ripper were marginalized, sensationalized, or ignored women.   As Janine M. Torsiello of Morrisbeats noted in her review: "...A woman in the audience thanked the playwright, Aoise Stratford, for giving the women who were the Ripper's victims back their lives. Indeed she did that very well, and because of that, this is a production not to be missed."

 

Who We Are

Aoise Stratford, international-award winning Playwright. Aoise's work has been produced in Canada, Austria, Italy, Australia, Belgium, England, and throughout the USA. She is a member and regional representative of the Dramatists Guild and her work has been published by Smith and Kraus, JAC, United Stages and Merriweather Press.

David M. Kaplan, Production Coordinator / Producer @ Vertical Tasting Productions. With his MFA in Techincal Direction from Florida State University, David has been a Technical Director at theaters large and small, as well as universities. Most recently, he was the Technical Director at Kean University and Premiere Stages.

Diana Cherkas, Actor / Producer @ Vertical Tasting Productions. Besides Mary Jane, Diana has originated roles in half a dozen shows regionally, and also works in film and webseries. Her recent feature My Little Demon will be available on Video on Demand in summer 2013. For more info, visit www.dianacherkas.com

Ryan Whinnem, Director. Ryan is the Artistic Director of Vacant Lot Theatre. He also founded The Mobtown Players and ran it for eight years in Baltimore before receiving his MFA from Catholic University in 2009.  

 

What We Need & What You Get

FringeNYC handles the venue costs, and Centenary Stage Company is lending Mary Jane her costume (thank you very much!), but we still need to recreate the Ten Bells pub at its most desolate:

  • We need to build a new bar to fit the new venue, because what's a pub without a bar? Also stools, tables, chairs, liquor bottles, glasses...
  • The eerie sounds of the abandoned bar don't just happen--we need a fabulous sound designer to make them happen

And then there are fees associated with the FringeNYC itself:

  • participation fees
  • insurance

The Unfortunuates will be an amazing production, but people need to hear about it! So there's marketing. New York is a big theater town, and the FringeNYC is a big festival, so it takes a good marketing campaign to stand out, including:

  • Print ad in the FringeNYC program
  • Online listings
  • A publicist to help bring in reviewers and media coverage

There are some very cool perks available, including limited edition items to be used in the FringeNYC run of the show. Check out the individual donation levels for the associated perks. Thanks to Fractured Atlas, this production is non-profit, so all donations are tax deductible.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute right now, that's ok. You can also help us out by sharing the campaign with friends via email, by posting the campaign to your facebook or twitter. If you know of any reviewers, bloggers, podcasters or arts' writers looking for a story, send them our way.

Then come see the show! For more info about dates, showtimes, tickets, and press, visit Vertical Tasting Productions.

Most recently, he was the Technical Director at Kean University and Premiere Stages.
Diana Cherkas, Actor / Producer @ Vertical Tasting Productions. Besides Mary Jane, Diana has originated roles in half a dozen shows regionally, and also works in film and webseries. Her recent feature My Little Demon will be available on Video on Demand in summer 2013. For more info, visit www.dianacherkas.com
Ryan Whinnem, Director. Ryan is the Artistic Director of Vacant Lot Theatre. He also founded The Mobtown Players and ran it for eight years in Baltimore before receiving his MFA from Catholic University in 2009.  
 


What We Need & What You Get
FringeNYC handles the venue costs, and Centenary Stage Company is lending Mary Jane her costume (thank you very much!), but we still need to recreate the Ten Bells pub at its most desolate:

We need to build a new bar to fit the new venue, because what's a pub without a bar? Also stools, tables, chairs, liquor bottles, glasses...
The eerie sounds of the abandoned bar don't just happen--we need a fabulous sound designer to make them happen

And then there are fees associated with the FringeNYC itself:

participation fees
insurance

The Unfortunuates will be an amazing production, but people need to hear about it! So there's marketing. New York is a big theater town, and the FringeNYC is a big festival, so it takes a good marketing campaign to stand out, including:

Print ad in the FringeNYC program
Online listings
A publicist to help bring in reviewers and media coverage

There are some very cool perks available, including limited edition items to be used in the FringeNYC run of the show. Check out the individual donation levels for the associated perks. Thanks to Fractured Atlas, this production is non-profit, so all donations are tax deductible.
Other Ways You Can Help


If you can't contribute right now, that's ok. You can also help us out by sharing the campaign with friends via email, by posting the campaign to your facebook or twitter. If you know of any reviewers, bloggers, podcasters or arts' writers looking for a story, send them our way.
Then come see the show! For more info about dates, showtimes, tickets, and press, visit Vertical Tasting Productions.

story:
Dig Infinity!

Dig Infinity! is a stage play celebrating the legacy of Lord Buckley (1906-1960), a nearly forgotten jazz comedian, visionary storyteller/philosopher, hipster saint and premier beatnik rapper. Lord Buckley was best known for transforming Bible stories, Shakespeare soliloquies, the Classics, myth, legend and history into one-of-a-kind hip-talk monologues combining African-American street argot and the King’s English into a jazzy patois and worldview that anticipated psychedelia and rap by decades. "Jonah & The Whale," "The Hip Gahn," "Scrooge," "Hipsters, Flipsters & Finger-Poppin' Daddies," and "The Nazz" are just a few of his hallmark monologues that are the stuff of bohemian fable.

Dig Infinity! transpires in a surreal radio station where, on the midnight after his death, Lord Buckley spins out his life story to a DJ named Orpheus while demonstrating his signature material. As the two talk, a dialogue interspersed with flashbacks to various points in Lord Buckley's life, the conversation shifts into a discussion about the importance of truth and art, a topic which includes a trip to Hades and a cameo by God as it becomes increasingly apparent that Lord Buckley is bargaining for his very soul.

Lord Buckley’s life and art remain so resonantly timely and why each new generation seems to rediscover and revere his legacy are the ways in which it confronts and comments on controversial components of contemporary American life: religion, language, art, sex, drugs, and race. Yet despite being a secret subterranean hero to the likes of Bob Dylan, the Beatles, Grateful Dead, Robin Williams, Bill T. Jones, Ken Kesey, Joni Mitchell, Tom Waits, Julie Taymor, George Carlin, Whoopi Goldberg, James Taylor, Roseanne, Jimmy Buffett, Joan Baez and scores of others, Buckley's achievement has remained tragically overlooked.

As Lord Buckley's biographer (Dig Infinity! The Life & Art of Lord Buckley/Welcome Rain Publishers, 2002) and a keeper of the flame, I have shared His Lordship's work in a variety of settings and media for more than two decades.

I have assembled a dedicated and talented circle of actors, musicians, videographers and crew who have thus far worked for the love of the project. Foremost amongst these are Russell Jordan (http://www.russelljordan.com/) playing the role of Orpheus and John Kruth leading the band. Russell has was named Outstanding Actor in a Staged Reading at last year's Festivity and has distinguished himself in a number of productions over the past few years. John is a founding member of the transcendent World Beat jazz band Tribecastan (http://tribecastan.tv/) that has performed frequently in and around NYC and toured both Europe and the West Coast. Rounding out our humble cast is multi-threat actor David Lamberton (http://www.davidlamberton.com) and ace drummer Boris Kinberg.

In addition to compensating my cast and crew for their time and efforts ($2500), I will need to rent rehearsal space ($300) and projection equipment ($100), print scripts ($30), pay a festival entrance fee ($250), and hire a PR outfit ($800) all in service in presenting the play in the most compelling and transformative manner possible. Many of you came through last year when we presented a staged reading of Dig Infinity! but, with three full productions slated for this year's fest, the costs (and stakes!) have risen.

Your generosity will ensure a top shelf production and help spread a bit of Buckley's gospel -- a vision of a better world!

We are all proud that Dig Infinity! has been selected to be presented at this year's Planet Connections Festivity -- NYC's premier eco-friendly/socially-conscious arts festival. Fostering a diverse cross-section of performances, the Festivity seeks to inspire artists and audiences both creatively and fundamentally, in a festive atmosphere. At the heart of the Festivity are like-minded individuals striving to create professional, meaningful theatre, film, music and art while supporting organizations which give back to the community at large.

To purchase tickets: https://web.ovationtix.com/trs/pr/933370

To give you an idea of how we have handled the material, this cool review of our first staged reading should give you a notion of what we have conjured:  http://hannahmenziesblog.wordpress.com/2012/11/06/dig-infinity-lord-buckley-gets-mythical-at-the-indian-cafe/


Cast
Oliver Trager … Lord Buckley

Russell Jordan… Orpheus

David Lamberton… Abe, God, Midas, Worm

John Kruth… Jazzbo, Shadow and strings/flutes

Boris Kinberg… Slick and percussion

Eric Feldman… Lights & Sound


Other Ways You Can Help

We welcome your contribution, no matter its form.

If you’re unable to contribute financially, you can help by spreading the word about Dig Infinity! to as many friends and family as possible.

You can:

  • Copy and paste this content into an email and send it to your email list

  • Share our campaign link on Facebook, Twitter, Google+, etc.

  • Come see Dig Infinity! in New York City @ Paradise Factory Downstairs Theatre 64 E. 4th St.

    Wednesday May 14th @ 6.30pm

    Sunday May 18th @ 9:00pm

    Saturday May 24th @ 7:30pm


Photo: Ray Avery (Courtesy of CTS Images)/Collage: Peter Stetler

Video/Photography: Stephen Adler

story:
Who am I am why do I need you?

Aren James Hooper, Alumni of UNM's department of Theatre and Dance is coming back fall of 2013 to set a new work in the alumni show. 

After graduating Mr. Hooper moved to NYC and has since danced with two active professional companies and done many projects throught the dance community including starting his own not for profit dance company--DOTA Dance Theatre. 

Aren will return to New Mexico in the fall to set a work for the Friends of Dance Alumni show with a cast of incredible movers from the community. This Indie gogo campaign will raise funds to fully support the creation of this work! Thank you. 

 

--Aren James Hooper

 

What:

So here is the deal. Without funding the show will still go on, BUT (there is always a catch) if we don't make this funding goal the dancers will not be paid (ARTISTS NEED TO EAT TOO), props will be non existent, AND they MAY be dancing naked. Basically, all of the funding from this indiegogo will support the wonderful work of my dancers in New Mexico. Without their time and energy this work would not be a success

Why:

The purpose of any work created by DOTA Dance Theatre is to expand appreciation for the arts, specifically the marraige of film and concert dance, and this work follows suit. This work will be produced for an alumni show at the University of New Mexico in association with the Friends of Dance organization and will bring together dancers from the community to showcase a multimedia dance experience available to the community (and later online at www.dotadancetheatre.com)

Are you broke too?

If you can't support with financial help (even a dollar helps!) then please spread the word to friends and family!

story:
AN AGONIZING DILEMMA

“What the hell am I going to do?” The military draft during the Vietnam War created an agonizing dilemma for millions of young Americans. And the choices they made changed their lives forever.

The Draft  is a stage play that dramatizes the compelling real-life stories of ten of those young people. They're drawn from Tom Weiner's book "Called To Serve, Stories of Men and Women Confronted by the Vietnam War Draft".

George, Al, and John accepted the call to serve, saw combat in Vietnam, and struggled with post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) and societal rejection after their return home. Tom won conscientious objector status and organized for civil rights and against the war. Randy resisted and went to jail. Jay chose self-exile in Canada. Roger was prepared to leave the country, too, but the draft ended before he was called up; he was active in a college anti-war group. Frank got a medical deferment with a fake x-ray provided by his family doctor and became a draft counselor. Diane was a campus anti-war leader and counseled traumatized veterans. Penny worked as a nurse at a U.S. military hospital in Vietnam, and saw the horrors of war in the maimed and dying young people she cared for.  

POWERFUL STORIES -- RIVETING THEATER

In The Draft, the testimonials of these young people – all played by actors of draft age – are interwoven with music, archival photos, video clips, and poetry. Together, they give voice to the passion, the anguish, the joy, the inspiration, and the intense personal and collective struggles of a generation. And they make for riveting theater – as we happily learned at the first staged reading of the piece at Smith College in Northampton, MA.

We’re eager to share The Draft with audiences across the country, particularly with younger people of college and high-school age. And we need your help to make that happen.

The play will premiere at Hibernian Hall, a multicultural performing arts center in Boston’s Roxbury neighborhood, from September 10-20, 2015. We'll then take the production on tour for three performances – at Westfield State University in Westfield, MA; Trinity College in Hartford, CT; and the Academy of Music in Northampton, MA.  Your support will help us cover the costs of the tour – and promote the play to other colleges, high schools, and theaters around the country.

WHY NOW?

This year marks the 50th anniversary of the arrival of the first U.S. combat troops in Vietnam and the 40th anniversary of the end of what the Vietnamese call “the American war”.  But ask any college or high school student in this country about the Vietnam War, and the likely response will be: “I don’t know much about it. We never covered it in history class.” Now Congress has given the Pentagon $65 million to alter the image of this disastrous and devastating war and paint it as an honorable, even noble endeavor. 

ASKING CRITICAL QUESTIONS

The Draft provides a sampling of the personal truths of young Americans who struggled to make sense of it all – and to do the right thing. Thus, amid the continuing public debate about “the lessons of Vietnam”, the play is also an educational tool: With all the immediacy and intimacy of live theater, The Draft asks questions that are as urgent and relevant now as they were back then: about the nature of patriotism, the role of dissent in a democracy, the impacts of war and militarism, and the transforming power of social movements.

For those who lived through it, the Vietnam War remains a divisive topic. We believe that The Draft can also contribute to healing the many still-festering wounds from those turbulent times.

HOW WE’LL USE YOUR GIFT

We need to raise $18,500 to cover the following costs:

  • Pay and per diem for the artists (actors, director, writer and crew)
  • Travel
  • Accommodation
  • Equipment rental
  • Performance space rental
  • Promotional campaign including production and distribution of a videotaped performance of the play.

We’re excited. Our cast and crew are excited. And we believe our audiences will be moved and inspired!

Thank you for your belief and support.

story:
"It costs a lot to look this cheap."

The video is full of fibs. We're not reality TV rejects who have cobbled together a shambolic make-shift gameshow to attract the attention of Channel 4's casting directors and become the 'next Jade Goody'.

We're actually four Theatre graduates from the University of Warwick - and our theatre company, Tit4Twat, aims to create interactive experiences which a) question the role and responsibility of audiences, b) comment on the dilemmas of our media-saturated society and c) appeal to those who love theatre but also those who hate it.

LOSERS, our debut show, is a tongue-in-cheek (and slightly controversial) look at the dark side of reality TV - with audience participation at its forefront. Battling it out over eight nail-biting rounds to prove their multitude of questionable 'talents', the wannabes will do quite literally anything to ensure the audience keeps voting for THEM. Lots is left down to chance, and only one thing is for certain. Shit will go down. To whom, though, is entirely up to you. And the reason why this show is not your average night out at the theatre.


Where We've Been

LOSERS was originally created as our final year dissertation performance - to explore the ethics of participation and manipulation in reality TV and live performance. Warwick University loved it, the show seemed to be a hot topic of conversation all over campus for weeks and we quickly decided we could not keep our voting handsets in a dusty box.

We soon received an incredible offer from The Rag Factory on Brick Lane, and made our professional London debut in January 2015 - performing the show over an amazing twelve nights to sold-out audiences and incredibly positive reviews:

“A cleverly constructed dramatical piece that educates and challenges throughout the performance”, ★★★★, West End Wilma

“Truly interactive and innovative theatre…the interactive nature sets it apart from anything I’ve seen before”, A Younger Theatre


Where We're Going (And What We Need)

Whilst getting onto Geordie Shore is tempting, the real dream is to make LOSERS tour-ready. We want to be able to jump on a train - suitcases of props, set and tech in hand - and perform at venues, festivals and fringes all around the country. Why? Because we love what we do, we're passionate about raising the profile of our theatre company and we want non-Londoners to have the chance to see the show.

The next step on the LOSERS journey is opening the Camden Fringe - a huge honour that we're really excited about. But until now, LOSERS (and Tit4Twat) has been entirely self-funded. And we just can't afford to keep it that way for much longer.

In order to get the show ready for Camden and for future venues, festivals and fringes, we need to raise £1200 for three reasons.

  1. Equipment

    Lots of Fringe venues (Camden People's Theatre included) are unable to offer storage facilities. So we need to ensure all the equipment, set and props we use are ultra-light and transportable so we can easily take them home (and around the country when we take the show further). In addition, with often only 10 minutes to get in and out of spaces at festivals, it won't always be possible to suspend things from the ceiling so we needed to re-think some of our set.

    For this reason, we need to invest in new stand-alone screens (that we'll project onto), boxes (that are as lightweight as possible) and wireless microphones (that'll mean we don't need to waste valuable time taping wires down).

    And as makeshift as the aesthetic is intended to look, we want to make the show feel a little 'bigger budget' in terms of its production values. We want crazier costumes, a couple of additional outrageous props and to purchase a couple of quirky 'photoshoot lanterns' to make the lighting design more interesting.

  2. Rehearsal space

    We benefitted from a wealth of suggestions as to how we can make LOSERS an even more unforgettable theatrical experience - and are extremely keen to dedicate six days back in a professional rehearsal space to explore some new ideas, make tweaks to the show and even introduce brand new rounds.

    For this to happen, there's a couple of costs that we'll need to cover. Trains for Rachel to get down from her hometown of Wakefield, and a small rehearsal room hire fee to make sure we are exploring new ideas in a creative environment which is larger and more adaptable than someone's bedroom!


  3. Making sure London knows about LOSERS

    Camden Fringe is an extremely exciting prospect, but with loads of shows for audiences to choose from over the festival, we're naturally incredibly keen to ensure every single seat over our five performances is occupied!

    We therefore need to spend a small amount on making sure people have heard about Losers, and know how exciting it is. We need to get leaflets printed, get professional production shots (which can make all the difference with getting newspaper/PR coverage) taken and put a bit of money behind social media posts to ensure people interested in interactive theatre and reality TV know where to find us.


So be generous.

We hope we've explained clearly why we are asking for you to give us a small donation. And we'd love to reward generosity with some irresistably silly rewards - all of which you can find to the right!

If you have any questions, or would like to find out more about the show or our work, check out our website or email info@tit4twat.com.

Thanks in advance for your generosity, and for taking the time to read this.

Because we love what we do, we're passionate about raising the profile of our theatre company and we want non-Londoners to have the chance to see the show.The next step on the LOSERS journey is opening the Camden Fringe - a huge honour that we're really excited about. But until now, LOSERS (and Tit4Twat) has been entirely self-funded. And we just can't afford to keep it that way for much longer.In order to get the show ready for Camden and for future venues, festivals and fringes, we need to raise £1200 for three reasons.



EquipmentLots of Fringe venues (Camden People's Theatre included) are unable to offer storage facilities. So we need to ensure all the equipment, set and props we use are ultra-light and transportable so we can easily take them home (and around the country when we take the show further). In addition, with often only 10 minutes to get in and out of spaces at festivals, it won't always be possible to suspend things from the ceiling so we needed to re-think some of our set.For this reason, we need to invest in new stand-alone screens (that we'll project onto), boxes (that are as lightweight as possible) and wireless microphones (that'll mean we don't need to waste valuable time taping wires down).And as makeshift as the aesthetic is intended to look, we want to make the show feel a little 'bigger budget' in terms of its production values. We want crazier costumes, a couple of additional outrageous props and to purchase a couple of quirky 'photoshoot lanterns' to make the lighting design more interesting.


Rehearsal spaceWe benefitted from a wealth of suggestions as to how we can make LOSERS an even more unforgettable theatrical experience - and are extremely keen to dedicate six days back in a professional rehearsal space to explore some new ideas, make tweaks to the show and even introduce brand new rounds.For this to happen, there's a couple of costs that we'll need to cover. Trains for Rachel to get down from her hometown of Wakefield, and a small rehearsal room hire fee to make sure we are exploring new ideas in a creative environment which is larger and more adaptable than someone's bedroom!


Making sure London knows about LOSERSCamden Fringe is an extremely exciting prospect, but with loads of shows for audiences to choose from over the festival, we're naturally incredibly keen to ensure every single seat over our five performances is occupied!We therefore need to spend a small amount on making sure people have heard about Losers, and know how exciting it is. We need to get leaflets printed, get professional production shots (which can make all the difference with getting newspaper/PR coverage) taken and put a bit of money behind social media posts to ensure people interested in interactive theatre and reality TV know where to find us.

So be generous.We hope we've explained clearly why we are asking for you to give us a small donation. And we'd love to reward generosity with some irresistably silly rewards - all of which you can find to the right!If you have any questions, or would like to find out more about the show or our work, check out our website or email info@tit4twat.com.Thanks in advance for your generosity, and for taking the time to read this.

story:
Theatre artist Amy Crumpacker has been heading up groups of people since 2006 making community based theater, which is: by, of, and for the people. Working as the award winning Not Your Grammy's Theater, for the last 4 years in the Bayview/Hunters Point District of San Franicisco--a district going through tremendous change of demographics--we've collected stories from the many cultural groups in the district. We've written scenes, created a diverse ensemble of adult community members partnered with professional actors, and shared a few of our rehearsals with the community. Our goal is to get the grants needed for completion of our 'Love Letter to Bayview' project in the fall of 2013. We have a portable set, and respected partners—YMCA, Quesada Gardens Initiative, Infinity Productions, resident theater company of the Bayview Opera House. All we need is some financial support for the stipends for our grant writer and our youth intern. All we need is you! 

  

We at Not Your Grammy's Theater are seeking funds to give a $500 stipend to our grant writer for writing this season's grant and proposal applications. We are seeking $200 for our youth administration intern. This intern will be from the Willie Mays' Boys and Girls Club, and will give job skills to a local young person and help out NYGTheater at the same time.

 

The Impact:

Our Love Letter is all inclusive of all groups in the Bayview:  Artists, Business Owners, Homeless, Whites, African American, Chinese, Latino, Pacific Islander, Police, Criminals, and that's what makes our oral histories and scenes different from the rest of the community based projects in our village of the Bayview.  Already we've brought together individuals who would not normally be in the same room together, and dialogues have started for community change.  We are teaching artistic skills to adults, a sometimes underserved group in the world of community programs.   

Feel free to give as little or large as you can, as we get all funds from this campaign, whether we reach our goal of $700 or not.  And please share our campaign!

Thanks!
