story:
The Call

Despite the beauty of my life, I have often asked myself and the Universe what my greater purpose was. Why am I here? How can I make a difference in this world before I leave it? What can I do to shine my light? Aren’t these the questions that echo across time lines and across culture lines? I believe they are the questions that we all ask, at some point in our life.  I have been called on that deep search for new meaning and my legacy. 

In July of 2013, I received the first step to answering that question. I have created the space in my life to ride free, now it is time to dance. In a Shamanic Ceremony, I was blessed with a vision, a call from the Great Mother. In my vision She asked me to travel the world and learn women's dances from many different cultures. I am to make a pilgrimage to find these dances and bring them home into my body, home onto the land, and then home to other women. 

My name is Roxanne Mousseau. I have been a high school teacher for 10 years as well as a Mentor, Healer, and Guide. When I was a child I had two very big dreams - to dance and to ride horses. 

In the past three years I have learned to ride (finally) and have gone beyond that to become a certified Equine Assisted Personal Development Coach. I also have spent the past two years as teaching riding to youth while working with them to develop skills in leadership and living their Authentic lives. One of my greatest joys is when one of my clients (youth or adult) has the Aha! moment and their lives suddenly change because of what they have discovered inside of themselves. 

Riding my beloved horse to me has held some of the most profound moments of self discovery. She has been one of the greatest teachers in my life. I have come to a place now where we ride without tack (no saddles or pads) and only a bitless bridle (nothing in her mouth, just my reins) because of the feel of our connection when we are body to body. When we walk, trot, or fly in gallop across the land, I feel free, full, connected, and one with the Divine.

Dancing has always done the same thing for me. It brings me back into my body while being focused on that greater connectedness. Since this call has come, I’ve had the idea that it would be so powerful to be able to learn dances designed to create connection and play with them to help myself and others experience greater connectedness to the Great Spirit (God, Creator, Mother Earth, the Universe…whomever it is that works for you), to each other, and to our beautiful planet.

Dance takes us to other places inside our own souls. It allows us to access the spaces within us that have no words. It allows us to play in those spaces and bring them more fully forward into our lives. That’s when miracles happen.

I’ve played with this idea a little with some of the youth that I mentor and have seen tremendous results in seeing them do things they thought they could not do before after dancing around and moving their bodies until that old story of “I can’t…” no longer existed in their mind space or body space. These moments of dancing to let go has literally changed the lives of my students and has left me in awe of the possibilities to come. I want more! I want to learn more from around the world and bring it home.

Phase I of Dance the World will see me step out into the world as a pilgrim. I will first head to Bali followed by India, West Africa, Australia and New Zealand. In each place I will be seeking out tribal dances, ancestral dances, and the dance that connects us as humans to Spirit, to the land, and to each other. By learning each of these, it is my dream to help myself reconnect to Earth and heal more and then bring that connection and healing to others. The joy of dance is my legacy and my contribution to raising the energy and consciousness of our planet. 

This is my leap of faith, my quest to birth something new in my life and new to my world. Through that, to bring an old idea back to life for others – connection through dance. By helping me shed the much-loved, but stagnant life I have become comfortable in - you as a contributor will be helping to change the life of a woman who will bring that opportunity and space to change to the lives of many others. 

The Asking

“Pilgrimage is a powerful metaphor for any journey with the purpose of finding something that matters to the traveler” (Phil Cousineau in The Art of Pilgrimage).

The supporting of pilgrims is not only a gift to that person but a gift to yourself as well. When you provide for a sacred sojourner  you step into an energy that brings you to the growth, change, and beauty you are desiring for your own life. If you’ve always wanted to go in pilgrimage – take that grand adventure of your life time but you are constrained by responsibilities – this is a way to get that energy without having to drop your life to do so. There are those that are called to the path of travel and those that are called to support such journeys – it has been this way since time immemorial.

In deep gratitude I am seeking to raise $10,000 for Phase 1 of Dance the World. The money will be used to purchase the flights necessary to travel to the places I am called to seek dance, to provide thank you gifts to those people and families that host me as a Pilgrim and Dancer in the World, and also to provide food and lodging when I stay in places where I am not offered the hospitality of homes.  In the event that I do not reach my goal, the money will still be used as described above.

I have some unique and beautiful gifts in return for your support!

Donations of:

$1 - $50 will receive an invocation of the name of the donor or name of donor’s choice at the beginning of each dance I will learn and perform throughout my journey with mention of that invocation on my blog.

$51 - $100 will receive the above along with a 30 minute Angel Reading to connect you with your Angels, Guides, and Ancestors.

$101 - $200 will receive the invocation of the name of the donor or name of donor’s choice at the beginning of each dance I will learn and perform throughout my journey with mention of that invocation on my blog as well as a 1 hour, in depth Angel Reading to connect you with your Angels, Guides, and Ancestors to answer your life questions and bring insight to your life direction.

$201 - $300 will receive the invocation of the name of the donor or name of donor’s choice at the beginning of each dance I will learn and perform throughout my journey with mention of that invocation on my blog as well as a 90 minute Angel Reading and Healing session to connect you with your Angels, Guides, and Ancestors to answer your life questions and bring insight to your life direction and help remove any blocks that are currently standing in your way.

$301 - $400 will receive the invocation of the name of the donor or name of donor’s choice at the beginning of each dance I will learn and perform throughout my journey with mention of that invocation on my blog as well as a full 2 hour Catalytic Healing Session (this session is service that I provide as a catapult forward. By tuning into your body, energy, and spirit, I am able to take you deep into beliefs, patterns, stories, history - current and past life - and identify the area that needs to brought to the surface for forward movement to occur. This process allows an accelerated energetic reaction to arise which precipitates great change in the recipient's life).

$401 - $499 will receive the invocation of the name of the donor or name of donor’s choice at the beginning of each dance I will learn and perform throughout my journey with mention of that invocation on my blog as well as a full 2 hour Catalytic Healing Session (see description of session in previous paragraph), and a video of the first dance that I learn and perform while on pilgrimage.

$500+ will receive the invocation of the name of the donor or name of donor’s choice at the beginning of each dance I will learn and perform throughout my journey with mention of that invocation on my blog as well as a 1 hour Angel Reading, a full 2 hour Catalytic Healing Session, and a compilation video of the dances that I learned during my pilgrimage (to be produced and delivered at the end of my travels).

Please note that these gratitude gifts may be used by the donor themselves or gifted to a recipient of the donor’s choice with the recipient’s consent. Also, all readings and healings can be done in person (if location allows), over the phone, or over Skype. 

The Alternative

I recognize that not all folks, friends, and family that read this will be able to help financially. Don’t worry, a good portion of what I need isn’t financial resource!

Here are some other things you can do to help me out on my sacred journey:

·  Do you know places in the world, in different countries where I can find dances? Let me know by emailing me!

·  Do you have family or friends in the countries I have mentioned that would be willing to host a pilgrim? Please connect me to those folks!

·  As you are reading this, do you have an idea, thought, or feeling about a place that I should go check out from my listed countries or in other places of the world that I can travel to in Phase 2? Let me know!

·  And most importantly - Please share this through your social media sites (Facebook, Twitter, etc.) so that others will know of what I am doing. This will be one of the biggest things you can do to help! Just use those handy Indiegogo Share Tools and blast me out into your world!

I am definitely willing to offer some of the perks listed above for the requests listed above. When you get in touch with me, we can work out what that looks like in the way that is best for both of us.  

The Impact

“I offered my support in the form of cash and promotion of the Indiegogo site to a pilgrim.  She carried my energy with her on the path and changed my life in the process.  During the course of her journey to Brigid, the energies of Brigid entered my life as well and I found myself on the brink of a new venture that opened my life in ways I had only imagined before.  Having been on walkabout myself 10 years ago, I can speak from both sides of the process.  And the energies I received from the support I offered were similar in strength to those I felt on the journey itself all those years ago.  Supporting a pilgrim is a sacred action.  It comes with sacred rewards.  Step onto your path by helping another step onto theirs.”  -  Kelle Sparta, Thought Alchemist/Shaman/Coach, Spiritual Leader University

At the very least, your help will change my life and will fill it with more joy than I already experience. At most, you will faciliatate the space for change and healing for all the lives of those I meet and touch throughout my journey and in the coming years as I dance to the drum of my own heart, of the heart of the Great Mother, our beautiful Earth, and the rhythm that connects us all as human beings.

Thank you. Thank you for taking the time to read this, for sharing it, for your contribution in whatever form it takes. Know that I carry you with me in my heart whether I ever know your name or not and I wish you all the beauty and brightness life has to offer.

Sincerely,

Roxanne Mousseau

***


(To learn more about me please go to http://roxannemousseau.com OR to follow my preparations and travels visit my blog at http://blog.roxannemousseau.com )

story:
Tommy is your average mid twenties nobody living in New York City. He isn't what you would call a stand up guy. But when he comes home to find his girlfriend in bed with his teenage brother, his life changes forever. Thanks to new friends, spontaneous violence, and a little bit of whiskey, Tommy learns how to settle his scores like a motherfuckin cowboy.

SO! come see "How to Settle Your Scores Like a Motherfuckin Cowboy" a new Scandalous Western Romance Adventure set in modern day New York City. If you want sex, blood, cocaine, transvestites, and cowboy boots; this is the play for you.

This Production is part of The Riant Theatre's Strawberry Theatre Festival.

Starring!

Brent Rose 
Omrae Smith 
Katy-May Hudson
Pedro Aijon 
Bob Burns
Wesley Zurick 
Seth Clayton
and Sergio Maggiolo 

Written and Directed by Wesley Zurick 

At the Hudson Guild Theatre 

441 W 26th St

August 15th @ 8:00 pm 
18th @ 10:10 pm 
19th @ 6:30 pm 

To purchase tickets go to:
http://www.therianttheatre.com/item.php?id=182 

or call the box office: (646)-623-3488


(Being a cowboy ain't always easy. It comes with certain...costs. Such as actors, lighting designers, stage blood, cowboy boots, ninja costumes, fishnets, guns, knives, whiskey, cocaine... I could go on. So please, help a cowboy out. You won't regret it.)

story:
ECT needs your help to open Hurricane Season!!!

 

It's been a tough year for many independent theatre companies, this year being one of the hardest. With our annual festival around the corner, we need your help! This year marks the 10th anniversary of our original one act play festival and playwriting competition, Hurricane Season - and we want it to be the best ever. 

 

 

 

Throughout the years we have had writers submit scripts from all over the world, picking 9 out of over 100 scripts to produce this year.  That's 9 different shows with 9 different sets of directors, actors, props and costumes, and we also need to supply concessions, postcards and marketing in order to produce in the style our 10th anniversary deserves!  This year our staff includes:  7 directors, 28 actors, 9 playwrights, two designers, one stage manager, and four producers.  And the producers are doing it without expectation of pay - just because we love and support The Eclectic Company Theatre and its Hurricane Season endeavors!

 

 

 

Your help goes to fund the numerous projects our producers have to finish as well as ensuring that we are able to pay a small stipend to as many participants a as possible.  Every contribution counts! Whether its $10 or $100, your donation will ultimately help us open the show. With these additional funds (a relatively small amount), we hope to take some of the financial pressure off our non-profit Company!

 

 

 

 If you can't donate...no worries!!! Asking a friend or a family member to donate/ share our campaign helps! By you helping us get the word out there, we are steps closer to reaching our goal.  Help us launch our 10th anniversary Hurricane Season with style: donate today!

story:
A little bit about The How


We are an international ensemble of movers, actors, and musicians from all over the world. We started in 2016 and since have created work all around New York City. The How’s mission is to create a place for audiences and artists to be challenged by a multiplicity of viewpoints, forms, and stories. We believe in upending convention. We believe in creating a sense of place. We believe in taking the emotional temperature of the world and manifesting it in physical form. We’ve performed at The Tank, Irt Theater, Dixon Place, Rubulad, Montgomery Gardens in Brooklyn, and The Unruly Collective in Brooklyn. We love experimenting, we love involving musicians in our work.  We are so honored and humbled to be included in the Emergence residency program at Culture Lab LIC. This winter, they are providing space to a select number of artists across multiple disciplines to develop new work.

 

 

About the project

 

This is a residency to develop a 5 hour movement theater piece exploring the 5 stages of grief and the connection between people. The movement theater piece will be devised and created in rehearsal. What we are curious about is how do all of these emotions live in the body, how are they expressed? The past year has been trying, to say the least. Many of us have lost people, so many of us have been separated from family members, lost jobs, lost heart, lost feeling, and had to adapt. These feelings, this grief, settles in the body and starts to eat away at the soul if it isn’t looked at. This piece is an attempt to release some of this stagnated, heavy energy, and come to a place of catharsis, come to a place of healing through movement. 

We are starting the development of the piece with a series of digital rehearsals before moving into Culture Lab’s beautiful gallery space for in-person rehearsals.

The cast: 6 phenomenal movers and musicians based in NYC, working together to devise the piece directed by Polina Ionina.

 

 

This is a huge deal for performers who have been unable to work face to face. That’s most of us! The closest we get to that is on Zoom…and I think we’re all pretty tired of creating work on the internet. To say that the team is looking forward to this is an understatement. 

While the pandemic has caused a momentous amount of strain on the world at large, it has been no less problematic for artists. Connection and collaboration are key ingredients to working as an artist, as well as the necessity to actually perform live. While virtual communication has been helpful to bridge the gap during this time, it cannot replace the overwhelming necessity of in-person human contact and connection. There is still so much uncertainty as to when the performing arts world can resume regularly without complications. One thing is for certain: art and expression are needed now more than ever in order to make it through these tumultuous times. Since our work is developed largely through improvisation, it is so important for us to have the space to create. Without the cost of rental fees [or outside COVID exposure,] we are able to set the groundwork to later expand and refine for performance when we can perform safely again.

 

 

Since this is an in person residency the nature of how we’re accomplishing this is: 

We’re asking everyone involved to get tested 72 hours before the date of the in person rehearsals. Everyone must receive a negative test. Then we’re asking people to sleep over in the gallery space for the 5 days of in-person rehearsals. This is the only way we can be the safest and fully immerse in the work.

In the space, there is a kitchen and shower! We will be rehearsing together and cooking together! 

While we are graciously being given the space to both rehearse and live in, there are still other costs that are necessary in order for us to make this happen. This is where you come in!

 

 

Why we need your help:

 

Your contribution will cover our residency cost amounting to $1555:

$900 to pay our team of 7 for the duration of the creation of the project

$270 to feed our team of 7 for the 5 days of the workshop

$255 to cover production costs 

$100 for gas and transportation

$30 for a glass of wine for all of us after we’ve rehearsed our butts off in the middle of a pandemic.

Anything extra that we get during fundraising will go into our fund for a full run of this production…

 

 

About the Director: 

 

Polina Ionina is an innovative movement theater maker. 

Visceral, simple and theatrical, Ionina’s work is characterized by the unique methodology she employs with her dancer/actors. Ionina is a co-founder of The How, an International Performance Ensemble that was created to provide opportunities for actors to play and explore new ways of creating by bringing disciplined artists together from around the world.

If you would like to find out more information about Polina’s work and previous work at The How visit: www.thehow.nyc


Interested to see full cast? Visit: https://www.thehow.nyc/meet-us

 

 

About Culture Lab:

 

The Culture Lab LIC realizes just how critical art is right now. They have been instrumental in helping artists during this time of great uncertainty. Starting with the Culture Lab sessions this summer, they turned their parking lot into a live performance venue providing music, comedy, dance, and food. Here people could gather in a safe and socially distanced environment to enjoy the performances and foster community. Now throughout the winter, they have continued to provide these sessions to the public, by live streaming music from the space every week until it is warm enough to resume outdoors again. Having the actual time and space for artistic expression, connection and development is a truly beautiful and cherished thing during this time. 

Read more about the residency program: https://www.culturelablic.org/emergence-residen...

We are grateful to our community for supporting us and believing in the power of the arts, especially in this difficult time.

story:
Creative Difference & Co presents 

ANTIGONE: PRESENTED BY THE GIRLS OF ST. CATHERINE'S (an excerpt)

Written by Madhuri Shekar

Directed by Tara Paterson

“A fantastic ensemble piece for young women that is both beautiful and tragic - just as its source material can be. Each character is a delightfully and intriguingly full person who I could gladly watch for far longer than the length of the play. And along with the brilliant way this play uses Sophocles' Antigone and creates something even bigger, I love that it challenges the notion of "the show must go on" and asks us if that is truly the healthiest mentality to promote.” - Audrey Lang, New Play Exchange

Creative Difference & Co produces engaging , thought-provoking, and relevant content with diverse and inclusive narratives. Our first production is a 60 minute excerpt of Madhuri Shekar's masterpiece, Antigone: Presented by the Girls of St. Catherine's. The play makes its first appearance in Canada and exclusively for the Toronto Fringe Festival. 

Starring a powerful, diverse and stellar cast, this coming-of-age story follows the girls at St. Catherine’s boarding school as they struggle with their identity, sexuality, morality, and putting on their play, Antigone, amidst an unforgivable betrayal by their beloved director.

Beautiful. Raw. Provocative.

 

What We Need & What You Get

The project has been a labour of love for the producers of CD&CO who've poured their heart, souls and wallets into making art in the midst of a global pandemic and COVID restrictions. The goal was to deliver a top notch production, while keeping our artists healthy and safe. The process was challenging as it was rewarding. 

In order to take it to the next level (an potentially on the road!), we're looking for like-minded artists and lovers of the arts to support us by promoting and donating to this movement so we can not only finish production of our virtual play, but launch a live tour when things open and ultimately, bring to life the dreams of other artists in our community. 

All funding will go towards production costs, which include: venue rentals, editing, equipment rentals, food, staging, props, advertising, travel and much more.

Here are just a few of the incredible perks we've put together for our supporters:

  • Complimentary tickets to view the show on the FringeTO platform
  • Signed poster from cast and crew
  • Special video shout outs on social media
  • Production help from the Creative Difference & Co

The Impact

Your contribution not only helps this incredible story come to life, but helps us share the love by producing the works of other artists, through a joint venture with Monologue Slam Canada. Our goal is to bring theatre back to Toronto and rebuild this community. 

  • If you're an artist  or supporter of the arts, you know that most small theatre spaces have closed and it will be a herculean challenge for artists coming out of the pandemic.
  • We're looking to share our experience and talents to help build back the small theatre community. 

Risks & Challenges

Some of the major hurdles to producing anything this year are lockdown, unclear guidelines, gathering restrictions, and the shortage of venues and resources. 

  • We rose to the challenge of producing a play during the pandemic and learned a ton doing so. It wasn't easy, but it was worth. 
  • Our goal is to share this experience with other artists. 

Other Ways You Can Help

We know that the past few years have been challenging financially for everyone. Any contribution helps, whether it's a small donation or sharing and cheerings us on. Here are af ew ways to contribute:

  • Make some noise about Creative Difference & Co!
  • Encourage people to support Fringe Toronto and our production of Antigone: Presented by the Girl's of St. Catherines. 
  • Post us on social media and share the links and hashtags #creativedifferenceTO #antigoneTO

story:
OVERVIEW
The Interrobang Theatre Company is a Baltimore-based, artist-driven, non-profit theatre that focuses on the development and production of new works by traditionally underrepresented voices. This fall, Interrobang will present the world premiere of Here We Are by Jen Diamond.

ABOUT THE PLAY
Amelia was the first female pilot to fly around the world. Now, she's dead. When she wakes up in the Underworld, she is forced by Death himself to confront the worst things about her time on Earth in order to forget them once and for all.

Here We Are is a re-framing of Amelia Earhart's history through a feminist, contemporary lens, exploring how the the men in Amelia's life tried their very best to keep Amelia down at every turn just because she was a woman who had big dreams. The story is told from Amelia's perspective and is inspired by real people and events from her life, with a healthy dose of artistic license and magical realism. Central themes exploring the power and destruction of patriarchal fear and Amelia's journey to overcoming that fear are what make the script so incredibly compelling.

Here We Are illustrates how important it is to allow and empower marginalized communities to tell their own stories, and explores what happens when those stories are lost to the narrative of white, male-dominated history and expectations. Amelia Earhart is a timeless symbol of female courage, tenacity, and ingenuity, and it is our hope that our audiences will recognize their own courage through her story of facing off with Death and discovering what it takes to make a place for herself in the world.

PLAY HISTORY
2014 - Jen Diamond wrote Here We Are while earning her degree at Johns Hopkins University.

2016 - Interrobang worked with Jen for the first time when she joined the 2016 playwright cohort of our Heavy Hors D'oeuvres short play festival. She wrote a script called Pretty Like Normal, which was given an encore performance at Charm City Fringe's Nights on the Fringe in June 2016. We enjoyed working with Jen so much that we asked her to send us more of her work. She shared Here We Are.

2017 - Interrobang produced a small reading of Here We Are through Hanging With Interrobang, a monthly reading series featuring new full-length works-in-progress by local playwrights with facilitated feed back sessions to aid the playwright in further developing their work. After hosting this reading, we knew that we wanted to produce Here We Are on a larger scale. The script had comedy, drama, poetry, urgency, and, at its core, a strong female character working to find her own voice to tell her own story. 

2019 - Throughout the summer of 2019, we worked with Jen to develop and hone Here We Are. In August 2019, we presented a new draft of the script to a full house at the Kennedy Center's 18th Annual Page to Stage New Play Festival. After receiving feedback there, Jen will provide one more draft before we head into rehearsals on September 30, 2019. Performances of Here We Are will run November 8-17, 2019.

ABOUT INTERROBANG
It is Interrobang's mission to develop new, relevant, potent theatre that challenges the Baltimore community to explore new ideas and have new conversations.

Interrobang has always been dedicated to the development of new plays since its inception in 2014. We work to empower our playwrights by providing as many resources and helpful eyes, ears, and voices as possible leading up to show time. We are always trying to educate ourselves and our guest artists to better talk about work-in-development in a way that is supportive, nurturing, and collaborative.

Here We Are is the first full production Interrobang has embarked on in nearly two years after a hiatus in 2018. We are excited to be back with a play very dear to our hearts by a phenomenal up-and-coming playwright. With your help, we will be able to tell this story the way it deserves to be told with a sophisticated, beautiful production featuring artists that have been compensated fairly for their time and talent.

We believe that Baltimore has the potential to become a vital hub in the contemporary theatre scene, and to do that more folks need to be able to access the theatre that is happening here. Your support will help us spread that access to and awareness about the vibrant theatre happening in Baltimore, and would give us the opportunity to build a more sustainable community for us all.

We are very excited to share that Here We Are is sponsored in part by Free Fall Baltimore. The first weekend of shows will be free to Baltimore audiences. Through Free Fall, we hope to engage with a new community of theatre-goers, and learn more about how to make our productions more accessible. Free Fall Baltimore is presented by BGE, and is a program of the Baltimore Office of Promotion & The Arts, an independent 501(c)3 non-profit organization.

story:
Qui suis-je ? 

Évoluant en tant qu’interprète et chorégraphe en danse contemporaine depuis quatre ans, j’ai eu la chance de danser pour des chorégraphes aussi prestigieux et diversifiés que Ginette Laurin (O Vertigo), Ismael Mouaraki (Destins Croisés) ou encore Dana Gingras (Animals of Distinction / The Holly Body Tattoo). Ce parcours m’a aussi mené sur plusieurs scènes internationales, et à chaque fois, le bonheur de faire partie de ceux qui participent au rayonnement de notre culture n’en n’était que plus grand ! Mais cette fois-ci, pour la toute 1ère fois, c’est mon œuvre en tant que chorégraphe; [ID] DOUBLE, qui s’exporte au plan international - et j'en suis très fier !! :) 
 

C'est quoi [ID] DOUBLE ?

En 2013, un documentaire au sujet de Maria Callas interpela ma sensibilité de chorégraphe. Ce n’est pas tant sa prodigieuse carrière qui retint mon attention, mais plutôt sa personnalité complexe et troublante. Au-delà de sa force et de son assurance, un combat acharné se jouait en secret, qu’elle perdit d’ailleurs. C’est alors que l’idée d’une nouvelle œuvre naquit en moi : [ID] DOUBLE. 

Je créais un solo,  avec le profond désir de témoigner avec précision, force et humanisme, de la lutte qu’elle mena, s’évertuant à la fois à dissimuler sa vraie personnalité tout en se dévoiler en tant qu’artiste. Même si la Callas servait de trame de fond, je compris rapidement que toute artiste pouvait être confrontée au même problème, et qu’[ID] DOUBLE serait un thème universel. Et c’est exactement là que nous nous rendîmes : au bord du vide, entre chute et ascension - où le corps féminin porteur de cette gestuelle organique, fort et doux à la fois, allait se mouvoir avec fluidité dans l'espace et faire preuve d'une maîtrise assumée dans sa dualité exacerbée.

 

Et ensuite ?

En 2015, lorsque la 1ère représentation de ma pièce [ID] DOUBLE, eut lieu à la Maison de la Culture Maisonneuve de Montréal, je fus réellement ravi et touché de la confiance que l’on me démontrait, mais surtout de pouvoir présenter mon travail chorégraphique. Plusieurs autres dates * se rajoutèrent dans différentes Maisons de la Culture, et plus récemment le prestigieux FIFA, Festival International du Film sur l’Art décidait de programmer la version court-métrage de 8 min. d’[ID] DOUBLE à son édition 2016 – tout un honneur ! J'étais comblé :)

* Maison de la Culture Maisonneuve, MONTRÉAL, Centre Phi, MONTRÉAL / FIFA 2016, Maison de la Culture Rosemont, MONTRÉAL, Théâtre Fairmount, MONTRÉAL, Maison de la Culture Mercier, MONTRÉAL, Maison de la Culture Marie-Uguay, MONTRÉAL ...

 

Maintenant plus concrètement ?

Heureux de tout cela, je ne m’attendais néanmoins pas à recevoir récemment l’offre exceptionnelle de présenter [ID] DOUBLE en France ! Ainsi trois représentations sont confirmées :  

  • Vendredi 25 novembre 2016 / Le Croiseur, Scène 7 à Lyon
  • Mercredi 30 novembre 2016 / Théâtre Jean Le Bleu à Manosque
  • Vendredi 02 décembre 2016 / Le Regard du Cygne à Paris

Pour ce déplacement, nous serons seulement quatre personnes à nous y rendre : LAURIE-ANNE LANGIS; danseuse interprète et collaboratrice à la chorégraphie, moi-même; chorégraphe et répétiteur, l'éclairagiste et le directeur de tournée, opérateur son et coordonnateur diffuseurs et médias. Pour mener à terme ce projet, je dois compléter mon budget et c'est exactement ici que vous pouvez me soutenir ! 
 

Votre contribution va servir à quoi précisément ?

Votre contribution servira directement au financement du projet, c'est à dire cela permettra de compléter les dépenses suivantes : 

- billets d'avion aller-retour Québec-France de l'équipe,
- transports en France ; trains, navettes, métro,
- hébergements en France,
- per diems de l'équipe en France,

Actuellement le financement est assuré à 60%, il manque donc un 40% soit 3 000$, que je souhaite compléter par ce financement participatif. 

Finalement, pourquoi ce projet est si important et votre contribution essentielle ?

Ce projet de présenter [ID] DOUBLE en France est un aboutissement exceptionnel qui marquera un tournant décisif dans ma carrière de chorégraphe. Tout d’abord, il y a cette rencontre avec un tout nouveau public qui m’est donnée de pouvoir vivre. La possibilité pour un chorégraphe d’offrir son travail à un regard neuf et étranger est un  accomplissement résolument enrichissant, car il remet aussi en question certains acquis, et confronte l’artiste à une probable insécurité. Ensuite, il y a l’impact direct et majeur qu’une tournée en France peut entraîner sans son sillage, c'est à dire interpeller d'autres diffuseurs au niveau international, et envisager d'autres représentations à l'étranger ! :) 

Votre contribution est donc essentielle à ce stade-ci, elle me permettra de compléter le budget nécessaire à la réalisation du projet, en plus de contribuer à l’exportation et au rayonnement de la culture québécoise au niveau international, la tournée [ID] DOUBLE en France ne peut être que bénéfique en termes de retombées nationales et internationales. Ces bénéfices auront un impact direct autant sur mon travail chorégraphique que sur l’avenir et le développement de ma carrière, entraînant dans mon sillage plusieurs autres artistes avec lesquels je collabore. 

D'avance, merci !! :)
story_txt:
Qui suis-je ? 
Évoluant en tant qu’interprète et chorégraphe en danse contemporaine depuis quatre ans, j’ai eu la chance de danser pour des chorégraphes aussi prestigieux et diversifiés que Ginette Laurin (O Vertigo), Ismael Mouaraki (Destins Croisés) ou encore Dana Gingras (Animals of Distinction / The Holly Body Tattoo). Ce parcours m’a aussi mené sur plusieurs scènes internationales, et à chaque fois, le bonheur de faire partie de ceux qui participent au rayonnement de notre culture n’en n’était que plus grand ! Mais cette fois-ci, pour la toute 1ère fois, c’est mon œuvre en tant que chorégraphe; [ID] DOUBLE, qui s’exporte au plan international - et j'en suis très fier !! :)  
C'est quoi [ID] DOUBLE ?

En 2013, un documentaire au sujet de Maria Callas interpela ma sensibilité de chorégraphe. Ce n’est pas tant sa prodigieuse carrière qui retint mon attention, mais plutôt sa personnalité complexe et troublante. Au-delà de sa force et de son assurance, un combat acharné se jouait en secret, qu’elle perdit d’ailleurs. C’est alors que l’idée d’une nouvelle œuvre naquit en moi : [ID] DOUBLE.

J'étais comblé :)

story:
What is happening!?

This legendary venue, one we watch youtube videos of all the time, has contacted US(!!!!!) to perform concert versions of Jurassic Parody: The Musical! and How I Met My Mother: A Back to the Future Musical Parody. 

  • Who is 'US'? We are a semi-professional theatre group in Vancouver, Canada, prioritizing body-positivity, warm humour, inclusivity, LGBT+ casting, diversity, and PAYING OUR ACTORS! We perform mostly original parody-based content with the goal of getting people into theatre who might not otherwise have explored it. You might know us from Vancouver stages or Youtube, where you can find our Portal 2 musical panto or our Star Wars parody burlesque spectculars!
  • This is the chance of a lifetime for all of us. Getting seen by industry professionals in New York City, and achieving the ultimate dream of getting to perform our work Off-Broadway. We are excited AND scared at what this could mean for us.
  • ...However, the latest dates they had available when they contacted us this week were September 22nd and 23rd, 2017. That's in EIGHTY FOUR DAYS!?!??! We all have jobs and rent to pay, as well as a Fringe show we can't get out of (nor do we want to-- it's a huge passion project). We don't have a lot of time to get this organized and together! 
  • Notable performers that have been onstage at 54 Below include Lea Salonga, Matthew Morrison, Santino Fontana, Andrew Rannells, and dozens of other Broadway luminaries. To grace that stage ourselves would be beyond overwhelming and special. Performing in New York is our biggest dream.
  • Want to know more about 54 Below? https://54below.com

What We Need

Your love and good vibes, first of all!

  • Your contribution will go directly toward our work visas, our flights, and our accommodation. We'll be paid by the venue, but not enough to offset the cost of making this happen, as they usually focus on performers who are... already in New York.
  • If we don't reach our entire goal, we're all moving back in with our parents. Are we kidding? Probably not. We've GOT to go! This could be our big break, for real.

The Company

This is our cast and band (alphabetically)!

Katherine Alpen - Lex (Jurassic Parody), Ensemble (BTTF)
Jesse Alvarez - Everybody Else (Jurassic Parody), Billy Zane (BTTF)
Maia Beresford - Ellie Sattler (Jurassic Parody), Jennifer (BTTF)
Stephen Blakley - Alan Grant (Jurassic Parody), Ensemble (BTTF), associate producer, additional writing
Patrice Bowler - Dinosaur Ensemble (Jurassic Parody), Ensemble (BTTF)
Ryan Caron - Tim (Jurassic Parody), Ensemble (BTTF), co-director
Ross Foster - Gennaro (Jurassic Parody), Biff (BTTF)
Erik Gow - Muldoon/Nedry (Jurassic Parody), Marty McFly (BTTF)
Matt Grinke - Piano
Fairlith Harvey - Dinosaur Ensemble (Jurassic Parody), Ensemble (BTTF), co-director
Alison Jenkins - Tyrannosaur (Jurassic Parody), Ensemble (BTTF), vocal director
Seth Little - John Hammond (Jurassic Parody), Doc Brown (BTTF)
Taegan Mohle - Brachiosaur (Jurassic Parody), Ensemble (BTT)
Ian Montgomery - Percussion
Hal Rogers - Mr. Arnold (Jurassic Parody), Marvin Berry (BTTF)
Graeme Thompson - Ian Malcolm (Jurassic Parody), George McFly (BTTF)
Stanley Tsang - Bass/guitar/music director
Erin Walker - Janine the Velocitapper (Jurassic Parody), Lorraine (BTTF), choreographer

For Jurassic Parody - Lyrics by James Dunlop. Book and additional lyrics by Fairlith Harvey and Stephen Blakley. Additional jokes by Beni Spieler.
For How I Met My Mother - Lyrics by Abbey St. Brendan. 'Great Scott, Marty' by James Dunlop. Book by Fairlith Harvey. Additional jokes by Stephen Blakley.
 

Other Ways You Can Help

We REALLY HATE asking people for money, so please don't worry if you can't contribute! How you can help us:

  • Please let people know about this campaign! If each of our Facebook fans gave five dollars, we'd be more than able to go!
  • If you're one of our treasured American fans, please buy a ticket to our performances once they go on sale! We'd love to meet all of you!
  • Send memes.

HERE IS A CHART OF THE COOL THINGS YOU CAN GET!

story:
Why This Story?

We are all struggling to be seen, to be heard. In this adaptation he writer has chosen to focus on opening up the mind of someone who is struggling with serious mental illness (specifically anxiety and depression) and create a landscape in order for those on the outside to see what is actually going on. Our goal is to tell an honest story of trying to survive patriarchal systems of oppression and give voice to and validation to the mental health struggles that come with that.

For more information on the original myth you can check out the story here on Wikipedia.

What We Need

Art is work and it is our goal to be able to pay our artists what they are worth. Our production is low-key as far as physical design elements, but we still would love support to make this all it can be. With your help we will be able to :

  • Pay actor and designer stipends
  • Pay off the space right away
  • Charge less for tickets to make our production more accessible

Our goal is accessibility and inclusion and that doesn't stop at casting; we want our audiences to feel welcome and excited to hear these stories for the first time. 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • You can support us monthly on Patreon!
  • Spread the word! Word of mouth is more powerful than any other media.
  • Share, share, share! Social media is the second most powerful way to hear about events like this.
  • Come see the show. After all, we couldn't have done it without you. :)

Who We Are

​​Stage Rage was originally conceptualized by Megan Tripaldi and Beth Somerville in Portland, ME in 2014 with the creepiest production of King Lear (at least that we had seen).
From there we have been generating projects that create original concepts for established work or creating and supporting new and exciting work from local artists based on myths, legends, and stories that have been around for centuries.
​We want to continue asking why we return to classical works. Why do we keep telling these stories? How can we make them more relevant?

story:
What We Are Doing:

Following over a year of rehearsal and a Fall 2014 workshop at New York City’s Dixon Place, HamletGhosts is being performed in both New York City and Rochester in the upcoming months. First, it will be presented at HERE Arts Center August 3rd through 5th as part of their SubletSeries@HERE: Co-op  and then it will debut in Rochester as part of the First Niagara Rochester Fringe Festival in September.  We are so excited to bring this to audiences in both New York City and Rochester – but we need your help!

Alongside director Cody Holliday Haefner, the cast of HamletGhosts and reconstructs Shakespeare's Hamlet for a modern audience. Through a series of vignettes mixing Hamlet with Lady Gaga, Yahoo Answers, and personal narratives, witness the guts of Hamlet without any of the plot. Whether you know what happened to Rosencrantz or don’t even know this Hamlet guy, dive head first into this fun and radical new show. It's a sexy meditation on death with a clown! 

What We Need & What You Get:

We’re asking for your help in raising $4,500 needed to further develop the show and help us hit the road! It's an ambitious sum, but also a modest one given we have two productions to mount, and have to fund an entire cast's travel to Rochester.  Here are a few things that your tax-deductible donation will help fund:

$30 provides the costumes for one actor

$60 puts a roof over our heads for a whole rehearsal

$150 enables us to purchase all of our props

$250 fuels us to Rochester and back

$500 tells the world about HamletGhosts

$650 rents a van to help transport our 10 actors to Rochester

We're so grateful for every single donation, and to express our gratitude we've included some cool perks to the right that we encourage you to check out.

Tell Everyone:

Your contribution means the world to us, but so does your word! Crowdfunding only works if we have a crowd, so strut your philanthropic side on all your social media networks! 

The Artists:

Rebecca Clark, Claudia Givings, Cody Holliday Haefner, Alex Hare, Julia Izumi, Emily Kaplan, Kaitlin Kaufman, Jake Lasser, Olivia Levine, Theo Maltz, and Matthew McShane.

Who We Are:

Cody Holliday Haefner is ecstatic to bring HamletGhosts to his hometown of Rochester! Cody is a theater director and deviser based in NYC and a founding member of The Brewing Dept. With TBD, he co-directed The Lady from the Sea and was recently seen in Emily Kaplan’s devised piece STAN at Dixon Place. Select directing credits include The Connected (FringeNYC), The Arab (Manhattan Rep), NAKED (Fresh Fruit Festival reading), Terremoto (Barnard College reading), and bare: a pop opera (MuCCC). Cody graduated from Columbia University with a B.A. in Drama after directing LaChiusa’s GLORDAY as his senior thesis.

The Brewing Dept. is a group of 20-something theater-makers (actors, composers, clowns, designers, devisers, directors, dramaturges, playwrights) who’ve been making a meaningful impact on the way theater is made in our home town, New York City.  We’ve promoted emerging artists, committed to and delivered long-term (multi-year!) creative and financial support in development of their work, and fostered a community that enables exploration, creativity, and artistic sustainability. Having begun it's development in 2013, HamletGhosts exemplifies TBD's mission and commitment to giving artists an extended process to work on their piece.

HamletGhosts's August production is part of SubletSeries@HERE: Co-op, HERE’s curated rental program, which provides artists with subsidized space and equipment, as well as technical support.

story:
The Actor's Nightmare is a dark comedic play writen by prolific american writer  Christopher Durang. the plot revolves around accountant named George Spelvin, a man erroneously recognized  as an actor and  involuntarily thrust into the spotlight and into the role of to performer for a play with which he is unfamiliar. 

This production is the collaborative effort between seniors Jeremy Suarez, Jacob Wade, and Ramsey Heitmann and is a part of the SUNY Purchase PPL! In order to bring our vision to fruition, unfortunately our actor's nightmare has been empty wallets. Please help us get the funds we need to let our show shine.

Here are a few fun perks for supporters of our campaign.

10$ Special thanks in our program

20$ A reserved seat for our production in the Spring (all prior perks included) 

50$ The Actor's Nightmare commemorative pin and thank you letter from the creative team (all prior perks included) 

100$ A Commemorative pillow signed by the cast and Printed Production stills (all prior perks included) 

Any amounts donated in between will be rewarded with the closest tier of perk. Thank you so much for your help and we look forward to lights up in the spring. 

Love,

The Actor's Nightmare Production Team

story:
Chapitres de la chute - Saga des Lehman Brothers - 

R É S U M É   D E   L A   P I È C E :

Septembre 1884, un jeune Juif de Bavière, Heyum Lehmann, débarque en Amérique comme des milliers d’autres avec lui. Les douaniers d’Ellis Island se chargent rapidement de le rebaptiser Henry et l’homme file vers l’Alabama. Parti d’absolument rien, il monte avec ses deux frères un petit magasin de tissu appelé à devenir le premier endroit de négociation de coton du pays.

Septembre 2008, minée par les «subprimes», emprunts pourris qu’elle a créés et vendus sans ménagement aux classes moyennes américaines, la Banque d’investissement Lehman Brothers, quatrième des Etats-Unis, s’écroule avec violence. L’entreprise qui avait pourtant survécu aux plus violentes bourrasques des deux siècles précédents (Guerre de Sécession et crise de 29) entraîne le monde entier dans sa chute. Cet immense empire financier patiemment élevé par la famille Lehman révèle ce en quoi il s’est transformé : un golem immatériel, cupide et insatiable. Mais en-a-t-il toujours été ainsi ?

Septembre 2018, Portrait-Robot présente au Périscope cette extraordinaire épopée. Une pièce monumentale en trois parties, qui se développe sur plusieurs générations en mettant en scène près de deux siècles de capitalisme américain. Des champs de coton du Sud au New York du tournant du siècle, de l’abolition de l’esclavagisme à l’apparition de la télévision, de la seconde guerre mondiale à la folie des marchés boursiers, de la sobre naissance à la spectaculaire chute finale.

P O R T R A I T - R O B O T

Portrait-Robot est une jeune compagnie artistique de la ville de Québec.

Voici notre historique et notre mandat :

Portrait-Robot pour la recherche de la vérité. Parce que le théâtre est souvent un casse-tête. Parce qu’il y a des essais et des erreurs. Parce que l’on doit être patient, intelligent, vif d’esprit, attentif aux moindres détails. Parce que tout est toujours en mouvement, en cavale. Parce qu’au départ, tout cela n’était qu’un jeu. Parce que l’on s’y fait rencontrer les disciplines artistiques. Parce que le théâtre peut être artisanal. (portrait) Parce qu’il peut aussi être technologique. (robot) Parce qu’il peut être une conjugaison des deux. Parce que c’est un devoir de mémoire. Parce que sans portrait, le Robot n’a pas d’émotion.

Femme Non-Rééducable / Anna P., présenté en mars 2014 à Premier Acte fut le premier projet. Fort d’un succès critique et public (salles combles tout au long des 3 semaines de représentation), nous avons ensuite envie de nous attaquer à une création brute. Cependant, dans un désir de conserver l’aspect « documentaire » sous-jacent à notre mandat, nous aborderons les thématiques communes à la fin de la vie de Van Gogh et au printemps érable de 2012. Le tout, relié par la vie d’un homme en perte de repères qui rencontrent les acteurs reliés à ces deux événements. Et, avec cette histoire, transformer l’information en poésie et créer Architecture du printemps, solo qui fût présenté à Premier Acte en mars 2016.

Fort de ces deux spectacles, Chapitres de la chute - Saga des Lehman Brothers - est la nouvelle aventure artistique. Le troisième Portrait-Robot.

 

À QUOI SERVIRONS VOS CONTRIBUTIONS ?

 

Avec cette campagne de socio-financement, notre objectif est concrètement d'amasser plus de sous afin de payer encore plus convenablement les artistes impliqués au sein du projet.  Chapitres de la chute est un spectacle de plus de 4h30 et exige, évidemment, une grande implication physique, émotive et intellectuelle de la part de tous les artisans du spectacle.  

À l'image de la famille Lehman, nous nous sommes investis dans ce projet sans compter les heures.  Nous croyons fermement en notre projet et sommes persuadés de sa grande pertinence dans l'écologie de la vie théâtrale de Québec.  Nous sommes aussi certains du goût de l'audace qui habite la population de la Ville de Québec.

Contribuer à notre campagne, c'est encourager l'énergie créatrice, confirmer notre croyance en ce projet, collaborer à ce que des projets du genre puissent voir le jour à Québec et réussir à payer de façon un peu plus convenable les humains investis dans cette épopée théâtrale.

 

L'IMPACT

Le monde financier apparaît fréquemment, aux communs des mortels, comme un casse-tête impossible à comprendre dans son entièreté. Nous vivons dans une époque où l’économie est fragile et le taux d’endettement très élevé ; près de 160 % au Québec. Lors des deux dernières années (2016-2017), c’est environ 40 000 consommateurs ou entreprises qui ont déclaré faillite ou soumis une entente de paiements à leurs créanciers. Des records. 


Il est inutile alors de préciser que, pour la majorité des gens, le visage de la finance et de ses dirigeants n’est pas reluisant. Il représente l’ennemi, le rapace, le riche qui se plaît à creuser l’écart entre les classes sociales. 


Sans croire que la pensée populaire bifurquera entièrement, nous considérons que ce spectacle offre des pistes de réflexions et de nouvelles visions sur ce monde complexe et difficile à défricher. En 2008, la faillite de la banque d’investissement Lehman Brothers est devenue le symbole de la crise de tout un système. Un système qui avait fini par échapper à ses créateurs, de même qu'il échappe encore aujourd'hui à la compréhension des non-initiés. Avec cette pièce, chaque spectateur mènera sa propre réflexion grâce aux indices, préfigurations et pressentiments de la chute qui jalonnent la pièce. 


La force théâtrale et politique de Chapitres de la chute est de remettre l'humain au cœur de l'élaboration d'un système qui, aujourd'hui, nous apparaît dépourvu de visage humain. 

Voici quelques extraits de critiques du spectacle, ils démontrent, selon nous, la grande pertinence du projet : 

"Franchement, le Théâtre Périscope démarre sa nouvelle saison en force avec cette pièce qui fait plus que jamais écho à notre société."

Ici Radio-Canada

"La proposition est on ne peut plus costaude — plus de 4h30 de représentation, 150 ans d’histoire à traverser — mais les personnages et les épisodes sont si bien amenés qu’on regarde la saga des Lehman Brothers avec autant d’appétit qu’une série addictive sur Netflix. »

Revue Jeu

« Le théâtre de la rue Crémazie ne fait pas les choses à moitié en ouvrant sa saison avec Chapitres de la chute, une costaude, ambitieuse et solide proposition  (…) on ne peut que lever notre chapeau aux comédiens qui portent ce spectacle ambitieux sans jamais lui laisser perdre son souffle. »

Le Soleil

 

PRENDRE DES RISQUES 

Nous avons pris un risque en choisissant cette oeuvre théâtrale.

Tout comme les Lehman ont pris des risques en débutant leur entreprise, en Alabama, au milieu du 19ème siècle.

Nous croyons fermement en la pertinence de cette pièce mais sommes bien conscients que, même avec un appui financer de diverses formes de subventions, le salaire de chacun des gens impliqués au sein du projet ne sera pas à la hauteur de leur investissement.

Nous savons aussi que ce spectacle est audacieux dans le cadre d'une saison régulière de théâtre. Il cadre davantage dans une forme de festival de théâtre.

Mais nous avons envie de cette audace, de ce risque, de croire.

En nous encourageant, c'est votre façon de démontrer que nous avions raison.

Et que vous croyez, vous aussi, en nous !

ÉQUIPE DE CRÉATION

Texte  : Stefano Massini

Mise en scène :  Olivier Lépine

Interprétation : Carolanne Foucher, Annabelle Pelletier-Legros, Maxime Perron, Jean-René Moisan, Nicola-Frank Vachon, Mustapha Aramis et Vincent Champoux.

Conception : Julie Levesque, Bruno Matte, Olivier Lépine et Josué Beaucage.

 

D'AUTRES FAÇONS D'AIDER !

N'hésitez pas à partager cette campagne !

Sinon, nous sommes en représentation jusqu'au samedi 29 septembre inclusivement.  Toutes les informations sont sur le site internet du Périscope, au www.theatreperiscope.qc.ca.

Venez voir le show !!!

story:
About and Upcoming Show:

Catch "MAYBE EVEN HIGHER" at the Performance Garage October 23, 24 and 27. Tickets $20 ahead, or at the door.
https://www.performancegarage.org/upcoming-perf...


Since 2016, ARTIST HOUSE /Asya Zlatina + Dancers has created original works for Philadelphia and beyond as a sole prop DANCE COMPANY. On May 1, we proudly gained LLC status, officially becoming another arts organization of Pennsylvania AND a female run business in 2019!
Thanks to your support, we have represented at:
The Philadelphia Fringe Festival, the Multicultural Dance Exchange, The Kennedy Center, The Jazz at Lincoln Center, Battery Park Dance Festival, the Koresh Come Together Festival, the World Heritage Cultural Center at the Philadelphia Convention Center, and as cultural ambassadors to the International Yiddish Festival in Bucharest.

Your generosity also serves our seniors in aging communities:
Margate JCC Holocaust Survivors group, the Rainbow Senior Center, the Hebrew Home of Greater Washington, and the KleinLife Holocaust Survivors group.

What Your Contribution Funds: Running a Dance Company!

Please support our latest endeavor: dancer's stipend and reimbursement. 
Additionally, every dollar goes towards one of the below:

  • Studio rentals can range from $18-45/hour. Creating a show takes anywhere from 15-20+ hours, rehearsal is key! 
  • Costumes
  • Venue rentals, tech and lighting support, application fees for festivals and showings.
  • OUR ONE-OF-A-KIND 2019 OPPORTUNITY FOR MORE INTERNATIONAL TRAVEL- we aim to build bridges across cultures and bring back our experiences to the city we live in!

You Can View Our Shows Online

  • "BARRY: MAMALOSHEN IN DANCE!" (2016) at the Kennedy Center's Millennium Stage
    https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NykX4fIgFqI&t=548s
  • "BARRY" at The Jazz at Lincoln Center as part of the Booking Dance Festival
    https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qYfmfhwIc5E
  • Commissioned work "Tous Les Dangers/Boundless Night" (2018)
    https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BIxkjHT8Ev4
  • "STORM" (2017) at Philadelphia's Fringe Festival
    https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Fmb0OoR8BUI&t=2606s
     
  • About "BARRY" as Senior Outreach 
    https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HXYp2IHlCN8&t=8s
     

Inside the Studio
 

Check out our rehearsals for how the shows come together, and see our works in progress.

  • Latest from "MAYBE EVEN HIGHER" (2019) https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3VuN_TR0qKc
  • Creating partnering movements in https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=T8-fmBD11Zs
  • "BARRY" was featured in Evan Davis's documentary film "I'M A DANCER", trailer here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UqwvYSMNLas&t=3s.
    FULL Available on TubiTv here: https://tubitv.com/movies/487315/i_am_a_dancer
     

Please share online and in your social media! Get the word out and make some noise about ARTIST HOUSE! :)

 

An enormous thank you to our very special supporters, you've been there from the start:
Sam Nemirovsky
Galina Teverovsky
Alina Kelman
Jeffrey Rubenstein
Bob Oliveti
Curt Bosson
Tina and Don Slater
Steve Katz
Ullman Family
Eugene Brusilovskiy

story:
You want to be free. You want to walk the streets of San Francisco and follow Jack Kerouac and Neal Cassady on the road. You want to follow them badly as you stare into faces of older men who rip you clothes apart and take you for granted. You want to shake your big hips as you are in control of everything and everyone around you. You want to possess and be possessed without seeming a little bit too slutty or whore like. You are in control of your own body and your fantasies, as you energetically type those words onto your friend’s type writer “I’m into you. Please be mine”. You remember that first kiss in the middle of a field, where his breath stank of LUCKY STRIKE, a present from an uncle from CHICAGO, and cheap wine.

THINGS THAT DO NOT C(O)UNT is an experimental feminist solo piece which explores themes of body positivity and female sexuality. World War II Poland, communist Poland and rapidly changing early naughties Poland as well as modern day London, serve as settings of this poetic story about three generations of women striving to claim their own bodies and desires. Partially autobiographic, Nastazja Somers’ multidisciplinary show co-created with Bj McNeill is a journey through time, space and body, a journey that aims to bring us closer to the understanding of body acceptance and our own longings.

Who are we?

No Offence Theatre is probably the only Polish Australian theatre company in London.

Nastazja Somers

Originally from Poland, Nastazja trained as an actress both in Dublin and London. She assisted directed Phil Willmott on his critically acclaimed productions of Fear and Misery of the Third Reich and Three Sisters and collaborated with Phil on the family show The Wawel Dragon at The Scoop. Nastazja is the founder and producer of HerStory: Intersectional Feminist Theatre Festival which challenges the misrepresentation of women in theatre. She is currently
working with Barbara Houseman on an all female project Dangerous Space.

Bj McNeill

Bj is the co-artistic director of No Offence Theatre.Originally from Sydney, Australia, Bj came to London several years ago to study acting.Prior to his move across the globe Bj studied at the prestigious NIDA in Sydney. His work includes assistant directing in Sydney on The Good Soul of Szechuan and in London on ‘Tis Pity She’s a Whore, directing Safe to Shoot for HerStory Feminist Theatre festival and working with Shunt on their immersive piece Monument.

 

What We Need

In order to be able to afford to put our time and creativity into this production we need to raise £1800 which will cover our marketing costs, rehearsal space, venue costs and most importantly paying our stage manager and designers. 

During the last two years we have mostly strived to support our work with our own money but unfortunately there is only so far one can get with freelancing gigs and working in hospitality.

Any donation no matter how small will make a difference to the quality of our experience with this piece, as we will be able to concentrate on the production instead of freaking out about money. Which happens a lot. It happens all the time.

The Impact

THINGS THAT DO NOT COUNT explores the subject of female body and body positivity. A coming of age, story that will hopefully spark conversations about the pressures and oppressions that women face on a day to day basis. Partially autobiographical the show also aims to investigate the connection between female body and politics, be it the politics of our societies or the regimes we live under.  We are currently in the process of partnering up with charities who raise awareness about eating disorders and body positivity.

We want women to feel empowered when they see this show.

We want them to see their own story reflected on stage.

We want everyone to understand that essentially women are not allowed to OWN and LOVE their bodies.

In short, we want to smash the patriarchy. Just a little bit more.  Bit by bit.

 

Risks & Challenges

Theatre is a place full of risk. As experimental creators we are at risk of being misunderstood, not understood or simply hated. But that's the risk that we are willing to take as theatre makers. Our shows always divide audiences and now after couple of years of being in this industry, we realise that this can work in our favour.

We are at a big venue so our biggest challenge will be to fill the auditorium with plenty of people. However with the right marketing strategy and the support we have already started gathering from creating feminist work, we are positive about our potential audiences.

Other Ways You Can Help

COME AND SEE THE SHOW

TWEET ABOUT IT

LET PEOPLE KNOW ABOUT IT

LET YOUR FAMILY KNOW ABOUT IT

SEND US AN EMAIL AND SAY HI. WE LOVE HEARING FROM PEOPLE.
story_txt:
You want to be free. You want to walk the streets of San Francisco and follow Jack Kerouac and Neal Cassady on the road. You want to follow them badly as you stare into faces of older men who rip you clothes apart and take you for granted. You want to shake your big hips as you are in control of everything and everyone around you. You want to possess and be possessed without seeming a little bit too slutty or whore like. You are in control of your own body and your fantasies, as you energetically type those words onto your friend’s type writer “I’m into you. Please be mine”. You remember that first kiss in the middle of a field, where his breath stank of LUCKY STRIKE, a present from an uncle from CHICAGO, and cheap wine.THINGS THAT DO NOT C(O)UNT is an experimental feminist solo piece which explores themes of body positivity and female sexuality. World War II Poland, communist Poland and rapidly changing early naughties Poland as well as modern day London, serve as settings of this poetic story about three generations of women striving to claim their own bodies and desires. Partially autobiographic, Nastazja Somers’ multidisciplinary show co-created with Bj McNeill is a journey through time, space and body, a journey that aims to bring us closer to the understanding of body acceptance and our own longings.Who are we?No Offence Theatre is probably the only Polish Australian theatre company in London.Nastazja SomersOriginally from Poland, Nastazja trained as an actress both in Dublin and London. She assisted directed Phil Willmott on his critically acclaimed productions of Fear and Misery of the Third Reich and Three Sisters and collaborated with Phil on the family show The Wawel Dragon at The Scoop. Nastazja is the founder and producer of HerStory: Intersectional Feminist Theatre Festival which challenges the misrepresentation of women in theatre. She is currentlyworking with Barbara Houseman on an all female project Dangerous Space.Bj McNeill Bj is the co-artistic director of No Offence Theatre.Originally from Sydney, Australia, Bj came to London several years ago to study acting.Prior to his move across the globe Bj studied at the prestigious NIDA in Sydney. His work includes assistant directing in Sydney on The Good Soul of Szechuan and in London on ‘Tis Pity She’s a Whore, directing Safe to Shoot for HerStory Feminist Theatre festival and working with Shunt on their immersive piece Monument. What We Need

We want them to see their own story reflected on stage.
We want everyone to understand that essentially women are not allowed to OWN and LOVE their bodies.
In short, we want to smash the patriarchy. Just a little bit more.  Bit by bit.
 

Risks & Challenges
Theatre is a place full of risk. As experimental creators we are at risk of being misunderstood, not understood or simply hated. But that's the risk that we are willing to take as theatre makers. Our shows always divide audiences and now after couple of years of being in this industry, we realise that this can work in our favour.
We are at a big venue so our biggest challenge will be to fill the auditorium with plenty of people. However with the right marketing strategy and the support we have already started gathering from creating feminist work, we are positive about our potential audiences.

Other Ways You Can Help

story:
Exit12's performance in Washington, DC

Exit12 - telling veteran's stories, beyond words, to heal the world.

Exit12 is heading to Washington, DC March 2nd-5th to perform at the Atlas Intersections Festival, inspiring community and vibrancy in the heart of the capital of the United States.  The performance will feature choreographic works by military veterans and loved ones, and stories of impact from the war zone.  The highlight of the evening will be the premiere of a new work-in-progress by US Marine Iraq War veteran Roman Baca -  an exploration of the impact of military training on individuality and personal experience.  

The Atlas Performing Arts Center gives audience members an intimate and up close experience, and an opportunity to chat with the company after the performance.

As part of Exit12's outreach, the company will be leading a movement workshop for military veterans and their loved ones in collaboration with the Armed Forces Arts Partnership.  

What your support means

Your gift allows Exit12 to perform and workshop in Washington, DC. This means reaching members of our community, whether they are service-members, veterans, loved ones, or supporters.  It also means providing fair pay for all of our artists and dancers. 

The Impact

According to the Suicide Data Report from the 2012 US Veterans Affairs study, an average of 22 US veterans commit suicide daily (Kemp, Bossarte, 2012). In addition, U.S. soldiers experience PTSD at rates of 21 to 29 percent. 

Exit12 has been moving with veterans, and sharing their stories for 10 years.  In that time our workshop participants have said:

"I'm not somebody who easily leaves my comfort zone," she said. "As Roman says, there's no wrong answer," said a US Army Veteran. "And if I do something weird, that's my thing that's weird. And it's mine."

"All these things help me to move into another world," said a US Army Veteran, "a world that's so different than I kept inside of me for so long."

Perks for you

Exit12 would like to thank you for your donation in a meaningful way by making you part of the company.  We have included many ways to thank you for your donation depending on giving levels including:

  • Personal "shout outs" through our weekly video blogs and on the Exit12 website.
  • Signed, suitable for framing, Exit12 performance photos.
  • Exit12 Challenge Coins (or a commemorative coin for our repeat donors).
  • A special Exit12 cocktail recipe delivered via personalized video.
  • Tickets to the performance.

Other Ways You Can Help

In order to produce this showcase, we need your help.  Please give to our Indiegogo campaign at whatever level you can. Every contribution is greatly appreciated, and we will be forever grateful for your kind support.

Please SHARE this Indiegogo link with your family, friends, 
co-workers, clients, email lists … post about it, tweet about it, email about it, talk about it, text about it, blog about it …

Gather some friends, buy some tickets, and come to the show! Or simply contribute, as you are able, and receive a keepsake perk as a thank you for your participation in this exciting movement!

story:
Short Summary

The Royal Medieval Faire has been a favourite community event in the Kitchener-Waterloo region for 15 years.  Established and evolved by volunteers, "The Faire" has pleased participants and patrons alike through friendship, creativity and effort.

The Faire is grateful for the corporate sponsorship it has received over the years, but that is becoming more difficult to acquire.  The fees to run the event have increased significantly over the years and the budget available for enhancing the experience has decreased.

Your support will allow us to add some delightfully new features such as different performers, new activities and games as well as period decorations and costumes.  We would love to provide the patrons of the faire with an expanded schedule of frolic and fun.

What We Need & What You Get

The Faire needs a influx of about $5000 to add some creative, innovative attractions.

  • Prizes for the games including new trading cards
  • A maze
  • New costumes
  • Some performers with different shows

Our perks are unique and fun.  Would you like to perform a staged swordfight at the faire?  Or have a photoshoot in favourite costume?  These are just a couple of great perks for your generosity.

The goal is $5000 but if we don't quite make it (or if we make lots more), all of the funds will still go toward enhancing the faire.

The Impact

Supporting the Faire will allow all the creative and hardworking volunteers an opportunity to see their ideas become a reality. The Royal Medieval Faire takes a year of preparation for our one glorious day and we hope to keep attracting new volunteers as well as new patrons.  

We have provided Waterloo Region with 15 medieval days over 15 years and we would like to entertain a new generation of patrons with colourful, exciting activities.  We want to keep your interest and garner new fans of our event.

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that not everyone can participate in this campaign, but we still need volunteers for the faire and if you can help spread the word about this site and our goals, we absolutely appreciate that!

story:
Help PlayGround Publications publish this year’s anthology of the season’s best scripts by pre-ordering a copy of The Best of PlayGround-Los Angeles (2015)

 THE BACKSTORY

Since 1994, the mission of PlayGround has been to support the development of new voices for the theatre. For over two decades, PlayGround has been a leading playwright incubator, providing unique opportunities for the cultivation and development of early-career local playwrights and partnerships with leading professional directors, actors, theatres and theatre lovers. In 2012, PlayGround expanded to Los Angeles with the launch of PlayGround-LA and its inaugural season in residence at the Zephyr Theatre.

Through the development of original short (and eventually full-length) plays, PlayGround-LA creates a microcosm of the greater theatre scene, supporting emerging playwrights' experimentation and risk-taking, while helping them hone their style and technique.

 PUBLISH OR PERISH

For the past fourteen years, PlayGround Publications has promoted the work of scores of emerging new playwrights and their short plays through the Best of PlayGround series of anthologies.

In mid-May, PlayGround Publications will print two new Best of PlayGround 2015 anthologies. You can help us in this mission by pre-ordering copies of the Los Angeles book through this Indiegogo funding campaign.

The book contains six scripts as performed at this year’s Best of PlayGround Gala new plays showcase (May 11, 2015). These six plays were selected as the best this season from more than 100 submissions and thirty-six works developed through the Monday Night PlayGround staged reading series.

Each script is printed in its entirety, creating an historical record of the development of these plays, with dates of first reading and premiere, original casting information and playwright biographies.

Proceeds of this funding campaign will be used exclusively to print and distribute the Best of PlayGround-Los Angeles anthology.

The Best of PlayGround anthologies:

  • Celebrate the best short plays of the past season;
  • Provide an economical way to bring high-quality audience-tested scripts to the attention of producers and educators;
  • Promote the work of new generations of talented playwrights;
  • Provide students and new dramatists with models of plays that have proven popular with audiences;
  • Creates an historical record of the development of these plays.

This year PlayGround is expanding the role of these books to help move the work of its talented emerging writers from page and into production.

The 2015 Los Angeles anthology contains complete scripts of the following plays:

Sexy Popcorn by Megan Breen
Meeting Matt Damon by Ron Burch
About Your Mother by Tiffany Cascio
Baby Black Jesus by Vincent Terrell Durham
Dinner Story by Mercedes Segesvary
’Til It’s Over by Jennie Webb

 CUT TO THE CHASE

By contributing to our campaign, you can pre-order copies of this year’s anthology which will be available in mid-May, 2015. This frees PlayGround-LA to invest its working capital in developing and producing the best new plays by Los Angeles's best new playwrights.

In addition to pre-ordering an anthology, if you are able to contribute more, we’ve lined up some swell perks as our way of saying thank you. If you'd like to pre-order multiple copies, please contact us for special rates.

Even though a great deal of in-kind labor is donated to support this publishing project, there’s no avoiding the need for cold, hard cash.

PlayGround Publications will use proceeds of this campaign to:

  • Print the 2015 Best of PlayGround-Los Angeles anthology;
  • Acquire ISBN numbers (yes, they cost money);
  • Market the anthologies to producers, educators, drama students, and fans of the theatre;
  • Create and distribute electronic versions of the anthologies.

Please support our campaign and help us jump-start the careers of some exciting new voices in the theatre community. Thank you!

  PlayGround Publications is a fiscally-sponsored project of PlayGround (Federal ID 94-3336399). All gifts to this campaign are tax-deductible to the extent allowed by law.

story:
define: ORPHAN

one deprived of some protection or advantage

As a young director, and being a part of a thriving theater community, it is important to interact and engage with the community in a way that is personal; distinct. This play magnifies the orphan that exists as part of being human; the individual, the outsider, the unique perspective.  We become more exposed (internet, social media) and vulnerable.  And in the space we call a theater we have the opportunity to be changed through the story.  In those moments of joy and sadness, laughter and tears we as audience are brought together to share in our individual experiences and to create, for a brief moment, a place where its okay to be orphans, where its okay to let down your guard. 

ward:trust

Small Theatre in Los Angeles is at a crossroads and this production is an earmark for the road ahead.  With your generous support, you will provide the opportunity to a young theatre company to continue to produce individual work during a time when that fabric is in peril.  The 99 seat contract at is core is a place for artists to play, to stretch, to explore and there is a chance that those opportunities will dwindle.  Through your donation you lend an individual voice to a multitude of artists across the city.

sponsor:custodian:part of a whole

The value of your contribution is immeasurable.  It will allow LA New Court Theatre to continue to grow and resonate within the community and to continue to support an environment for artists and audience to explore what it is about the human condition that is so unique.  To share stories.  To live lifetimes in minutes and seconds. To create together.  
We are asking that each person donate $10.  We are asking that because we want to give the opportunity for each voice to be shared, and each person the chance to breath life into these three amazing characters.  
All donations are welcome and are tax deductible to the full extent of the law.

root:reason:purpose

60% of this campaign will go to rehearsal space for the show.  It is in that space and time where we have the chance to explore the individuality of the show, discover the humanity in Phillip, Treat and Harold, and understand what questions we are attempting to ask.

30% will go towards cast and crew salary.  This show is demanding and it would be a great treat (a bad pun, i know!) to give back to those who have already given so much.

10% will be for marketing and promotion.  This how we here at LANCT can help foster the individual voice you have given to us.  

tribute:thank you

We are extremely excited to be working with Daughter Browne on this show and to have original music for this production.  Daughter Browne is working to create a soundscape unique to the world of Treat and Phillip, one that tells the story of the orphan inside us all. With each donation of $10 or more, you will receive a link to download the original music as well as our thanks on our website and in the theater lobby.

angel:advocate:patron

An equal and sustaining contribution is the gift of WORD OF MOUTH.  The donation of your time to share this campaign and help ignite this story is a valuable part of the theatre community and crucial to our success. 

Share with friends, family, people you might think would be interested.  Use the tools to share below or just copy and paste the URL.

Thank you for giving of yourself and of your time.

Sincerely.       ~ Samson


Orphans by Lyle Kessler

Starring :

Nathan Lee Burkart as Treat

Matthew Grondin as Phillip

&

Warren Davis as Harold

Creative Team :

Set Design: Sean Cote

Lighting Design: Brian Barraza

Costume Design: Jillian Clark

Fight Choreography: Matt Franta

Stage Management: Grace Earley

Produced by:

 Ashley Partington and The Los Angeles New Court Theatre
