story:
About The Project


In this 45-min romp through dance, storytelling and song, Sarah excavates the "childhood crap" rattling around in her head and her mom's midwestern basement. At once comedic and deeply personal, "Songs" sorts through the capitalist excess, gender socialization and family heritage that we accumulate on our way to making sense of who we are.​

 

This is a show meant for all audiences.

You need no performance dictionary or arts appreciation class to be able to engage with the work. Audiences munch on real Girl Scout cookies, cuddle Beanie Babies, and sing along to an oft-forgotten children’s song while contemplating Sarah’s question “What do you do with memories that no longer fit?”  It's a work that reminds each of us that our story is already worth telling, and that we can be simultaneously compassionate and critical as we sort through the raw material of our lives.

We know from audience and press reactions that this story, and the way we’ve told it, resonates deeply and personally with queer folks, people who are renegotiating their relationship to difficult pasts, or who are making changes in their lives, just to name a few. It is a work that deserves to live on, and to be shared. If we did all this as a two-woman powerhouse team, imagine what we could do with the support of a wider community!
 


 

Where Will The Money Go?


We’re looking to:

  1. Cover basic tour expenses like festival fees, transportation, lodging, and shipping props!
  2. Pay ourselves a $10 hourly wage for tour rehearsals moving forwards!
  3. Expand our artistic team to include local stage managers, collaborations with costume and lighting designers, and local visual artists, whom we will all compensate fairly!

We’re starting off with a reasonable fundraising goal ($3500) that is actually $1,424.10 less than our total projected budget. I’ve got skin in this game too, and am planning to cover any remaining expenses from my personal earnings.

We are expecting a small income from ticket sales (offered on a sliding scale to include as many folks as possible) and teaching master classes; and the possibility to save on housing costs by staying with friends and borrowing gear. Any profits will be reinvested into procuring future tour locations.
 

Challenges

Asking for money is scary!

Talk about childhood baggage- asking for money, talking about money, and ESPECIALLY asking for money to support my own art was something I was never supposed to do. My father, like many children of immigrants, was worried about the instability and respectability of an arts career for his daughter. So from an early age, I understood that if I was going to be an artist, I needed to prove the starving-artist stereotype wrong. And I did! I graduated college, got a day job and have funded everything I do through my own career as a UX Researcher ever since. But doing solo work has actually taught me the value of collaboration -- it’s necessary to making better work. I want this show to reach more people, and to keep sharing its message. I want to bring on more collaborators. And I can no longer fund it alone.


Booking more tours!

Providence Fringe Festival is booked, confirmed, and 100% happening. Knoxville is still in production conversations. We are actively reaching out to contacts in places like New Jersey (close), Seattle (far) and Italy (really far). We are developing an outreach package for colleges. If YOU know a small blackbox theater, a local festival or another organization that would benefit from a message about personal storytelling through the arts, please connect us!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

​

  1. ​Please share this campaign with your own networks! We are trying to reach new audiences and every signal boost helps!  A personal recommendation alongside a link is always best. Click the button on the top right of this page.
  2. Connect us to an organization in your town- we are looking for partners that can help draw an audience. If you have an idea, reach out to songsstuckinmybody@gmail.com

 

---

Special Thanks to Collaborators Past & Present

 

Ky Wyman, Providence Stage Manager 
Carmen Caceres & Hannah Wendel, Pitch Video
Ariane Michaud, Crowdfunding Strategy
Nina Levine, Clown Coaching/Early Research

story:
GENDER PLAY - a dance theatre project

Hi, 
I’m Martina Marini, a dancer and choreographer living and working in Italy/Southtirol. I’m the Director of the MartinaMariniDanceTheatre who wants to give professional dancers, which live abroad due to lack of job opportunities, the possibility, to do high quality work in Italy.


With my creative work I want to express my visions, ideas and thoughts, but above all, I want to tell a story. The expressive language I therefore use, is movement not only in it's form, but especially in it's intention. For the company, the most important thing is the content; dance is a mix of theatrical elements and everything is composed in a very experimental way. For the new project “Gender Play” I decided to work with two young and very motivated dancers, Anastasia and David.


The new project is a piece about gender identity, which plays with typical male or female movements or what the society perceives as. The dancers started from the question what a typical male or female movement could be, observing people on the street, discussing about the reasons. Do the difference depends on hormons, physics or education? Experimenting with our observations, playing with clichés and changing roles, we come up with interesting interpretations. During the working process which is based on movement research the dancers are developing their own material which is surrounded by gender topic and includes personal experiences but also stereotypes. The issue is treated in an ironic way, without neglecting the dramatic aspect of all the people, which are born in a wrong body.


We won an initiative, that allows us to take part in a big dance festival in Italy (Oriente Occidente 2015, 18th september 2015) where emerging companies can show their work, and we are very excited and grateful for this fantastic opportunitiy. What we do need from you in order to complete our choreography and to make the performance happen, is your support. We kindly ask for your help to cover the production costs for dancers, choreography, light design, costumes and video.

Our time and passion flows to our dancing and with you as a partner we would be able to cover the financial gap! Any help you could provide is highly appreciated and we  would be deeply grateful for any support from your side. 


Thank you very much!




David Bauer studied contemporary and classical dance at the "Hochschule für Musik und Darstellenden Kunst in Frankfurt am Main". He currently works as a freelancer mostly in Germany and Korea, and danced at the "Staatstheater Heidelberg" and the "Staatstheater Kassel", as well as the "Volkstheater Rostock". He worked amongst others with William Forsythe, Dieter Heitkamp, Reinhild Hoffman, Paul White and Nanine Linning.


Anastasia Kostner completed two Bachelor of Dance & Performance in Linz. In the following year she completed a Diploma at "Laban Trinity University" in London. Next to pursuing a Master of Arts at the "Hochschule für Musik und Darstellende Kunst in Frankfurt am Main", she started to work internationally as a dancer, working with  amongst others Robert Steijn, Doris Stelzer, Jonathan Burrows, Les Gents d'Uterpan, Thierry De Mey and Roberto Castello.


Martina Marini, born in Merano, Italy, completed her contemporary dance and dance-theater studies in Bologna and Rome, where she graduated also in a Master of choreography. At the same time she studied arts, fotography and scenography in the "Accademia di Belle Arti" in Bologna, Italy. For several years she was member of the "Chorea Company" as dancer and choreographer, back to Merano she worked as dancer and/or actor. She worked with Rhys Martin, Remo Rostagno and Arthur Rosenfeld (Pina Bausch). In Berlin she studied Butoh-dance with Minako Seki, Yumiko Yoshioka and Yuko Kaseki. In 2007 she founded the cultural association "Tanzschmiede/Fucinadanza", and in 2014 the professional dance company MartinaMariniDanceTheater. The new company debuts with the piece „Sehnsucht – Das Syndrom des Anderswo“ and won the third price in the choreographic contest Danzé in Rovereto 2014.


More information: www.martinamarini.com
